Last month, Parliamentary Budget Officer Yves Giroux said the $27.2 billion the Liberals have budgeted for the Canada-wide program would not be enough to meet expected demand . Giroux estimated the shortfall to be about $1 billion.
What if a deal isn’t reached by March 31?
All the experts agreed it is unlikely Ford will allow the March 31 deadline to pass without a deal, especially in an election year.
A senior Ontario government official recently told the Star’s Robert Benzie that an agreement will be reached well before the June 2 election.
Gould, the federal minister, said this past week she remains optimistic a deal will be done.
“But we’re running against the clock,” she said, reiterating the need for Ontario to submit its action plan.
Bhutila Karpoche, the Parkdale-High Park MPP and NDP critic on child-care issues, said in an interview that the Ford government’s “stalling” has put more than a billion dollars at risk, and it should have negotiated a deal much earlier.
While parents in other provinces are already seeing fees drop, Karpoche said, the opposite is happening in Ontario. “We’re not providing the relief for families that they desperately need.”
Ballantyne and others also laid the blame for the impasse with Ford’s government.
“If there was a major flaw in the federal government’s approach then we wouldn’t have 12 of 13 jurisdictions having signed on, especially provincial governments of all political stripes,” she said.
Given the looming March 31 deadline, pressure is building on both sides, and Ballantyne suggested they could potentially focus on finding common ground on a one-year agreement to salvage this year’s money, kicking the most contentious issues down the road.
“They may run out of time to be able to work out every detail by March 31,” she said. “But they probably could get far enough along to have a good agreement that would produce really good outcomes for families and for those who work in the sector.”
Brendan Kennedy is a Toronto-based social justice reporter for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @BKennedyStar

The pricey politics of transportation: We're seeing plenty of promises to make getting around cheaper, but who will pay for them?

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 07 Mar 2022: A.11.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/pricey-politics-transportation-were-seeing-plenty/docview/2636281220/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=The+pricey+politics+of+transportation%3A+We%27re+seeing+plenty+of+promises+to+make+getting+around+cheaper%2C+but+who+will+pay+for+them%3F%3A+We%27re+seeing+plenty+of+promises+to+make+getting+around+cheaper%2C+but+who+will+pay+for+them%3F&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Getting around the city can be a political act.
It's election season, so getting around is even more political than usual, with commuters of all kinds being wooed with treats. Some commuters more than others, that is.
Last month the Ford government announced licence plate renewal fees are being scrapped. That's an awful lot of money out of the provincial coffers related to infrastructure that takes a lot of wear and tear from motorists and costs an awful lot to keep in a state of good repair. Remember, the rebuilding of a small section of the Gardiner Expressway alone eats up $2 billion, or 38 per cent, of the city of Toronto's 2021-2030 capital budget for transportation. Can we complain about potholes with a plate rebate in our hands?
It's bold to cut this revenue while pushing through the quite-controversial expansion of Highway 413 into the Greenbelt as well as the Bradford Bypass, massive road building that will cost billions. The Ford government offered more treats when it announced it would cancel tolls on Highways 412 and 418. How will that revenue be replaced?
If you ride the TTC or another Ontario transit agency and watched the fares go up and up over the years, you might ask, where's my treat? If tolls are removed from the highway and plates, why can't the tolls on riding the bus, streetcar, or subway be removed?
The Ford government announced last week it would be eliminating "double fares" for riders on trips that connect from GO Transit to local transit services across the Greater Golden Horseshoe, but not including the TTC. It's a very conspicuous omission from a government that has often treated Toronto conspicuously different than it treats other municipalities.
On the face of it, this is a good start in erasing some of the arbitrary borders across our region.
While everyone in the Golden Horseshoe lives in distinct places that are self-governed, when it comes to transportation, we're all one metropolis, living, working and going to school across those borders, part of the same social and economic area. Transportation should be fluid. If you're in a car, save for the welcome sign at the city limits, you barely notice when you cross from one municipality to another. On transit, though, you're much more likely to notice because another fare is required.
Many transit systems around the world have zoned fares. The London Underground is one such system, with six zones that radiate from the city centre in concentric rings. Travelling within the dense first or second zone is a base fare. The more zones travelled, the higher the fare. GO transit works like this across the region. Fare pricing everywhere depends on how much the ride is subsidized, though.
Like the breaks for drivers and highway users, eliminating the second fare on local transit will cost something. The province will have to subsidize the fare for the local transit agencies. All fine, and how it works around the world, but this kind thing gets buried in populist announcements, especially when the head of that populist government, Doug Ford, is fond of saying there is only one taxpayer.
Somebody will have to pay for all the transit rides, the untolled highways, and the lack of revenue from plate renewal will have to be made up somewhere or result in cuts. An agency like the TTC has some of the lowest fare subsidies in North America, and increasing these local transit subsidies could be a good thing, but we need to be more honest about who's getting subsidized, and who isn't.
If somebody knocks on your door asking for your vote while bearing treats this spring, ask them how the treats are going to be paid for. It's important to also remember that the previous Liberal government had implemented a $1.50 discount program for riders transferring between the TTC and Metrolinx-operated transit like GO or the UP Express. The Ford government let that expire but, lo, come election year this kind of thing is a good idea after all.
The Toronto Region Board of Trade issued a statement Wednesday saying dropping double fares was a significant step toward an integrated, regionwide transit system, but that excluding the TTC was a mistake and will have economic consequences. "We are in a once-in-a-generation race for talent," said board CEO Jan De Silva in the statement. "Waiting to integrate fares for Toronto locks out talent, especially lower-income earners."
The board has been a long-time advocate for fare integration and a critic of how fragmented the regional transportation system is. Its 2020 report called "Erasing the Invisible Line: Integrating the Toronto Region's Transit Networks" decried "punitive double fares and poorly co-ordinated routes" that made for longer rides and unnecessary crowding.
Despite all the lines on the map, we're all part of one giant megalopolis, criss-crossing it for all kinds of reasons. Making it easy for everyone to do that shouldn't be so political.
Twitter: @shawnmicallef
CAPTION: Premier Doug Ford announced last week that Ontario will drop the "double fare" for riders transferring from local services to GO Transit, though the deal doesn't include the TTC.Toronto Star File Photo

'One lockdown too many': Ontario's election will be a messy affair, and leaders must embrace the uncertainty

Publication info: Mar 6, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/one-lockdown-too-many-ontarios-election-will-be/docview/2636118305/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=%27One+lockdown+too+many%27%3A+Ontario%27s+election+will+be+a+messy+affair%2C+and+leaders+must+embrace+the+uncertainty&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: It was only four years ago today that Ontario Progressive Conservative organizers, staff and candidates were consumed by an all-out sprint to elect a new leader — while managing the predictable party infighting, desperate as they were to present a viable alternative to the Wynne Liberals.
Back in 2018, perfectly naturally, many assumed that this would be the strangest, most unpredictable election of Doug Ford’s career. But they would turn out to be wrong.
Now, less than three months away from Ontario’s 43rd provincial election, Premier Ford and his challengers share one common predicament: uncertainty.
The chronic resurgence and retreat of COVID-19, combined with a convergence of social, economic and political changes, have contributed to an incredibly volatile opinion environment in which it’s difficult to measure even the immediate priorities of the electorate, let alone forecast where they are headed.
There is a sense that Ontarians have had “one lockdown too many,” as a Toronto resident put it to me. As public health restrictions are gradually phased out, I am increasingly optimistic that this election will be about much more than managing the pandemic, focused instead on charting a better path forward for Ontario.
Of course, politics is a game of managing expectations. Just as the Trudeau Liberals campaigned on an expansion of temporary pandemic relief programs and an articulation of longer-term priorities last year, the Ford government will have to balance competing pressures.
Key to their success will be outlining a coherent vision that feels relevant and forward-looking, while at the same time anticipating the probability that Omicron is neither the last nor the worst variant we will face. To put it more simply, they need to get on with the great pursuits of government.
Presently, leaders of all major political parties appear to be in a state of paralysis, keeping their cards close until closer to the writ period. For example, earlier this week the Ford government quietly passed legislation that will delay the spring budget without penalty, a move that’s transparently motivated by a desire for a pre-writ, election-friendly budget document.
While Liberal and NDP leaders have criticized the move, neither have taken it as an invitation to fill the void with their own platforms.
In this instance, timidity will do far more harm than audacity. Rather than waiting to communicate a perfect post-pandemic road map, parties should embrace the uncertainty, resist ideological orthodoxies and demonstrate their willingness to evolve as circumstances change at breakneck speed. It will be messy, and Ontario voters will get a meaningful look at the capabilities of their political leaders.
Being adaptive does not mean being unprincipled. Rather, one of the core tenets of strong political leadership is presenting a value set that is resilient to changing circumstances. To that end, Premier Ford can return to his roots as a champion for affordability — a positioning that was central to his 2018 win.
If it worked well in peacetime, it may prove even more relevant after the economic fallout of COVID-19. Or in the face of an unjust war with massive repercussions for logistics, deliveries and consumer prices. For voters with no elasticity in their budget, these are not abstract problems.
Recent commitments to cancel toll roads and scrap licence plate renewal fees have been right on the mark, but Premier Ford’s more persistent affordability challenge will be rising gas prices. While largely out of his control, this challenge has added pressure around his government’s unmet promise to lower prices by 10 cents a litre.
Issues of this scale and complexity are challenging to address publicly during the best of times, let alone when accompanied by the disorder of an election campaign. However, there is no question that Ford’s re-election prospects will be shaped by his ability to rise to the challenge.
Whether additional variants or international developments throw new hurdles in those plans is anybody’s guess. What’s certain is that the peculiarities of our 43rd provincial election are only getting started.
Jaime Watt is the executive chairman of Navigator Ltd. and a Conservative strategist. He is a freelance contributing columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @jaimewatt

CAPTION: Ontario Premier Doug Ford is seen in a mask that reads "open for business." Just as the Trudeau Liberals campaigned on an expansion of temporary pandemic relief programs and an articulation of longer-term priorities last year, Jaime Watt writes, the Ford government will have to balance competing pressures.
CREDIT: Jaime Watt;

Two cheers for women

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 07 Mar 2022: A.13.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/two-cheers-women/docview/2636276480/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Two+cheers+for+women&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-07&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.13&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: On Tuesday, we celebrate International Women's Day. Let joy be unconfined, etc.
But admit it, it's difficult in one of the most fraught years in the planet's history to see advancements in women's rights. We're in the shadows. It's a twist on what women are told whenever they ask for a raise: "Now is not the time."
It seems now is not the time for women to close the wage gap, for femicide to decrease, for abusive men to be exiled from the home rather than the women and children they torment, for women to prosper at work while raising children, to retain access to abortion, or even to feel easy about using the word "woman."
No, we have been called "menstruators" and even "chest-feeders" and "pregnant people." When so many of us never did or no longer do menstruate, breastfeed or give birth, we do not exist, I suppose.
This last one is a minor fringe issue, already fading. The others will not fade. Money rules all. Access to money is at the heart of women's advancement, and it's not going well.
As Armine Yalnizyan wrote in the Star in Sept. 2021, "Canada-wide, just 56.7 per cent of the population of women aged 15 and over have paid work, levels last seen in 2002." That was 20 long years ago. Although Quebec and B.C. have recovered to 2016 levels, Ontario is in the backwoods of 1999.
I hope those numbers have gone up as we slowly reopen. Retail jobs sustained so many women. As you walk down the street, look around you. Do you see an open store and if so, is it well-staffed? Should you bother? This is not an anecdote, but a national problem. It's unclear if retailers understand their own shrinkage or the appeal of Amazon.
As our population ages, employment changes. As Yalnizyan put it in another column, do jobs deserve that old "devotion?" Unless caregivers, usually women, are paid fairly with steady, safe work and good benefits, our current crisis will widen again.
Women are seeking to enter new fields in large numbers, including medicine, surgery, trades, law, architecture, possibly policing and the highest reaches of politics. It was a sorrow to see Ontario Health Minister Christine Elliott announce her departure from politics. She was the only competent member of Premier Doug Ford's cabinet, and he has always taken care to have no plausible successor in place.
On the other hand, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, a feminist, has always advanced the cause of women. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland has been called "Minister of Everything," having served as minister of international trade, foreign affairs and intergovernmental affairs - and (still) as deputy prime minister.
And she has been strikingly competent in every portfolio, thanks to her intelligence, breadth of knowledge, human understanding and patience. The quality we most need in politicians right now is unflappability, a radiating confidence that problems can indeed be solved.
I see fatigue, rage and panic among citizens. Trudeau has been a calming figure offering careful confidence.
He hasn't been afraid to hand over to Freeland to let her do her finance job, but also to comment publicly on a devastated country she knows well: Ukraine.
Politicians are rarely so generous about the local competition. U.S. President Joe Biden hasn't allowed Vice-President Kamala Harris to range widely, to allow Americans to get to know her. At his age with poor prospects for re-election, the Democrats - and the planet - may pay heavily for this.
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson won't leave, partly because he knows voters can see his cabinet is packed with no-hopers. That's his plan. It's not a great one for Britain. He's rather Putin-like that way.
Things to cheer about: abortion pills are becoming more commonly used, the concept of "femicide" as a particular kind of killing is slowly being recognized, #MeToo has finished off many old beasts, and then there's this last crucial fact: women don't give up. We never have. We never will.
Happy International Women's Day, and may we see many more.
Heather Mallick is a Toronto-based columnist covering
current affairs for the Star. Follow her on Twitter:
@HeatherMallick
CAPTION: Ministers Chrystia Freeland, left, and Anita Anand arrive to hold a press conference last Thursday. Women don't give up. We never have. We never will, Heather Mallick writes.Sean KilpatrickTHE CANADIAN PRESS

Full text: Russia not alone when it comes to foreign invasion
An affront to decency,
Editorial, Feb. 25
The Russian invasion of Ukraine is rightly drawing a lot of condemnation, but some of the statements from our leaders appear to be hypocritical.
As an example, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau stated that "Putin has chosen to upend 75 years of peace by invading."
I think this is a little rich. After all, we all remember the invasion of Iraq, when we turned the country upside down as we had (bogus) intelligence that it possessed weapons of mass destruction.
Afghanistan is another country that has been invaded many times - first by Russians, then by NATO.
Palestinian lands continue to be occupied even today.
All this occupation took place during the past 75 years.
The list is not limited to this of course. It includes Vietnam and Yemen and many other countries.
Although we should do what we can to minimize the sufferings of Ukraine, let's not trivialize the sufferings of those who have endured a similar fate.
After all, the devastation caused by a U.S. bomb is equally reprehensible as the one caused by a Russian bomb.
Mubashir Rizvi, Pickering
Russians must
be aware this war is not patriotic
Russian troops close in on Kyiv, Feb. 26
I was born four months after the start of the Second World War in Europe, and now a war has just started one month after my 82nd birthday in the same area of Europe, caused by the same kind of meddling maniac.
In 2022, there must be a better way to remove a meddling maniac than fighting him for years and enduring millions of deaths. We are going after his money, but maybe we should be making sure that the Russian people know this is not a great patriotic war. This war is against Putin's made-up enemy, who are not neo-Nazis; they are just fellow Slavs trying to live in peace.
Keith Parkinson,
Cambridge, Ont.
Hungarian refugee's son remembers
In Hungary in the 1950s, my father, John, lived a life of challenges. Never had he experienced freedom, as Magyar Land was oppressed by the Soviets.
Then came the Hungarian Revolution in 1956, and a call to all young people to stand up and be counted for their motherland. John stood up and took on this challenge. Many of his comrades and neighbours fell to Russian bullets. My father was wounded and left for dead, but rose to fight again.
The Soviet-Russian juggernaut had won the day, but only by fleeing could my father and his wife survive.
Thank you, Canada, for your friendship, opportunities and promise.
Steven Kaszab, Bradford, Ont.
Ford is taking
all Ontarians
for suckers
So Premier Doug Ford has decided to scrap the very restrictions that have helped save thousands of lives over the past two years.
This premature plan to allow a full reopening of businesses with no need to show vaccination certificates will put lives in danger for the workers and for their customers. Health-care workers cannot catch their breath before the fallout from Ford's decision hits them hard yet again.
Now that an election is coming up, he is resorting to the old trick of bribing the voters with their own money.
P.T. Barnum famously said, "There's a sucker born every minute." In Doug Ford, we have our very own circus ringmaster.
Richard Murri,
Niagara Falls

Doug Ford is taking all Ontarians for suckers

Publication info: Mar 6, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/doug-ford-is-taking-all-ontarians-suckers/docview/2635971637/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Doug+Ford+is+taking+all+Ontarians+for+suckers&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: So Premier Doug Ford has decided to scrap the very restrictions that have helped save thousands of lives over the past two years. This Ontario government has always made poor decisions because it had its eye on the next election rather than its sworn duty to do what was right for the people of Ontario.
This premature plan to allow a full reopening of businesses with no need to show vaccination certificates will put lives in danger for the workers and for their customers.
The workers in our health-care system cannot catch their breath, with the current lower numbers, before the fallout from Ford’s decision hits them hard yet again.
Now that an election is coming up, he is resorting to the old trick of bribing the voters with their own money. Promising to build highways in areas where he needs to increase support for Conservative candidates, giving up a billion dollars in driver’s licence fees with no plan in the works on how to replace that lost revenue.
American circus owner P.T. Barnum famously said, “There’s a sucker born every minute.” In Doug Ford, we have our very own circus ringmaster. Let’s not be suckers again.
Richard Murri , Niagara Falls, Ont.

Review of usage of Emergencies Act could take months

Full text: It could be months before a review committee delivers its findings on the federal government's unprecedented use of the Emergencies Act, one of its co-chairs said Friday.

Embracing uncertainty

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 06 Mar 2022: IN.7.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/embracing-uncertainty/docview/2635965855/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Embracing+uncertainty&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-06&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=IN.7&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: It was only four years ago today that Ontario Progressive Conservative organizers, staff and candidates were consumed by an all-out sprint to elect a new leader - while managing the predictable party infighting, desperate as they were to present a viable alternative to the Wynne Liberals.
Back in 2018, perfectly naturally, many assumed that this would be the strangest, most unpredictable election of Doug Ford's career. But they would turn out to be wrong.
Now, less than three months away from Ontario's 43rd provincial election, Premier Ford and his challengers share one common predicament: uncertainty.
The chronic resurgence and retreat of COVID-19, combined with a convergence of social, economic and political changes, have contributed to an incredibly volatile opinion environment in which it's difficult to measure even the immediate priorities of the electorate, let alone forecast where they are headed.
There is a sense that Ontarians have had "one lockdown too many," as a Toronto resident put it to me. As public health restrictions are gradually phased out, I am increasingly optimistic that this election will be about much more than managing the pandemic, focused instead on charting a better path forward for Ontario.
Of course, politics is a game of managing expectations. Just as the Trudeau Liberals campaigned on an expansion of temporary pandemic relief programs and an articulation of longer-term priorities last year, the Ford government will have to balance competing pressures.
Key to their success will be outlining a coherent vision that feels relevant and forward-looking, while at the same time anticipating the probability that Omicron is neither the last nor the worst variant we will face. To put it more simply, they need to get on with the great pursuits of government.
Presently, leaders of all major political parties appear to be in a state of paralysis, keeping their cards close until closer to the writ period. For example, earlier this week the Ford government quietly passed legislation that will delay the spring budget without penalty, a move that's transparently motivated by a desire for a pre-writ, election-friendly budget document.
While Liberal and NDP leaders have criticized the move, neither have taken it as an invitation to fill the void with their own platforms.
In this instance, timidity will do far more harm than audacity. Rather than waiting to communicate a perfect post-pandemic road map, parties should embrace the uncertainty, resist ideological orthodoxies and demonstrate their willingness to evolve as circumstances change at breakneck speed. It will be messy, and Ontario voters will get a meaningful look at the capabilities of their political leaders.
Being adaptive does not mean being unprincipled. Rather, one of the core tenets of strong political leadership is presenting a value set that is resilient to changing circumstances. To that end, Premier Ford can return to his roots as a champion for affordability - a positioning that was central to his 2018 win.
If it worked well in peacetime, it may prove even more relevant after the economic fallout of COVID-19. Or in the face of an unjust war with massive repercussions for logistics, deliveries and consumer prices. For voters with no elasticity in their budget, these are not abstract problems.
Recent commitments to cancel toll roads and scrap licence plate renewal fees have been right on the mark, but Premier Ford's more persistent affordability challenge will be rising gas prices. While largely out of his control, this challenge has added pressure around his government's unmet promise to lower prices by 10 cents a litre.
Issues of this scale and complexity are challenging to address publicly during the best of times, let alone when accompanied by the disorder of an election campaign. However, there is no question that Ford's re-election prospects will be shaped by his ability to rise to the challenge.
Whether additional variants or international developments throw new hurdles in those plans is anybody's guess. What's certain is that the peculiarities of our 43rd provincial election are only getting started.
Jaime Watt is the executive chairman of Navigator Ltd. and a Conservative strategist. He is a freelance contributing columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @jaimewatt

Martin Regg Cohn: Without Christine Elliott, will Doug Ford revert to form?

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/martin-regg-cohn-without-christine-elliott-will/docview/2635889009/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Martin+Regg+Cohn%3A+Without+Christine+Elliott%2C+will+Doug+Ford+revert+to+form%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Four years ago, Christine Elliott ran to be leader of Ontario’s Progressive Conservatives.
Now, the province’s powerful deputy premier is walking away from it all.
She’s not alone.
Elliott is the 18th MPP elected alongside Doug Ford in the 2018 “change” election to now change their mind in the aftermath. That’s an exodus amounting to almost one-quarter of the 76 MPPs described by Ford as his “all-star” team — though some stars dimmed, fell into disrepute, were dumped from cabinet or devolved into anti-vax dissidents.
Never before have so many politicians opted to get out when the going was so good for the governing party. As polarizing as the premier is, he’s still sitting pretty in public opinion polls — with 39 per cent support, far ahead of the opposition Liberals and NDP tied at 27 per cent each, according to the latest Leger survey.
Which is what makes so many of these departures so novel.
Elliott is quitting not for fear of defeat, she is resigning to avoid winning re-election. She dreamed of power four years ago, but now realizes you’d best be careful what you wish for — lest you win four more years with Ford.
Rod Phillips, who worked closely with Elliott on pandemic management, made a similar calculation when he quit suddenly in January. Phillips had his ups and downs — he lost the finance portfolio after taking a Caribbean vacation mid-pandemic — but he was brought back into cabinet to clean up the mess in long-term care.
Both were known for their quiet expertise. Now they are both quietly exiting.
Their departures speak volumes about what they put up with over the last four years, and what the province might face without them over the next four.
Phillips and Elliott were the main guardrails keeping Ford in his lane and on course, lest he go over a cliff. They could speak truth to power even when he wasn’t always of a mind to listen.
“From the day she became my deputy, we’ve never had a disagreement,” Ford mused Friday at a joint appearance with Elliott.
In fact, Elliott criticized him severely when they were rival leadership candidates, but the premier always gave her a hearing when they worked together in government. That’s because everyone understood that she was the one minister he could never fire from cabinet — too popular, too much profile, too much pandemic.
Now, she has fired her boss.
Leadership aspirants like her only bide their time until their time is up. Elliott first ran for the PC leadership in 2009 (losing to Tim Hudak), tried a second time in 2015 (beaten by Patrick Brown), and then quit her seat in a funk.
She made a third leadership bid in 2018, losing narrowly to Ford but not before promising to come back as an MPP win or lose. Elliott kept her word, but the writing was on the wall.
In her own mind, she was the deputy premier who should have been premier. Serving as deputy was not what she signed up for, and so she resigned one last time on Friday.
After all, Elliott is not about to try a fourth time for the top job. And Phillips had too much baggage from his past travels to continue his forward journey in politics.
They will be missed. Amid Ford’s flamboyance, Elliott and Phillips were the competent grown-ups in the cabinet room, even if they weren’t always centre stage during COVID-19.
Ford tended to hold the microphone, handing it off mostly to the medical officer of health. But behind the scenes, the ministerial tag team of Elliott and Phillips oversaw the hospitals and long-term facilities that are the backbone of the system, while also backstopping the bureaucracy.
On their watch, Ontario mostly weathered the pandemic storm. For all the media alarmism and epidemiological partisanship of the past two years, the province consistently delivered the most cautious COVID-19 restrictions on the continent, among the best vaccine distribution networks (notably boosters for younger adults), and the best outcomes, all things considered.
Without them in cabinet, Ford will be more out of balance — less ballast and more bluster.
Without COVID-19 in his sights, he may be more out of step — less mission-focused and more mischief-making.
The pandemic served as an additional guardrail, keeping Ford’s eyes — and mouth — on the road ahead. He softened his rough edges, dialed down his puerile populist rhetoric, and acted more like a grown-up in government.
Without the enforced discipline from COVID-19 and his cabinet lieutenants, will the premier revert to form , embracing his past penchant for baubles and bombast in the coming campaign — and beyond? Elliott and Phillips weren’t willing to wait to find out — a telltale clue for the rest of us.
Martin Regg Cohn is a Toronto-based columnist focusing on Ontario politics and international affairs for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @reggcohn

The Emergencies Act was only used for days. Finding out how will take months

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/emergencies-act-was-only-used-days-finding-out/docview/2635885559/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=The+Emergencies+Act+was+only+used+for+days.+Finding+out+how+will+take+months&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: It could be months before a review committee delivers its findings on the federal government’s unprecedented use of the Emergencies Act, one of its co-chairs said Friday.
“There isn’t a scenario where we can get to the bottom of this within a week,” NDP MP Matthew Green said in an interview. “I would anticipate this would run well into the summer.
“There ought not be a haste or a rush to get through this process for the sake of getting through it. We have to move through this process deliberately and cautiously.”
The federal government used the Emergencies Act for the first time on Feb. 14 to deal with the so-called Freedom Convoy occupation in Ottawa and blockades at border crossings. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau revoked the declaration of emergency on Feb. 23.
The task of reviewing how those powers were exercised now falls to a joint House-Senate committee created this week , as required by the act. And although the act states that the committee must submit its report to Parliament within seven sitting days after the declaration is revoked, Green said, “it is a report. It doesn’t necessarily, as I understand it, have to be the report.”
He said that first report will likely be largely administrative and lay out the processes that the committee will be following in its study.
Green’s co-chair, Bloc Québécois MP Rhéal Fortin, concurred. “We have no choice,” Fortin said. “The committee has just been formed ... Maybe there will be a preliminary report, but it’s clear we won’t have enough time to do it all.”
The NDP voted with the government to confirm the invocation of the Emergencies Act last month, while the Bloc opposed it along with the Conservatives.
Despite the act’s seven-day deadline, there are exceptional circumstances at play. The act’s architect, Perrin Beatty, told the Star that it was envisioned that emergencies would be fairly lengthy. He said the idea was that the committee would be created as soon as Parliament confirmed the declaration of emergency, to provide real-time oversight as well as scrutiny after the fact.
In this case, the declaration of emergency was in place for a little over a week, having been confirmed by the House of Commons , but was revoked even before it could be confirmed by the Senate.
“I’m not sure a great deal of thought was given to what happens if the situation on the ground has improved so dramatically before Parliament even gets to vote on the invocation of the act itself,” said Beatty, who introduced the act in 1987 as defence minister in Brian Mulroney’s Progressive Conservative government.
The act refers to holding some hearings behind closed doors in certain circumstances, but Green committed to making the committee’s work as public as possible. He also said it was his understanding that members will be given the required clearance to review security information.
Fortin said he’d like to see Trudeau and the ministers of public safety and justice testify, along with chiefs of police, adding he believes other opposition parties would push for the same.
“In my mind, it’s inevitable” that Trudeau would be called, Fortin said in an interview. “I think that accounts of cabinet meetings, testimonies from the ministers and the prime minister, those seem to be essentials to me.”
Green and Fortin will co-chair the committee with Sen. Gwen Boniface from the Independent Senators Group, who was unavailable for an interview Friday.
Also on the committee from the House will be Liberal MPs Yasir Naqvi, Rachel Bendayan and Arif Virani, and Conservatives Larry Brock and Glen Motz. And the other Senate members will be Claude Carignan from the Conservatives, Peter Harder from the Progressive Senate Group, and Vernon White from the Canadian Senators Group.
The government’s motion creating the committee passed the House of Commons on Wednesday with NDP and Bloc support, and was confirmed by the Senate. The government argued that neither the Liberals nor the Conservatives should co-chair, given the former invoked the Emergencies Act and the latter expressed support for the protests that led to its invocation.
The Tories rejected the proposal, saying that traditionally, oversight committees are chaired by the Official Opposition.
The bickering over the committee’s structure has led experts to question how useful the committee will be. Green said he will be meeting with committee members and staff in the coming days to ensure the review doesn’t “devolve into a hyperpartisan circus.”
Jacques Gallant is a Toronto-based reporter covering politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @JacquesGallant

Former GTA MP Leona Alleslev preparing to enter Tory leadership race

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/former-gta-mp-leona-alleslev-preparing-enter-tory/docview/2635888190/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Former+GTA+MP+Leona+Alleslev+preparing+to+enter+Tory+leadership+race&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA—A two-week break for the House of Commons that began Friday is setting the stage for an uptick in action in the federal Conservative leadership race.
Former MP Leona Alleslev is now adding her name to the list of candidates eyeing a run, while the one official candidate so far has nabbed a major endorsement and several other campaigns are gearing up to formally launch bids.
Alleslev was defeated in the last federal election in the GTA riding of Aurora-Oak Ridges-Richmond Hill, a loss that contributed to concerns that former leader Erin O’Toole could not lead the party to victory if he couldn’t help win ridings like hers.
Now Alleslev is heeding calls to seek the leadership that followed O’Toole’s departure in February and is gathering a team, money and the signatures needed to enter the race, the Star has learned.
“If I had to lay odds, I would say she’s going to get in,” said one party insider familiar with Alleslev’s efforts.
“I do know she has a vision for a modern, inclusive country and a Conservative party with broad appeal that she is eager to articulate.”
Alleslev did not return a request for comment from the Star.
Alleslev was first elected as a Liberal in 2015, but crossed the floor to the Conservatives in 2018, citing dissatisfaction with the Liberals on a number of files, including the economy and military spending. She’s a former captain in the Air Force.
She’d go on to become Conservative deputy leader under Andrew Scheer, but stepped down to join Peter MacKay’s campaign during the 2020 leadership contest. She then lost her seat to Liberal Leah Taylor Roy in the September 2021 election.
Candidates for the Conservative leadership race have to pay a $200,00 entry fee, plus a $100,000 refundable deposit.
They have until April 19 to apply to enter, and a new leader will be elected by Sept. 10.
So far, there’s only one official contestant, longtime MP Pierre Poilievre.
He’s on a campaign tour in Saskatchewan and is expected to receive Scheer’s endorsement at a Friday rally.
Though Scheer quit as leader under a cloud of controversy in 2020, he retains a position of prominence inside caucus and the party, and his imprimatur will carry weight.
Poilievre will also be travelling in Quebec, Ontario and Western Canada in the coming days.
Former Quebec premier and one-time federal Progressive Conservative party leader Jean Charest is also expected to make his candidacy official in the coming days.
MP and former leadership candidate Leslyn Lewis is expected to launch next week, and two-time MP Scott Aitchison, Ontario MPP Roman Baber and conservative strategist Tasha Kheiriddin are also mulling bids.
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

Shawn Micallef: Doug Ford has doled out election treats to drivers and some transit riders. But guess who's getting taken for a ride?

Publication info: Mar 5, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/shawn-micallef-doug-ford-has-doled-out-election/docview/2635874842/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Shawn+Micallef%3A+Doug+Ford+has+doled+out+election+treats+to+drivers+and+some+transit+riders.+But+guess+who%27s+getting+taken+for+a+ride%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Getting around the city can be a political act.
It’s election season, so getting around is even more political than usual, with commuters of all kinds being wooed with treats. Some commuters more than others, that is.
Last month the Ford government announced licence plate renewal fees are being scrapped. That’s an awful lot of money out of the provincial coffers related to infrastructure that takes a lot of wear and tear from motorists and costs an awful lot to keep in a state of good repair. Remember, the rebuilding of a small section of the Gardiner Expressway alone eats up $2 billion, or 38 per cent, of the city of Toronto’s 2021-2030 capital budget for transportation . Can we complain about potholes with a plate rebate in our hands?
It’s bold to cut this revenue while pushing through the quite-controversial expansion of Highway 413 into the Greenbelt as well as the Bradford Bypass, massive road building that will cost billions. The Ford government offered more treats when it announced it would cancel tolls on Highways 412 and 418. How will that revenue be replaced?
If you ride the TTC or another Ontario transit agency and watched the fares go up and up over the years, you might ask, where’s my treat? If tolls are removed from the highway and plates, why can’t the tolls on riding the bus, streetcar, or subway be removed?
This week the Ford government announced it would be eliminating “double fares” for riders on trips that connect from GO Transit to local transit services across the Greater Golden Horseshoe, but not including the TTC. It’s a very conspicuous omission from a government that has often treated Toronto conspicuously different t han it treats other municipalities .
On the face of it, this is a good start in erasing some of the arbitrary borders across our region. While everyone in the Golden Horseshoe lives in distinct places that are self-governed, when it comes to transportation, we’re all one metropolis, living, working and going to school across those borders, part of the same social and economic area. Transportation should be fluid. If you’re in a car, save for the welcome sign at the city limits, you barely notice when you cross from one municipality to another. On transit, though, you’re much more likely to notice because another fare is required.
Many transit systems around the world have zoned fares. The London Underground is one such system, with six zones that radiate from the city centre in concentric rings. Travelling within the dense first or second zone is a base fare. The more zones travelled, the higher the fare. GO transit works like this across the region. Fare pricing everywhere depends on how much the ride is subsidized, though.
Like the breaks for drivers and highway users, eliminating the second fare on local transit will cost something. The province will have to subsidize the fare for the local transit agencies. All fine, and how it works around the world, but this kind of thing gets buried in populist announcements, especially when the head of that populist government, Doug Ford, is fond of saying there is only one taxpayer.
Somebody will have to pay for all the transit rides, the untolled highways, and the lack of revenue from plate renewal will have to be made up somewhere or result in cuts. An agency like the TTC has some of the lowest fare subsidies in North America, and increasing these local transit subsidies could be a good thing, but we need to be more honest about who’s getting subsidized, and who isn’t.
If somebody knocks on your door asking for your vote while bearing treats this spring, ask them how the treats are going to be paid for. It’s important to also remember that the previous Liberal government had implemented a $1.50 discount program for riders transferring between the TTC and Metrolinx-operated transit like GO or the UP Express. The Ford government let that expire but, lo, come election year this kind of thing is a good idea after all.
The Toronto Region Board of Trade issued a statement Wednesday saying dropping double fares was a significant step towards an integrated, region-wide transit system, but that excluding the TTC was a mistake and will have economic consequences. “We are in a once-in-a-generation race for talent,” said board CEO Jan De Silva in the statement. “Waiting to integrate fares for Toronto locks out talent, especially lower-income earners.”
The board has been a long-time advocate for fare integration and a critic of how fragmented the regional transportation system is. Its 2020 report called “Erasing the Invisible Line: Integrating the Toronto Region’s Transit Networks” decried “punitive double fares and poorly coordinated routes” that made for longer rides and unnecessary crowding.
Despite all the lines on the map, we’re all part of one giant megalopolis, criss-crossing it for all kinds of reasons. Making it easy for everyone to do that shouldn’t be so political.
Shawn Micallef is a Toronto-based writer and a freelance contributing columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @shawnmicallef

MPP Elliott won't seek re-election in June: Health minister will continue to shepherd Ontario through pandemic until late spring vote

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 05 Mar 2022: A.3.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mpp-elliott-wont-seek-re-election-june-health/docview/2635823317/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=MPP+Elliott+won%27t+seek+re-election+in+June%3A+Health+minister+will+continue+to+shepherd+Ontario+through+pandemic+until+late+spring+vote%3A+Health+minister+will+continue+to+shepherd+Ontario+through+pandemic+until+late+spring+vote&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Premier Doug Ford is losing a key player as Health Minister Christine Elliott - also his deputy premier - says she won't run in the June 2 provincial election.
Elliott confirmed her pending retirement Friday following news reports on her decision.
"Between now and this spring, Premier Ford has asked me to continue to support our government as minister of health and I have agreed without hesitation," she said, calling her 13 years as an MPP "a great honour, a great responsibility."
Elliott, 66, is a lawyer by training. She has been in charge of the high-profile health portfolio throughout the pandemic, a role that attracted protesters to her home, sometimes into the early morning hours.
"After two-plus years of COVID, she deserves to have her life back," one source told the Star.
During a stop at Sunnybrook hospital with Elliott on Friday, Ford paid tribute to her for shepherding the Health Ministry through a critical time.
"I'm very grateful that Christine's going to stay on until the election and help us go through this pandemic, as we're coming out of it slowly," he said.
Elliott ran three times for the leadership of the Progressive Conservatives, losing close contests to Patrick Brown in 2015 and Ford in 2018. She also ran in 2009 against Tim Hudak.
The veteran MPP was first elected in Whitby-Oshawa in 2006. She took three years off from electoral politics after her 2015 leadership defeat and served as Ontario's first patient ombudsman, a $220,000-a-year role to which she was appointed by former Liberal premier Kathleen Wynne. Elliott had been her party's outspoken health critic.
She took a pay cut when she quit that job, unsuccessfully sought the leadership and subsequently won re-election to the legislature in Newmarket-Aurora four years ago.
Elliott is the second high-profile minister to announce a retirement from politics this year.
Businessman and former finance and environment minister Rod Phillips resigned the long-term-care portfolio last month to return to private life.
The PCs quickly announced Dawn Gallagher Murphy, a consultant who has been Elliott's community office manager in Newmarket-Aurora, will be the party's candidate in the riding.
Elliott is among 18 PCs elected in Ford's 2018 sweep of the previous Liberal government who are not running again under the party banner because they are in other parties, sitting as independents, refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19 or are leaving politics.
They include Independent MPP Randy Hillier (Lanark-Frontenac-Kingston), an outspoken opponent of public health measures to fight COVID-19, who said Thursday night he will not seek re-election. Hillier has been censured unanimously in the legislature twice recently for discreditable conduct.
CREDIT: Rob Ferguson Queen's Park Bureau

Former GTA MP prepares to enter Tory leadership race

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 05 Mar 2022: A.6.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/former-gta-mp-prepares-enter-tory-leadership-race/docview/2635819232/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Former+GTA+MP+prepares+to+enter+Tory+leadership+race&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A two-week break for the House of Commons that began Friday is setting the stage for an uptick in action in the federal Conservative leadership race.
Former MP Leona Alleslev is now adding her name to the list of candidates eyeing a run, while the one official candidate so far has nabbed a major endorsement and several other campaigns are gearing up to formally launch bids.
Alleslev was defeated in the last federal election in the GTA riding of Aurora-Oak Ridges-Richmond Hill, a loss that contributed to concerns that former leader Erin O'Toole could not lead the party to victory if he couldn't help win ridings like hers.
Now Alleslev is heeding calls to seek the leadership that followed O'Toole's departure in February and is gathering a team, money and the signatures needed to enter the race, the Star has learned.
"If I had to lay odds, I would say she's going to get in," said one party insider familiar with Alleslev's efforts. "I do know she has a vision for a modern, inclusive country and a Conservative party with broad appeal that she is eager to articulate."
Alleslev did not return a request for comment from the Star.
Alleslev was first elected as a Liberal in 2015, but crossed the floor to the Conservatives in 2018, citing dissatisfaction with the Liberals on a number of files. She's a former captain in the Air Force.
She'd go on to become Conservative deputy leader under Andrew Scheer, but stepped down to join Peter MacKay's campaign during the 2020 leadership contest. She then lost her seat to Liberal Leah Taylor Roy in last September's election.
Candidates for the Conservative leadership race have to pay a $200,00 entry fee, plus a $100,000 refundable deposit. They have until April 19 to apply to enter, and a new leader will be elected by Sept. 10.
So far, there's only one official contestant, longtime MP Pierre Poilievre. He's on a campaign tour in Saskatchewan and is expected to receive Scheer's endorsement at a Friday rally.
Though Scheer quit as leader under a cloud of controversy in 2020, he retains a position of prominence inside caucus and the party, and his imprimatur will carry weight.
Poilievre will also be travelling in Quebec, Ontario and Western Canada in the coming days.
Former Quebec premier and one-time federal Progressive Conservative party leader Jean Charest is also expected to make his candidacy official in the coming days.
MP and former leadership candidate Leslyn Lewis is expected to launch next week, and two-time MP Scott Aitchison, Ontario MPP Roman Baber and conservative strategist Tasha Kheiriddin are also mulling bids.
CAPTION: Leona Alleslev was first elected as a Liberal in 2015, but crossed the floor to the Conservatives in 2018.

Doug Ford didn't follow through on penalties for Ottawa protesters, opposition charges

Publication info: Mar 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/doug-ford-didnt-follow-through-on-penalties/docview/2635710665/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Doug+Ford+didn%27t+follow+through+on+penalties+for+Ottawa+protesters%2C+opposition+charges&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ontario’s transportation minister insists the province is not letting truck drivers from the so-called Freedom Convoy protests “off the hook” amid criticisms that penalties have not gone far enough.
Caroline Mulroney said the provincial state of emergency declared by Premier Doug Ford allowed police to suspend the licences and tow vehicles for a week without any right to appeal, which “provided more certainty that would allow them to clear the occupation in short order.”
But New Democrat Leader Andrea Horwath and other opposition parties were not buying that rationale after Ford warned truckers who participated in the protest against COVID-19 measures could face fines of $100,000 and a year in prison for resisting efforts to clear them out.
“The occupiers are literally driving away in the very trucks they used to occupy Ottawa,” Horwath said Thursday following reports that 39 vehicles seized by police were returned to their owners.
“Residents find out now that the $100,000 penalties that this premier was blustering about were all for show, as usual ... he’s sending a pretty dangerous signal that the kind of lawlessness that took place will have no consequences.”
Solicitor General Sylvia Jones said Ottawa police have laid a range of mischief and other criminal charges against dozens in the “illegal occupation,” with some remaining in jail while they seek bail.
“Any suspensions processed remain on the vehicle record and could affect the renewal of licences in the future,” she added.
Liberal house leader John Fraser, the MPP for Ottawa South, faulted Ford for waiting two weeks into the occupation to declare an emergency.
“I’ve never felt so let down,” he told reporters, suggesting Ford’s Progressive Conservative MPPs in suburban Ottawa could face difficulty in the June 2 election because residents of the nation’s capital were so frustrated.
Fraser said a major concern is the sudden departure of three Ford government appointees to the Ottawa police services board after the provincial politics publication QP Briefing revealed one of them attended a protest rally.
“This raises more questions than it answers,” Fraser said, wondering aloud if any sensitive information on police strategy was provided to protest organizers or participants.
Jones said the three provincial appointees will be replaced in the next few days.
“Because the city of Ottawa has chosen to take a new direction with their police services board, we accepted the resignations of the three,” she said.
Ford said the province makes about 3,500 appointments a year and, while he signs off on them, he can’t “dig into” all of them.
Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1

Elliott kept Ford on course. Now what?

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 05 Mar 2022: A.4.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/elliott-kept-ford-on-course-now-what/docview/2635817251/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Elliott+kept+Ford+on+course.+Now+what%3F&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-05&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Four years ago, Christine Elliott ran to be leader of Ontario's Progressive Conservatives.
Now, the province's powerful deputy premier is walking away from it all.
She's not alone.
Elliott is the 18th MPP elected alongside Doug Ford in the 2018 "change" election to now change their mind in the aftermath. That's an exodus amounting to almost one-quarter of the 76 MPPs described by Ford as his "all-star" team - though some stars dimmed, fell into disrepute, were dumped from cabinet or devolved into anti-vax dissidents.
Never before have so many politicians opted to get out when the going was so good for the governing party. As polarizing as the premier is, he's still sitting pretty in public opinion polls - with 39 per cent support, far ahead of the opposition Liberals and NDP tied at 27 per cent each, according to the latest Léger survey.
Which is what makes so many of these departures so novel.
Elliott is quitting not for fear of defeat, she is resigning to avoid winning re-election. She dreamed of power four years ago, but now realizes you'd best be careful what you wish for - lest you win four more years with Ford.
Rod Phillips, who worked closely with Elliott on pandemic management, made a similar calculation when he quit suddenly in January. Phillips had his ups and downs - he lost the finance portfolio after taking a Caribbean vacation mid-pandemic - but he was brought back into cabinet to clean up the mess in long-term care.
Both were known for their quiet expertise. Now they are both quietly exiting.
Their departures speak volumes about what they put up with over the last four years, and what the province might face without them over the next four.
Phillips and Elliott were the main guardrails keeping Ford in his lane and on course, lest he go over a cliff. They could speak truth to power even when he wasn't always of a mind to listen.
"From the day she became my deputy, we've never had a disagreement," Ford mused Friday at a joint appearance with Elliott.
In fact, Elliott criticized him severely when they were rival leadership candidates, but the premier always gave her a hearing when they worked together in government. That's because everyone understood that she was the one minister he could never fire from cabinet - too popular, too much profile, too much pandemic.
Now, she has fired her boss.
Leadership aspirants like her only bide their time until their time is up. Elliott first ran for the PC leadership in 2009 (losing to Tim Hudak), tried a second time in 2015 (beaten by Patrick Brown), and then quit her seat in a funk.
She made a third leadership bid in 2018, losing narrowly to Ford but not before promising to come back as an MPP win or lose. Elliott kept her word, but the writing was on the wall.
In her own mind, she was the deputy premier who should have been premier. Serving as deputy was not what she signed up for, and so she resigned one last time on Friday.
After all, Elliott is not about to try a fourth time for the top job. And Phillips had too much baggage from his past travels to continue his forward journey in politics.
They will be missed. Amid Ford's flamboyance, Elliott and Phillips were the competent grown-ups in the cabinet room, even if they weren't always centre stage during COVID-19.
Ford tended to hold the microphone, handing it off mostly to the medical officer of health. But behind the scenes, the ministerial tag team of Elliott and Phillips oversaw the hospitals and long-term facilities that are the backbone of the system, while also backstopping the bureaucracy.
On their watch, Ontario mostly weathered the pandemic storm. For all the media alarmism and epidemiological partisanship of the past two years, the province consistently delivered the most cautious COVID-19 restrictions on the continent, among the best vaccine distribution networks (notably boosters for younger adults), and the best outcomes, all things considered.
Without them in cabinet, Ford will be more out of balance - less ballast and more bluster.
Without COVID-19 in his sights, he may be more out of step - less mission-focused and more mischief-making.
The pandemic served as an additional guardrail, keeping Ford's eyes - and mouth - on the road ahead. He softened his rough edges, dialed down his puerile populist rhetoric, and acted more like a grown-up in government.
Without the enforced discipline from COVID-19 and his cabinet lieutenants, will the premier revert to form, embracing his past penchant for baubles and bombast in the coming campaign - and beyond? Elliott and Phillips weren't willing to wait to find out - a telltale clue for the rest of us.
Twitter: @reggcohn

Martin Regg Cohn: Green Leader Mike Schreiner stands out among MPPs. So why does his party have a popularity problem?

Publication info: Mar 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/martin-regg-cohn-green-leader-mike-schreiner/docview/2635709450/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Martin+Regg+Cohn%3A+Green+Leader+Mike+Schreiner+stands+out+among+MPPs.+So+why+does+his+party+have+a+popularity+problem%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Mike Schreiner has an image problem.
Not him, his brand.
As leader of Ontario’s Green Party, he keeps outperforming his political rivals on the provincial stage. He is articulate and authentic, passionate and persuasive.
But that’s only half the story — his personal success story on the eve of an Ontario election campaign.
The other half is the hard part — the tough story of last September’s federal election.
That’s when Canada’s Greens self-destructed on the national campaign trail. The fallout was far and wide.
The fight against global warming was overshadowed by a civil war within a national party that couldn’t stop talking about war in the Middle East. Its high-profile leader, Annamie Paul , went down in a ball of flames and its voter support vanished.
In truth, Schreiner had nothing to do with that cross-country disaster. In fact, Ontario’s Green Party is a separate entity.
But in politics, perception counts. In reality, the Green movement is one big global brand with blurred boundaries.
Now, Schreiner must juggle brand management and damage control, while still trying to win over the province and save the planet. That means outshining the rival leaders of Ontario’s major parties, but also outrunning the ghosts of the Green Party of Canada.
Schreiner prefers to face the elephant in the room head on, rather than pretend no one sees it. At a recent Ryerson Democracy Forum that I hosted for Ontario’s three opposition party leaders, he heard a recurring audience question :
What happened to the federal Greens, and what does it mean for Ontario?
“I’m a straight shooter — there’s no doubt there was a lot of turmoil within the federal party over the last year,” Schreiner replied.
“But I want to be very clear with people: the Ontario Greens are a separate party with a different organizational culture and governance structure,” he stressed. “While the federal party was going through its turmoil, we set a record for the most fundraising we’ve ever, ever had in a year in our party’s history. We have more volunteers than we ever had, we have the largest staff.”
That’s the inescapable irony: Schreiner finds himself in an enviable position provincially despite the unenviable decline of his counterparts federally.
Today, 14 years after taking over the party, he has spearheaded breakthroughs that Greens had long waited for. Schreiner won the party’s first seat in Guelph in the last election, and the party has recruited a star candidate — former provincial environment commissioner Dianne Saxe — to serve as deputy leader and run in the Toronto riding of University-Rosedale.
He is also building out a broader campaign platform that goes beyond environmental issues, including an ambitious mental health framework to be released Thursday and a housing plan that won plaudits last year.
When he rises in the legislature, Schreiner stands out. As leader of a caucus of one, he is not only the superior debater and speechmaker, but a more quotable media interlocutor outside the house.
It’s hard not to notice that his comments often appear higher up in reporters’ stories than those from rival opposition parties. That may be a reflection of a built-in media bias for his clarity and accessibility over obfuscation and deflection — and the comparison with others will be obvious when he debuts in televised election debates (he was shut out in the past for lacking a seat).
But Schreiner’s ability to grow as a politician doesn’t mean he can keep growing the Green seat count. His breakthrough in Guelph owed much to the 2018 collapse of the Liberal vote, and while he is destined to be re-elected it won’t be easy to to translate his popularity further afield.
Public opinion polling shows the provincial Greens ranging from three to 10 per cent support over the last couple of years, usually hovering at about five per cent (with a noticeable softening after the federal party started crumbling early last year). That said, voters tend to ignore Ontario politics until the campaigns begin.
With three months until voting day on June 2, Schreiner understands that Ontario’s Greens must distinguish themselves from their provincial rivals — but also distance themselves from the federal Greens.
“Sometimes adversity can make you stronger,” he says. “Some of the adversity that the party went through at the federal level, we can learn from that at the provincial level.”
Ontario’s Greens must make the case against global warming, but that’s only half the story. Apart from climate change, they also need to show an understanding of the province’s political environment — and learn lessons from the fate of their federal cousins.
Martin Regg Cohn is a Toronto-based columnist focusing on Ontario politics and international affairs for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @reggcohn

Christine Elliott officially announces she's no longer running for re-election in June

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/christine-elliott-officially-announces-shes-no/docview/2635540387/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Christine+Elliott+officially+announces+she%27s+no+longer+running+for+re-election+in+June&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Premier Doug Ford is losing a key player as Health Minister Christine Elliott — also his deputy premier — says she won’t run in the June 2 provincial election.
Elliott confirmed her pending retirement Friday following news reports on her decision.
“Between now and this spring, Premier Ford has asked me to continue to support our government as minister of health and I have agreed without hesitation,” she said, calling her 13 years as an MPP “a great honour, a great responsibility.”
Elliott, 66, is a lawyer by training. She has been in charge of the high-profile health portfolio throughout the pandemic, a role that attracted protesters to her home, sometimes into the early morning hours.
“After two-plus years of COVID, she deserves to have her life back,” one source told the Star.
During a stop at Sunnybrook hospital with Elliott on Friday, Ford paid tribute to her for shepherding the Health Ministry through a critical time.
“I’m very grateful that Christine’s going to stay on until the election and help us go through this pandemic, as we’re coming out of it slowly,” he said.
Elliott ran three times for the leadership of the Progressive Conservatives, losing close contests to Patrick Brown in 2015 and Ford in 2018. She also ran in 2009 against Tim Hudak.
The veteran MPP was first elected in Whitby-Oshawa in 2006. She took three years off from electoral politics after her 2015 leadership defeat and served as Ontario’s first patient ombudsman , a $220,000-a-year role to which she was appointed by former Liberal premier Kathleen Wynne. Elliott had been her party’s outspoken health critic.
She took a pay cut when she quit that job, unsuccessfully sought the leadership and subsequently won re-election to the legislature in Newmarket-Aurora four years ago.
Elliott is the second high-profile minister to announce a retirement from politics this year. Businessman and former finance and environment minister Rod Phillips resigned the long-term-care portfolio last month to return to private life.
The PCs quickly announced Dawn Gallagher Murphy, a consultant who has been Elliott’s community office manager in Newmarket-Aurora, will be the party’s candidate in the riding.
Elliott is among 18 PCs elected in Ford’s 2018 sweep of the previous Liberal government who are not running again under the party banner because they are in other parties, sitting as independents, refused to be vaccinated against COVID-19 or are leaving politics.
They include Independent MPP Randy Hillier (Lanark-Frontenac-Kingston), an outspoken opponent of public health measures to fight COVID-19, who said Thursday night he will not seek re-election. Hillier has been censured unanimously in the legislature twice recently for discreditable conduct.
Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1
