Lewis mulls second leadership bid: In last go-round, MP won support of social conservatives

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Mar 2022: A.18.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/lewis-mulls-second-leadership-bid-last-go-round/docview/2635437974/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Lewis+mulls+second+leadership+bid%3A+In+last+go-round%2C+MP+won+support+of+social+conservatives%3A+In+last+go-round%2C+MP+won+support+of+social+conservatives&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.18&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Leslyn Lewis is expected to officially enter the federal Conservative leadership race next week, a contest starting to take shape after the release of several key deadlines.
Lewis, a lawyer who is now an MP, ran for the leadership in 2020.
Despite starting off as a relative unknown, she swept up support first from social conservatives and then from many grassroots party members turned off by the two front-runners, Erin O'Toole and Peter MacKay.
She ultimately placed third.
A source close to Lewis said she's still waiting to see the fine print on the rules and if there are no major surprises, she will enter the race.
"We're in it to win," a source, granted anonymity to discuss the internal dynamics at play, told the Star.
Lewis may not be the only woman in the race.
Conservative strategist Tasha Kheiriddin is also considering a bid, telling the Star on Thursday she is continuing to weigh all of her options.
MP Scott Aitchison (Parry Sound-Muskoka) said Thursday he is also considering running but is waiting for the details on the rules.
"I am building a team that will bring Canadians and our party together," he said in a statement.
Also considering running are Ontario MPP Roman Baber and longtime Tory MP Michael Chong.
Candidates have until April 19 to apply to enter, and will have to pay $200,000, plus a refundable $100,000 deposit.
The schedule to make those payments might trip up a candidate.
The only officially declared candidate - Pierre Poilievre - has been raising money and is on tour, spending Thursday in Saskatchewan decrying the federal carbon tax.
Former Quebec premier and federal Progressive Conservative party Jean Charest has verbal pledges for financial support.
If he formally launches, as expected, his biggest push will be to sign up new members who will back his bid.
He held one-on-one meetings with Conservative MPs in Ottawa Thursday, after hosting a reception for them on Wednesday evening
Charest has also said the rules will tell him whether a campaign is viable and if he will have enough time to sign up members.
Charest's campaign already has the support of a number of Quebec MPs, but lawmakers from Nova Scotia, Ontario and Alberta were among those in the crowd.
So far, Poilievre leads in endorsements from MPs, with close to 30 already backing the parliamentary veteran. Charest has support from several Quebec MPs, as well as some from Ontario and Nova Scotia.
Lewis had seven caucus endorsements in 2020, but one has already decamped for Poilievre, one didn't get re-elected, and a third - Scott Reid - is now the caucus chair, so will remain neutral.
Whether caucus endorsements matter or not depends, said longtime Conservative strategist Michael Diamond, who worked on leadership campaigns in 2020 and 2017 but is sitting this one out.
"If someone is willing to go to war for you, that's good," he said. "But if it's just someone who posts a message, it doesn't have any impact."
MPs can play a role in helping sign up new members, a process that eventually helps them too, since every new name feeds into the party's broader voter database.
To vote in the race, members must sign up by June 3.
How many may eventually do that could depend on another potential candidate.
Patrick Brown, currently mayor of Brampton and a former federal MP, is considered one of the savviest and best-connected political organizers in the conservative movement.
He too is mulling a bid, and insiders say he'd have no trouble signing up thousands of people to support him.
One thing potentially stopping Brown is timing.
The last race happened against the complicated backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, this one will run concurrently with elections in Quebec and Ontario.
In Quebec, ballots will be cast in October, the same month as Ontario's municipal elections.
Ontario's provincial vote is on June 2.
Not only does that mean the focus for many conservatives will be divided among the various races, it's a bigger issue for Brown, Diamond said.
He'll have to make a decision whether he wants to take another crack at federal politics or stay local.
Municipal candidates must register to run by mid-August.
By then, ballots for the federal leadership race will already be in the mail, with the winner expected to be announced on Sept. 10.
CREDIT: Stephanie Levitz Toronto Star

Ontario's social assistance rates should be an election issue

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/ontarios-social-assistance-rates-should-be/docview/2635434364/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ontario%27s+social+assistance+rates+should+be+an+election+issue&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Here’s the problem.
Social assistance benefit levels are not indexed in Ontario. In real terms, they have fallen so far for so long that no political party except the Greens has promised to restore them to where they stood before the Harris cuts of 1995.
If the provincial government were to restore rates to where they were before the cuts, the Ontario Works (OW) single rate would have to climb by 67 per cent from $733 a month to $1,108 a month. Similarly, the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) would also have to climb by 67 per cent from $930 to $1,554 a month.
Increases like that would cost billions of dollars, and serious government contenders will choose to spend those billions elsewhere. (The Greens have said they would double ODSP rates, but they won’t get the chance to fulfil that promise.)
There have been no increases since 2018; they are for now frozen in time. It would take an eight per cent increase just to restore their pre-pandemic purchasing power.
To put that in perspective, the single combined maximum benefit level for Old Age Security recipients along with the Guaranteed Income Supplement rate for low-income seniors was $1,463 a month in mid-2018, and is $1,602 a month now following eight scheduled increases since then.
There are various benchmarks that parties could use for promises to raise rates. However, politicians fear them all since they would derive little political credit from advocates and activists for doing so.
They would likely say “too little, too late” — and they would be right.
So, let’s lower the bar and ask political parties to pledge to raise rates to the amount Mike Harris cut them to in 1995.
If that pledge became a reality, the OW single rate would climb by 16.2 per cent from $733 a month to $852 a month. And let’s ask for a similar 16.2 per cent increase to ODSP to take the single rate from $1,169 to $1,359 a month.
How would we pay for it?
Since the beginning of the pandemic in spring 2020, the number of social assistance beneficiaries has fallen by 14 per cent, or over 142,000 beneficiaries in November 2021.
A 16.2 per cent increase could be fully funded by the money saved by paying fewer people since the pandemic’s onset.
Where we live in North Scarborough, the lowest advertised rent for a shared room in an illegal rooming house is $500 a month. A reasonable diet costs over $200 a month (the threadbare welfare diet costs $187). This leaves $33 left over for a phone, internet, clothing, utensils, transit, personal care and everything else.
In other words, living on the remaining $33 now paid in addition to the cheapest room and a sketchy diet is impossible. An extra $119 a month would mean a little less destitution, and the impossible would at least become remotely conceivable.
Let’s see if anyone steps up and promises “16.2 in ’22.”
John Stapleton is a social policy expert at Open Policy Ontario. Yvonne Yuan is a policy analyst with Open Policy.

Today's coronavirus news: Major events returning to Toronto; Ontario reporting 821 people hospitalized with COVID-19

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/todays-coronavirus-news-major-events-returning/docview/2635433722/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Today%27s+coronavirus+news%3A+Major+events+returning+to+Toronto%3B+Ontario+reporting+821+people+hospitalized+with+COVID-19&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The latest coronavirus news from Canada and around the world Friday. This file will be updated throughout the day. Web links to longer stories if available .
6:07 p.m. Canada is rescheduling 11 planeloads of rapid COVID-19 tests that were due to be delivered this month, via Russian cargo jets, reports The Canadian Press.
A Russian-owned cargo plane successfully delivered a shipment of tests to Canada Sunday morning at Pearson Airport, according to CP.
Hours later Transport Minister Omar Alghabra announced Canada was closing its airspace to all Russian aircraft, effective immediately, in response to Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, and that plane remains grounded in Toronto.
Eleven more shipments of rapid tests were to be delivered this month on Russian planes but have all been cancelled.
A spokesman for Public Services and Procurement Minister Filomena Tassi says most have found new planes already, though the Russian planes can typically carry more and a small number of the deliveries have yet to find space on a cargo plane that can land in Canada.
Since January 1, 300 million rapid tests have been delivered to the federal government, which is buying them mainly on behalf of provincial governments.
Legislation to approve $2.5 billion in funding to Health Canada to buy and distribute the tests received royal assent Friday. That was on top of $1.7 billion approved in the fall fiscal update also for rapid tests.
Chief public health officer Dr. Theresa Tam said at her weekly briefing Friday that the easier access to rapid tests will help Canada in the event of another wave of COVID-19.
Early in the Omicron wave access to rapid tests became a massive problem, as infection rates soared and public health systems couldn’t keep up with demand for PCR tests in person.
That demand has now dropped along with infection rates, and Tam said that after months of high infection rates from Omicron and Canada’s high vaccination uptake, there are high levels of immunity to the variant across the country.
Because of testing limitations there is not yet good data on how many people got Omicron, she said. Since Omicron became the dominant variant in Canada in mid-December, 1.3 million cases were confirmed but only a small fraction of infections are now being recorded.
Ontario’s chief medical officer of health Dr. Kieran Moore said this week the actual number in his province is likely 10 times the reported figure.
“I do think that if it’s Omicron that’s circulating in the next month, we have a very good level of protection in the community, particularly with boosters protecting against severe outcomes,” Tam said. “But if there’s a variant that’s very different to Omicron, then that’s a different story and we will have to re-evaluate the risk of any vaccine-evasive variants.”
Tam said even if such a variant arrives, there are more treatment options for COVID-19, including the recently approved Paxlovid antiviral drug from Pfizer, as well as more access to rapid tests, a better understanding of the virus’s transmission, the benefits of good ventilation and easy access to masks.
She said with all of those measures “we’ve got to be able to go into the fall and winter season, or indeed the next wave if it should come in between, with much more ability to respond without those really severe restrictions. That is the goal.”
Tam did urge health systems to take the time they have now to invest in surge capacity so if another wave arrives, we don’t need to turn to drastic closures to keep hospitals from getting overwhelmed.
She said possibly reconsidering how we license international health professionals to help in Canada could come into play, as could finding efficiencies by using virtual care.
Tam also said face masks should be kept on hand as the first line of defence against COVID-19 even if they are not mandatory.
Alberta and Saskatchewan lifted mask mandates this week, with Manitoba following mid-month, Ontario possibly by month’s end and Quebec by the middle of April.
She said she personally will look at local infection rates and the risk to her or her family members from COVID-19 to determine when or if she will stop wearing a mask.
Infection rates have continued to fall this week, as have hospitalizations and the number of people in intensive care.
The number of hospitalized patients with COVID-19 peaked on Jan. 22 at 11,022, with 1,233 of them in intensive care. As of Feb. 28, there were 5,136 people in hospital with COVID-19, and 570 in intensive care. That’s down more than 15 per cent in the last week alone.
Tam said people can help avoid another serious wave by getting vaccinated. Public Health Canada data show that since vaccines became available in Canada, unvaccinated and partly vaccinated individuals accounted for 58 per cent of all cases and 75 per cent of all hospitalizations.
4:13 p.m. Nova Scotia has reported four new COVID-19-related deaths, bringing the total number of deaths in the province to 212, reports The Canadian Press.
Officials say the most recent deaths involve a man in his 50s from the northern zone, a man in his 70s from the eastern zone and two men in their 80s from the northern and western zones, according to CP.
A total of 294 new lab-confirmed cases of COVID-19 were reported.
There are now 45 people in hospital due to the disease, including 13 in ICU.
Officials estimate there are now 2,650 active cases of COVID-19 in Nova Scotia.
Nova Scotia will be moving to weekly reporting, and the next COVID-19 release and dashboard update will be sent out on Thursday.
3:50 p.m. Montreal public health officials were against the COVID-19 curfew that the province imposed last December, because little data existed on its effectiveness and out of concern for the most vulnerable, government documents reveal, reports The Canadian Press.
Internal documents released by the Health Department indicate Montreal officials expressed concern over limited scientific data to support a curfew as an effective means of reducing COVID-19 transmission. City officials also cited pandemic fatigue, impact on vulnerable groups such as domestic violence victims, and the worry that a curfew would encourage people to adopt riskier behaviours, according to CP.
The ethics review was prepared by the city’s health officials during the hard-hitting wave of the Omicron variant of the novel coronavirus, when the Health Department was considering what restrictions to impose to reduce transmission.
Radio-Canada initially received the ethics review by Montreal officials through an access to information request — but the entirety of its contents was redacted. Following outcry from the opposition and journalists, the Health Department released the full review late Thursday.
Legault imposed the curfew on Dec. 31, 2021, forbidding Quebecers from leaving their homes between 10 p.m. and 5 a.m. He lifted the order two weeks later on Jan. 17. He had imposed a curfew earlier in 2021 for almost five months, between January and May. Quebec was the only province to prohibit its citizens from leaving their homes at night as a way to control COVID-19 transmission.
The documents also show that the province’s former public health director, Dr. Horacio Arruda, was looking for evidence to justify the December curfew only hours before it was announced.
Meanwhile, Quebec has reported 16 more deaths due to COVID-19 on Friday and a 51-patient drop in the number of people hospitalized with the disease. There were 1,313 people in hospital with COVID-19, after 88 people were admitted in the past 24 hours and 139 people were discharged. The number of people in intensive care rose by four, to 80.
Quebec announced earlier this week that it would lift most public health orders, including indoor capacity limits and the vaccine passport requirement, on March 12, which is two days earlier than previously announced.
Mask mandates in all public places except public transportation will be lifted by mid-April at the latest, the government said.
3:02 p.m. Canada’s chief public health officer says that, as long as Omicron remains the dominant variant of COVID-19 in Canada, the risk of another massive wave of infections is low, reports The Canadian Press.
Dr. Theresa Tam says the number of cases of Omicron in recent months, coupled with Canada’s high vaccination rates, created good community-level protection against COVID-19 for now, according to CP.
She warns that if another variant emerges that is significantly different from Omicron, and able to evade current vaccines, that could change.
But even in that scenario, she says better treatments and more availability of rapid tests make it unlikely that more disruptive measures such as school closures and gathering limits will be needed.
Tam says face masks should be kept on hand as the first line of defence against COVID-19 even if they are not mandatory.
2:59 p.m. Canada’s chief public health officer says that as long as Omicron remains the dominant variant of COVID-19 in Canada, the risk of another massive wave of infections is low.
Dr. Theresa Tam says the number of cases of Omicron in recent months, coupled with Canada’s high vaccination rates, created good community-level protection against COVID-19 for now.
She warns that if another variant emerges that is significantly different from Omicron, and able to evade current vaccines, that could change.
But even in that scenario, she says better treatments and more availability of rapid tests make it unlikely that more disruptive measures like school closures and gathering limits will be needed.
Tam says face masks should be kept on hand as the first line of defence against COVID-19 even if they are not mandatory.
Alberta and Saskatchewan lifted mask mandates this week, with Manitoba following mid-month, Ontario possibly by month’s end and Quebec by the middle of April.
2:55 p.m. Ege Kok had been searching for weeks for somewhere in her north Toronto neighbourhood where she could easily get a booster dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.
She’d received her second dose last summer but found it tough to secure a third when the province made them available for all Ontarians in late December.
This week, while scouring the internet for pop-up clinics, she learned of a walk-in site opening at a local library branch just a 10-minute bus ride away from her home. By Thursday afternoon, both 31-year-old Kok and her mother were able to get their boosters in the library’s glass-walled conference room where half a dozen vaccine stations had been set up.
The library clinic is part of the City of Toronto’s new “Vax and Read” campaign that launched this week as part of a hyper-local strategy to target areas with low vaccine uptake. Twelve public libraries will host walk-in vaccine clinics on various days until March 16.
2:45 p.m. Newfoundland and Labrador health authorities say 16 people are hospitalized with the disease, one more than reported during the last update on Wednesday.
Of those, the number of people in intensive care remains unchanged at six.
The province reported 497 new COVID-19 cases on Thursday and 450 today for a total of 947 new infections since Wednesday.
2:22 p.m. This time, it feels different.
Although Toronto concert venues — and clubs especially — were allowed 100 per cent capacity for six weeks in late 2021 before the Omicron surge hit, the lifting of restrictions feels like it’s more final than in other incarnations.
Shaun Bowring, owner of Toronto clubs The Garrison (capacity 350) and The Baby G (capacity 150), agreed.
“It seems in general that public health guidance and governments are at the point where they’re saying, ‘OK, we’re living with this and we’re hopefully headed into an endemic.’ That seems to be something that’s happening globally, not just locally or provincially.”
Whether this is a move by the Ontario government that’s borne out of COVID fatigue, public interest, mental health or a combination of all those factors, Bowring, who is happy that his clubs are back at full capacity, wishes they would have been given a little more notice.
Read more here.
12:56 p.m. Four athletes set to compete at the Tim Hortons Brier have yet to make the trip to Lethbridge, Alta., after testing positive for COVID-19 on their pre-departure PCR tests, Curling Canada said Friday in a statement.
Each competitor plays on a different team, the federation said, without identifying any of the athletes. The players remain in isolation in their respective hometowns.
Round-robin play was scheduled to begin Friday night at the Enmax Centre. Competition continues through March 13.
12:21 p.m. U.S. businesses stepped up their hiring last month as the Omicron faded and more Americans ventured out to spend at restaurants, shops, and hotels despite surging inflation.
Employers added 678,000 jobs in February, the largest monthly total since July, the Labor Department reported Friday. The unemployment rate dropped to 3.8%, from 4% in January, extending a sharp decline in joblessness to its lowest level since before the pandemic erupted two years ago.
Friday’s hiring figures were collected before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which has sent oil prices jumping and has heightened risks and uncertainties for economies in Europe and the rest of the world.
Yet the February hiring data suggest that two years after COVID-19 sparked a nationwide shutdown and 22 million job losses, the disease is losing its grip on America’s economy. More people are taking jobs or searching for work — a trend that, if it endures, will help ease the labor shortages that have bedeviled employers for the past year.
12:04 p.m. New York City will lift mandates next week requiring masks in public schools and proof of vaccination to dine in restaurants or enter entertainment, sports and cultural venues, Mayor Eric Adams announced Friday.
Standing in Times Square, Adams said that while the COVID-19 pandemic isn’t over, he was confident that it is now safe to send children to school unmasked.
“We want to see the faces of our children. We want to see their smiles,” the mayor said, adding that parents could continue to send their kids to school with face coverings if they wished.
The mayor, a Democrat, last weekend said he would lift the mandates if infections and hospitalizations continued a downward trend. He stressed that the mandates could be re-imposed if a new variant emerges that, like Omicron, poses a special danger.
11:52 a.m. Quebec is reporting 16 more deaths due to COVID-19 and a 51-patient drop in the number of people hospitalized with the disease.
There are 1,313 people in hospital with COVID-19, after 88 people were admitted in the past 24 hours and 139 people were discharged.
The number of people in intensive care rose by four, to 80.
Health officials are reporting another 1,354 COVID-19 infections detected through PCR testing, which is restricted to certain groups.
11:30 a.m. Canada’s Laurent Dubreuil has tested positive for COVID-19 at the world speedskating championships, sinking his chance at claiming the men’s sprint title.
Speed Skating Canada released a statement from Dubreuil confirming the positive test shortly before Friday’s races were set to begin.
Dubreuil sat first in the men’s overall sprint standings following Thursday’s races after winning the first 500-metre sprint and finishing third in the first 1,000-metre race.
Sprint champions are decided after two races over 500 metres and two over 1,000. The final sprint races were all scheduled to take place Friday.
10:17 a.m. (updated) Ontario is reporting 262 people in ICU due to COVID-19 and 821 in hospital overall testing positive for COVID-19, according to its latest report released Friday morning.
Of the people hospitalized, 44 per cent were admitted for COVID-19 and 56 per cent were admitted for other reasons but have since tested positive. For the ICU numbers, 80 per cent were admitted for COVID-19 and 20 per cent were admitted for other reasons but have since tested positive.
Given new provincial regulations around testing that took effect Dec. 31, 2021, case counts — reported at 2,085 on Friday, down eight per cent from the previous day — are also not considered an accurate assessment of how widespread COVID-19 is right now; 28 virus-related new deaths were reported in the latest numbers.

Mayor John Tory made the announcement at the TIFF Bell Lightbox on Friday morning, signalling the next phase of re-opening in the city almost 24 months since the provincial government first declared an emergency over COVID-19.

Elliott confirmed her pending retirement in a statement Friday morning, following news reports Thursday night .
“After considerable reflection and discussion with my family, it is with deep gratitude for my 16 years in public life that I recently shared with Premier Ford I will not be seeking re-election in the upcoming provincial contest in June,” she wrote.

7:35 a.m. March 1 marked a big day in Ontario, with proof of vaccination no longer required for workplaces, and capacity limits for indoor public settings being lifted.
With restrictions slowly being lifted, many workers are wondering what masking policies they will face as they slowly return to in-person work at the office.
The government of Ontario requires that people wear masks in the workplace if they are unable to stay at least two metres apart. In a common space, boardroom meeting, lunch room, people can be unmasked only if they’re a safe distance from one another.

7:10 a.m. Toronto high school student Evan Woo is “done” with wearing masks in class.
Not only does he miss seeing his friends’ faces — and would love to know what some teachers look like beneath the nose — but he says masks are a “barrier” to learning because voices are muffled.
“Sometimes it’s hard to hear someone speaking two desks down from where I’m sitting,” said the Grade 12 student at Earl Haig Second, ary School.
Read the full story from the Stars’s Isabel Teotonio
5:45 a.m.: Long-standing inequities in education, housing and employment in Nova Scotia’s Black communities have been amplified by COVID-19, according to community leaders who are trying to collect better race-based data on the pandemic.
Those same issues have left African Nova Scotians vulnerable to misinformation about the disease, said David Haase, with the Health Association of African Nova Scotians, or HAAC.
“When COVID came along, we recognized that there was misinformation, mainly on social media, that the community was seeing and absorbing,” Haase said during a recent interview. “Things like, ‘Black people are not as easily infected,’ which is the opposite to the reality, we realized.”
The last two years have been particularly difficult for the province’s Black community, many of whom are descendants of American Loyalists who arrived in Nova Scotia in the 1780s, as a result of the American Revolution.
John Ariyo, director of equality and engagement with the province, said in an interview last week, “COVID has actually uncovered ... some of the inequalities in our communities when it comes to Black residents.”
Friday 5:42 a.m.: The markets are crowded again. Traffic is jamming the roads. Migrant workers have returned to the cities. And young people are back at schools and universities — many of them for the first time in years.
It isn’t quite how things were before the COVID-19 pandemic — mask mandates still exist in some places — but with infections steadily declining, life in South Asia is returning to a sense of normalcy.
The mental scars from last year’s delta-driven surge persist — especially in India, where health systems collapsed and millions likely died — but across the region high vaccination rates and hope that the highly contagious Omicron variant has helped bolster immunity are giving people reasons to be optimistic.
While experts agree that opening up was the right move amid falling case numbers, they caution that optimism should be tempered with lessons from the past two years.

Will social assistance rates be an election issue?

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Mar 2022: A.16.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/will-social-assistance-rates-be-election-issue/docview/2635434344/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Will+social+assistance+rates+be+an+election+issue%3F&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.16&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Here's the problem: Social assistance benefit levels are not indexed in Ontario. In real terms, they have fallen so far for so long that no political party except the Greens has promised to restore them to where they stood before the Harris cuts of 1995.
If the province were to restore rates to where they were before the cuts, the Ontario Works single rate would have to climb by 67 per cent from $733 a month to $1,108 a month. Similarly, the Ontario Disability Support Program (ODSP) would also have to climb 67 per cent from $930 to $1,554 a month.
Increases like that would cost billions of dollars, and serious government contenders will choose to spend those billions elsewhere. (The Greens have said they would double ODSP rates, but they won't get the chance to fulfil that promise.)
There have been no increases since 2018; they are for now frozen in time. It would take an eight per cent increase just to restore their pre-pandemic purchasing power.
To put that in perspective, the single combined maximum benefit level for old age security recipients along with the guaranteed income supplement rate for low-income seniors was $1,463 a month in mid-2018, and is $1,602 a month now following eight scheduled increases since then.
There are various benchmarks that parties could use for promises to raise rates. However, politicians fear them all since they would derive little political credit from advocates and activists for doing so.
They would likely say "too little, too late" - correctly.
So, let's lower the bar and ask political parties to pledge to raise rates to the amount Mike Harris cut them to in 1995.
If that pledge became a reality, the OW single rate would climb by 16.2 per cent from $733 a month to $852 a month. And let's ask for a similar 16.2 per cent increase to ODSP to take the single rate from $1,169 to $1,359 a month.
How would we pay for it?
Since the beginning of the pandemic in spring 2020, the number of social assistance beneficiaries has fallen by 14 per cent, or over 142,000 beneficiaries in November 2021.
A 16.2 per cent increase could be fully funded by the money saved by paying fewer people since the pandemic's onset.
Where we live in North Scarborough, the lowest advertised rent for a shared room in an illegal rooming house is $500 a month. A reasonable diet costs over $200 a month (the threadbare welfare diet costs $187). This leaves $33 for a phone, internet, clothing, utensils, transit, personal care and everything else.
In other words, living on the remaining $33 now paid in addition to the cheapest room and a sketchy diet is impossible. An extra $119 a month would mean a little less destitution, and the impossible would at least become remotely conceivable.
Let's see if anyone steps up and promises "16.2 in '22."
John Stapleton is a social policy expert at Open Policy Ontario. Yvonne Yuan is a policy analyst with Open Policy ontario.
CREDIT: John Stapleton and Yvonne Yuan Contributors John Stapleton is a social policy expert at Open Policy Ontario. Yvonne Yuan is a policy analyst with Open Policy ontario.;

Leslyn Lewis preparing to enter Conservative leadership race

Publication info: Mar 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/leslyn-lewis-preparing-enter-conservative/docview/2635433482/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Leslyn+Lewis+preparing+to+enter+Conservative+leadership+race&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA—Leslyn Lewis is expected to officially enter the federal Conservative leadership race next week, a contest starting to take shape after the release of several key deadlines.
Lewis, a lawyer who is now an MP, ran for the leadership in 2020. Despite starting off as a relative unknown, she swept up support first from social conservatives and then from many grassroots party members turned off by the two front-runners, Erin O’Toole and Peter MacKay.
She ultimately placed third.
A source close to Lewis said she’s still waiting to see the fine print on the rules and if there are no major surprises, she will enter the race.
“We’re in it to win,” a source, granted anonymity to discuss the internal dynamics at play, told the Star.
Lewis may not be the only woman in the race.
Conservative strategist Tasha Kheiriddin is also considering a bid, telling the Star on Thursday she’s continuing to weigh her options.
MP Scott Aitchison (Parry Sound-Muskoka) said Thursday he is also considering running but is waiting for the details on the rules.
“I am building a team that will bring Canadians and our party together,” he said in a statement.
Also considering running are Ontario MPP Roman Baber and longtime Tory MP Michael Chong.
Candidates have until April 19 to apply to enter, and will have to pay $200,000, plus a refundable $100,000 deposit.
The schedule to make those payments might trip up a candidate. The only officially declared candidate — Pierre Poilievre — has been raising money and is on tour, spending Thursday in Saskatchewan decrying the federal carbon tax.
Former Quebec premier and federal Progressive Conservative party Jean Charest has verbal pledges for financial support. If he formally launches, as expected, his biggest push will be to sign up new members who will back his bid.
He held one-on-one meetings with Conservative MPs in Ottawa Thursday, after hosting a reception for them on Wednesday evening.
So far, Poilievre leads in endorsements from MPs, with close to 30 already backing the parliamentary veteran. Charest has support from several Quebec MPs, as well as some from Ontario and Nova Scotia.
Lewis had seven caucus endorsements in 2020, but one has already decamped for Poilievre, one didn’t get re-elected, and a third — Scott Reid — is now the caucus chair, so will remain neutral.
Whether caucus endorsements matter or not depends, said longtime Conservative strategist Michael Diamond, who worked on leadership campaigns in 2020 and 2017 but is sitting this one out.
“If someone is willing to go to war for you, that’s good,” he said. “But if it’s just someone who posts a message, it doesn’t have any impact.”
MPs can play a role in helping sign up new members, a process that eventually helps them too, since every new name feeds into the party’s broader voter database. To vote in the race, members must sign up by June 3.
How many may eventually do that could depend on another potential candidate.
Patrick Brown, currently mayor of Brampton and a former federal MP, is considered one of the savviest and best-connected political organizers in the conservative movement.
He too is mulling a bid, and insiders say he’d have no trouble signing up thousands of people to support him.
One thing potentially stopping Brown is timing.
The last race happened against the complicated backdrop of the COVID-19 pandemic, this one will run concurrently with elections in Quebec and Ontario.
In Quebec, ballots will be cast in October, the same month as Ontario’s municipal elections. Ontario’s provincial vote is on June 2.
Not only does that mean the focus for many conservatives will be divided among the various races, it’s a bigger issue for Brown, Diamond said.
He’ll have to make a decision whether he wants to take another crack at federal politics or stay local.
Municipal candidates must register to run by mid-August.
By then, ballots for the federal leadership race will already be in the mail, with the winner expected to be announced on Sept. 10.
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

Where is the respect for the vulnerable, the immunocompromised?

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/where-is-respect-vulnerable-immunocompromised/docview/2635432774/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Where+is+the+respect+for+the+vulnerable%2C+the+immunocompromised%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: As Ontario lifts restrictions, immunocompromised and other vulnerable people feel left out of the party, Feb. 28
I can relate to this article, because of my medical situation, as I’m sure many other people do. When Doug Ford said, “We have to learn to live with (COVID-19),” my immediate reaction was, “Great! I need to learn how not to die from COVID.”
Do I expect all public health guidelines to remain in force as numbers continue to improve?
No.
I do expect consideration be given to people like me and others who are at risk, by maintaining mask mandates, continuing with the vaccination campaign, and expanding testing for more accurate positivity numbers, so that we can have some semblance of safety.
I also wish people would respect physical distancing, especially when they are not masked. They might feel safe being close to me; I don’t feel the same way.
It is all about respect.
Phyllis Grossman , Toronto

Ontario on track to lift COVID-19 mask mandates this month, top doctor says

Publication info: Mar 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/ontario-on-track-lift-covid-19-mask-mandates-this/docview/2635432110/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ontario+on+track+to+lift+COVID-19+mask+mandates+this+month%2C+top+doctor+says&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ontario will lift mask mandates “by the end of March” if positive trends continue, even as the more contagious BA.2 strain of COVID-19 becomes dominant and wastewater shows infection levels rising during the province’s reopening.
That’s the message from chief medical officer Dr. Kieran Moore, who said Thursday a continued decline in hospitalizations and high booster shot levels among the most vulnerable are making the move possible.
“We can only mandate masking for so long,” Moore told a news conference, noting his office is monitoring data and is assuming actual infection levels are 10 times higher than shown by limited PCR testing.
That means Tuesday’s confirmed case count of another 2,262 Ontarians testing positive for COVID-19 actually represents something more like 23,000 new cases.
The masking change could be announced as soon as next Thursday, when Moore holds his last scheduled weekly briefing of the pandemic.
Premier Doug Ford said at a separate event in Toronto’s west end that he is waiting on a recommendation from Moore and hopes the mask mandate is lifted “as soon as possible.” Several days ago, the premier, who is up for re-election June 2, suggested masking could be lifted after March break.
While the BA.2 variant of COVID-19 is 30 per cent more contagious than the Omicron strain — which sparked a sudden fifth wave of the pandemic — and is expected to dominate in Ontario by mid-month, it does not appear to be causing an increase in hospitalizations.
“The only concern is that increased transmissibility factor, so it can spread quite quickly. There are some studies that show a very small risk of reinfection,” said Moore, who pointed to a “strong wall of defence” from vaccination and widespread levels of Omicron infection since early December.
Without widespread PCR testing, which was scrapped before Christmas amid the Omicron onslaught, Ontario is relying on wastewater testing that shows rates of new COVID-19 infections had stabilized and are “just slowly going up in many regions across Ontario,” Moore added.
That correlates with the reopening, but he expects that trend to stabilize given high immunization levels.
Moore said the lifting of mask mandates does not mean the dangers of COVID-19 are over and recommended people with medical conditions that put them in greater danger from the virus continue wearing masks in indoor public spaces and other situations where they feel it is appropriate.
“The risk remains,” he said.
Moore has indicated previously that mask mandates may remain in hospitals, nursing homes and on public transit even after they are lifted in most indoor public spaces and schools.
Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1

CAPTION: Dr. Kieran Moore, Ontario's chief medical officer of health speaks in Toronto on Wednesday, January 12, 2022.

Letters

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Mar 2022: A.16.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/letters/docview/2635431957/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Letters&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.16&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Divesting from fossil fuels should be next
More than 100 Canadian business leaders vow to sell off Russian investments - and call on other investors to do the same, March 2
I applaud the business leaders pulling their money out of Russia as a response to its invasion of Ukraine. Any individual divestment will have an effect, even if it is small. Perhaps more importantly, it involves the business leaders at a moral level in the response to the war and the threat it poses.
It is my hope these leaders will then see we face a much greater threat from the climate crisis that is upon us, and join with those of us who are divesting from oil, coal and gas.
After all, fossil fuels are the main sources of the gases that are causing climate change, which in turn causes between several hundred thousand to several million excess deaths per year, depending on the study cited.
Surely climate change also demands moral and practical responses from all of us, including business leaders.
Dave Kempton, Newmarket
We are at war for the future of our democracy
It is amazing that little old me in Sharbot Lake has been attacked by bots (robot Facebook accounts with no followers), because I posted Mark Carney's follow-the-money editorial about the convoy occupiers of Ottawa. Both my Sharbot Lake Business Group and my personal Facebook accounts were attacked.
Less than 1,000 folks shut down our capital, causing $1 billion in damages - never mind 30,000 residents having to be assaulted by horns 24/7 and harassed individually for 21 days.
The source of this is pro-Putin American and Russian money producing slick videos to make the vulnerable angry enough to try to bring down Canada's government. Trudeau and Freeland are the targets.
Putin's invasion of Ukraine is supported by Trump and his followers. Trump calls Canada a tyranny and supports the convoy occupiers.
We can no longer be naive about how world war is conducted, and how money and social media have no boundaries.
We are at war for the future of our democracy.
Ken Fisher, Sharbot Lake, Ont.
NATO, Biden partly to blame for Ukraine war
'Putin was wrong. We were ready', Mar. 2
Joe Biden's revival of his unity agenda, as Edward Keenan points out, may save his party from defeat at the midterm elections, but it is at the cost of Ukrainian lives lost in a war that he provoked.
Putin was wrong to invade, but the U.S.-led NATO countries must share the responsibility for this outcome by refusing to negotiate a security agreement with Russia over at least the last two decades.
Michael Kuttner, Toronto
Where is
the respect for the vulnerable?
As Ontario lifts restrictions, immunocompromised and other vulnerable people feel left out of the party, Feb. 28
I can relate to this article, because of my medical situation, as I'm sure many other people do. When Doug Ford said, "We have to learn to live with (COVID-19)," my immediate reaction was, "Great! I need to learn how not to die from COVID."
Do I expect all public health guidelines to remain in force as numbers continue to improve?
No.
I do expect consideration be given to people like me and others who are at risk, by maintaining mask mandates, continuing with the vaccination campaign, and expanding testing for more accurate positivity numbers, so that we can have some semblance of safety.
I also wish people would respect physical distancing, especially when they are not masked. They might feel safe being close to me; I don't feel the same way.
It is all about respect.
Phyllis Grossman, Toronto

Greens' Schreiner should be more popular

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Mar 2022: A.15.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/greens-schreiner-should-be-more-popular/docview/2635431796/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Greens%27+Schreiner+should+be+more+popular&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.15&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Mike Schreiner has an image problem.
Not him, his brand.
As leader of Ontario's Green Party, he keeps outperforming his political rivals on the provincial stage. He is articulate and authentic, passionate and persuasive.
But that's only half the story - his personal success story on the eve of an Ontario election campaign.
The other half is the hard part - the tough story of last September's federal election.
That's when Canada's Greens self-destructed on the national campaign trail. The fallout was far and wide.
The fight against global warming was overshadowed by a civil war within a national party that couldn't stop talking about war in the Middle East. Its high-profile leader, Annamie Paul, went down in a ball of flames and its voter support vanished.
In truth, Schreiner had nothing to do with that cross-country disaster. In fact, Ontario's Green Party is a separate entity.
But in politics, perception counts. In reality, the Green movement is one big global brand with blurred boundaries.
Now, Schreiner must juggle brand management and damage control, while still trying to win over the province and save the planet. That means outshining the rival leaders of Ontario's major parties, but also outrunning the ghosts of the Green Party of Canada.
Schreiner prefers to face the elephant in the room head on, rather than pretend no one sees it. At a recent Ryerson Democracy Forum that I hosted for Ontario's three opposition party leaders, he heard a recurring audience question:
What happened to the federal Greens, and what does it mean for Ontario?
"I'm a straight shooter - there's no doubt there was a lot of turmoil within the federal party over the last year," Schreiner replied.
"But I want to be very clear with people: the Ontario Greens are a separate party with a different organizational culture and governance structure," he stressed. "While the federal party was going through its turmoil, we set a record for the most fundraising we've ever, ever had in a year in our party's history. We have more volunteers than we ever had, we have the largest staff."
That's the inescapable irony: Schreiner finds himself in an enviable position provincially despite the unenviable decline of his counterparts federally.
Today, 14 years after taking over the party, he has spearheaded breakthroughs that Greens had long waited for.
Schreiner won the party's first seat in Guelph in the last election, and the party has recruited a star candidate - former provincial environment commissioner Dianne Saxe - to serve as deputy leader and run in the Toronto riding of University-Rosedale.
He is also building out a broader campaign platform that goes beyond environmental issues, including an ambitious mental health framework to be released Thursday and a housing plan that won plaudits last year.
When he rises in the legislature, Schreiner stands out.
As leader of a caucus of one, he is not only the superior debater and speechmaker, but a more quotable media interlocutor outside the house.
It's hard not to notice that his comments often appear higher up in reporters' stories than those from rival opposition parties. That may be a reflection of a built-in media bias for his clarity and accessibility over obfuscation and deflection - and the comparison with others will be obvious when he debuts in televised election debates (he was shut out in the past for lacking a seat).
But Schreiner's ability to grow as a politician doesn't mean he can keep growing the Green seat count. His breakthrough in Guelph owed much to the 2018 collapse of the Liberal vote, and while he is destined to be re-elected, it won't be easy to translate his popularity further afield.
Public opinion polling shows the provincial Greens ranging from three to 10 per cent support over the last couple of years, usually hovering at about five per cent (with a noticeable softening after the federal party started crumbling early last year). That said, voters tend to ignore Ontario politics until the campaigns begin.
With three months until voting day, Schreiner understands that Ontario's Greens must distinguish themselves from their provincial rivals - but also distance themselves from the federal Greens.
"Sometimes adversity can make you stronger," he says. "Some of the adversity that the party went through at the federal level, we can learn from that at the provincial level."
Ontario's Greens must make the case against global warming, but that's only half the story. Apart from climate change, they also need to show an understanding of the province's political environment - and learn lessons from the fate of their federal cousins.
Twitter: @reggcohn
CAPTION: Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner must outshine the rival leaders of Ontario's major political parties, but also outrun the ghosts of the Green Party of Canada, Martin Regg Cohn writes.Angus Chan

Deputy Premier Christine Elliott will not seek re-election, sources say

Publication info: Mar 4, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/deputy-premier-christine-elliott-will-not-seek-re/docview/2635431603/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Deputy+Premier+Christine+Elliott+will+not+seek+re-election%2C+sources+say&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Premier Doug Ford is about to lose another key member of his cabinet as Ontario’s spring election approaches.
Health minister and deputy premier Christine Elliott will not run for the Progressive Conservatives in the June 2 vote, sources said Thursday night.
Elliott, 66 and a lawyer by training, has been in charge of the high-profile health portfolio throughout the pandemic, a role that attracted anti-restrictions protesters to her home at times.
“After two-plus years of COVID she deserves to have her life back,” one source told the Star after CBC first reported her pending departure.
Neither Elliott nor government officials replied to requests for comment.
Elliott ran three times for the Progressive Conservative leadership, losing close contests to Patrick Brown in 2015 and Doug Ford in 2018 following Brown’s sudden resignation. She also ran in 2009 against Tim Hudak.
The veteran MPP took three years off from electoral politics after her 2015 leadership defeat and served as Ontario’s first patient ombudsman , a $220,000-a-year role to which she was appointed by former Liberal premier Kathleen Wynne. Elliott had been her party’s outspoken health critic.
She took a pay cut when she quit the job, unsuccessfully sought the leadership and subsequently won re-election to the legislature in Newmarket-Aurora four years ago.
Elliott is the second high-profile minister to quit Ford's cabinet this year. Businessman and former finance and environment minister Rod Phillips resigned the long-term care portfolio last month to return to private life.
Several of Ford’s MPPs have also announced they will not run in the June election.
Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1

Jean Charest mulls foray into Tory leadership race

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/jean-charest-mulls-foray-into-tory-leadership/docview/2635312286/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Jean+Charest+mulls+foray+into+Tory+leadership+race&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA—Longtime Quebec politician Jean Charest was greeted with hugs and applause late Wednesday in what was his first public foray into the leadership race for the federal Conservative party.
The stakes are high for the former federal Progressive Conservative leader, already being slammed as a Liberal by other federal Tories.
But Charest was jovial when asked on his way into the small reception — held in the aptly-named Quebec room of the famous Chateau Laurier hotel — whether he was going to run.
“Where to?” he joked.
In earnest, Charest said he was waiting for the rules of the race itself to be revealed before making a decision.
The party released a few details late Wednesday: The new leader will be selected by Sept. 10, and candidates will have until June 3 to sign up new members.
That deadline is key, sources close to Charest had said earlier, as it will help them decide whether they can sign up enough people in time to be able to win.
Charest said there is one thing he knows already.
“One thing that I believe to be very important is to have a national Conservative party that is able to represent every part of Canada,” he said.
“It’s really our responsibility to be that national political party.”
Charest said the rules will tell him whether a campaign is viable — will he have enough time to sign up members is a key point, his team told the Star.
Charest’s campaign already has the support of a number of Quebec MPs, but lawmakers from Nova Scotia, Ontario and Alberta were among those in the crowd.
He said he was there to hear from them about their concerns, and many said they were there to hear Charest’s ideas.
Calgary MP Greg McLean said while some might knock Charest’s progressive credentials, it’s not a bad thing.
“It is something he brings to the table that is laudable,” McLean said on his way into the event.
“A lot of people in Alberta still believe we need a Progressive Conservative type of government.”
So far, there is only one officially declared candidate in the race, career MP Pierre Poilievre.
He has amassed considerable support from caucus already — some on his side held their own private event on Thursday at the same time.
Others took to social media, circulating a graphic that equaled him to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, for his support of carbon taxes and the now-defunct long-gun registry.
He was in favour of both while serving as premier of Quebec, where he also raised provincial sales tax.
“I’m with grassroots Conservative Party members, Alberta MP Shannon Stubbs wrote.
“Our leader must share our values, and respect our policies. I’m against the carbon tax, the long-gun registry, and for tax cuts, not tax hikes.”
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

House votes in favour of Emergencies Act oversight committee

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/house-votes-favour-emergencies-act-oversight/docview/2635311658/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=House+votes+in+favour+of+Emergencies+Act+oversight+committee&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The House of Commons has approved the creation of a special committee to review the powers exercised by the Trudeau government under the Emergencies Act, but the bickering over its structure has cast doubt on its effectiveness.
The House voted 214-115 Wednesday evening in favour of a government proposal that will see three Liberal MPs, two Conservatives, one New Democrat and one Bloc Québécois sit on the committee, along with four senators.
Conservatives opposed the proposal, with the NDP and Bloc voting in favour. A similar motion must now be dealt with in the Senate before the committee can get up and running, with its report expected later this month.
The federal government used the Emergencies Act for the first time on Feb. 14 to deal with the so-called “Freedom Convoy” occupation in Ottawa and blockades at border crossings. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau revoked the declaration of emergency last week.
The act requires that a joint House-Senate committee review the powers and duties exercised while the declaration of emergency was in effect. Experts worry that the acrimony between the Liberals and Conservatives over what the committee should look like will taint its ultimate findings.
“There isn’t even an agreement on the structure of the parliamentary oversight committee, let alone what sort of report would come out of it,” said Perrin Beatty, who introduced the Emergencies Act in 1987 while serving as defence minister in Brian Mulroney’s Progressive Conservative government.
“That’s unfortunate. It disserves the country.”
The fighting has not inspired confidence in the committee’s ability to do its work, said national security expert Wesley Wark. He said this work should include getting a picture of what the federal government understood to be the threat requiring use of the act, and the delayed responses by government to the protests.
“Parliament is deeply divided in its response to the use of the Emergencies Act,” he said, “and it is very difficult to see how that partisanship is going to be set aside once the committee gets going.”
What exactly the committee will be studying and who it will be hearing from remains to be seen, with some of those parameters only becoming clearer once the committee begins its work.
The act states that committee members will take an oath of secrecy and review in private any order or regulation issued in secret while the declaration of emergency was in effect.
But the Privy Council Office confirmed that no such orders or regulations were made, and it’s expected some if not most of the committee’s work will be done in public.
The government’s proposal will see the committee get three co-chairs: the NDP and Bloc MPs and one senator. The government argued that neither the Liberals nor the Conservatives should co-chair, given that the former invoked the Emergencies Act and the latter expressed support for the protests that led to its invocation.
“It’s essential that as we move forward and look at this chapter of history, that the parliamentary review be done and that the committee be both balanced and impartial in its deliberations,” said Government House Leader Mark Holland during debate in the House on Monday.
“And I think what we have put forward demonstrates exactly those principles, and it’s time we get to work on that committee.”
The Tories rejected the proposal, arguing that traditionally, oversight committees are chaired by a member of the Official Opposition. They said that a Conservative senator should co-chair the committee with a Liberal MP, putting forward an amendment to that effect that failed in the House on Wednesday.
“It should stand to reason that there should be a member of Her Majesty’s Official Opposition as a chair of that committee because it is designed to provide extraordinary oversight,” Conservative House Leader John Brassard said Monday.
The Conservatives also accused the government of giving itself a “working majority” on the committee, given that the NDP voted with the Liberals to confirm the declaration of emergency .
The act requires the committee to deliver its report within seven sitting days after the declaration is revoked, which was last Wednesday. The House and Senate are off for two weeks after Friday, making March 22 the committee’s likely deadline.
The government’s motion says the parties in the House must identify their respective committee members by Thursday, and the Senate must also vote on a similar motion that would allow a member from each of the four Senate groups to sit on the committee.
A statement from the office of government representative Sen. Marc Gold said earlier this week that should the motion pass in the House, “the Senate will be called upon to do the same with expediency.”
Given the bickering over the committee, Sen. Scott Tannas, leader of the Canadian Senators Group (CSG), proposed on Wednesday that the upper chamber also strike its own, Senate-only committee to review the government’s use of the Emergencies Act and deliver an interim report no later than June 15.
A debate on Tannas’s proposal will happen at a later date.
“The CSG is concerned about the proposed process for reviewing the government’s decision to invoke the Emergencies Act,” Tannas said in a statement Wednesday. “We are confident that such a politically charged subject would benefit from a substantive investigation, freer from partisan considerations.”
As required by the act, the government also has to call an inquiry into the circumstances that led to the declaration of emergency, within 60 days of the declaration being revoked. The inquiry’s report must then be tabled in a year.
With files from Althia Raj
Jacques Gallant is a Toronto-based reporter covering politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @JacquesGallant

Green party focuses on mental health in Ontario election platform

Publication info: Mar 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/green-party-focuses-on-mental-health-ontario/docview/2635266907/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Green+party+focuses+on+mental+health+in+Ontario+election+platform&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Forget scrapping licence plate fees and losing $1.1 billion a year from the provincial treasury — that money should be spent on mental health, says the Green Party of Ontario.
In an election campaign platform that specifically addresses pandemic anxiety, the Greens are promising to cut wait times for children’s services, create a three-digit hotline for mental distress and even boost stress-busting help through more trails and parks.
The cost, at $6.6 billion over four years, would be largely funded by reinstating licence plate sticker fees — which Premier Doug Ford recently did away with — Green Leader Mike Schreiner told the Star in an exclusive interview in advance of Thursday’s platform release.
“I guess the bottom line for me is, everything is not OK when it comes to mental health,” Schreiner said.
“People were experiencing significant wait times and lack of access to services pre-pandemic, but things have gotten much worse over the past two years during the pandemic,” he said, with about half of Ontarians saying their mental health has worsened during the pandemic and many not being able to find the help they need.
Schreiner believes his party is the first to put out a stand-alone platform on mental health and addictions, which will form a large part of its campaign promises for the upcoming June 2 election.
Prior to the pandemic, Children’s Mental Health Ontario had reported 28,000 children on wait lists of up to 2.5 years for mental health services, and Schreiner said even accessing a therapist can take more than 67 days, and up to 92 days for more intensive treatments.
“If you went to an emergency room with a broken arm, and were told ‘Yes, we can fix that but it’s going to take 92 days,’ that would just be completely unacceptable and ridiculous,” he said. “So why is that the case with mental health services, especially when so many people are saying mental health is health?”
During the last election campaign, the Progressive Conservatives pledged $3.8 billion over 10 years for mental health. The Ford government has spent additional millions for mental health supports in education, much of it pandemic-related, and has an associate minister of mental health and addictions, Michael Tibollo, who Schreiner said has been listening to the needs of Ontarians.
Schreiner said a Green government would make mental health spending about 10 per cent of the provincial budget, with an immediate eight per cent increase for community health services.
“This is the real implications of taking $1.1 billion out of the provincial budget,” he said of the end of licence plate sticker fees. “That’s $6.6 billion over four years for mental health and addictions — $4.4 billion of that coming from the lost revenue from licence stickers. The rest is from the federal government fulfilling promises they made in the budget and their election platform.”
He said there’s a clear tie-in to communities and the environment, and that increasing access to “nature, parks, trails, green space — making investments in protecting green space, but also expanding things we have like parks, and trail networks, and community centres, youth wellness hubs” are proactive measures that will help people and, down the line, save money.
The Green plan for mental health and addictions would expand care under OHIP, as well as create a three-digit “crisis response” phone line” with specially trained staff, while also providing more training to Telehealth Ontario’s staff.
It also promises to reduce wait lists for children to 30 days or less, while also providing more help to Indigenous-led clinics and healing programs and would also declare the opiod crisis a public health emergency to free up more funds.
The Green party also supports decriminalizing drug use and creating more safe consumption sites.
“Our vision is to transform mental health care in Ontario to ensure people requiring care receive the services they need when and where they need them from a system that is affordable, accessible, comprehensive, and easy to navigate,” the Green platform says.
“Ontario Greens know that if we are hampered by high costs and inaccessible mental health care services, people and communities pay the price. The pandemic and the challenges of a changing climate are putting a strain on our mental health.”
Kristin Rushowy is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @krushowy

Mental health tops Green platform: Ontario party targets pandemic anxiety, vowing to cut wait times for children, create hotline

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.11.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/mental-health-tops-green-platform-ontario-party/docview/2635182254/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Mental+health+tops+Green+platform%3A+Ontario+party+targets+pandemic+anxiety%2C+vowing+to+cut+wait+times+for+children%2C+create+hotline%3A+Ontario+party+targets+pandemic+anxiety%2C+vowing+to+cut+wait+times+for+children%2C+create+hotline&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.11&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Forget scrapping licence plate fees and losing $1.1 billion a year from the provincial treasury - that money should be spent on mental health, says the Green Party of Ontario.
In an election campaign platform that specifically addresses pandemic anxiety, the Greens are promising to cut wait times for children's services, create a three-digit hotline for mental distress and even boost stress-busting help through more trails and parks.
The cost, at $6.6 billion over four years, would be largely funded by reinstating licence plate sticker fees - which Premier Doug Ford recently did away with - Green Leader Mike Schreiner told the Star in an exclusive interview in advance of Thursday's platform release.
"I guess the bottom line for me is, everything is not OK when it comes to mental health," Schreiner said.
"People were experiencing significant wait times and lack of access to services pre-pandemic, but things have gotten much worse over the past two years during the pandemic," he said, with about half of Ontarians saying their mental health has worsened during the pandemic and many not being able to find the help they need.
Schreiner believes his party is the first to put out a stand-alone platform on mental health and addictions, which will form a large part of its campaign promises for the upcoming June 2 election.
Before the pandemic, Children's Mental Health Ontario had reported 28,000 children on wait-lists of up to 21/2 years for mental health services, and Schreiner said even accessing a therapist can take more than 67 days, and up to 92 days for more intensive treatments.
"If you went to an emergency room with a broken arm, and were told 'Yes, we can fix that but it's going to take 92 days,' that would just be completely unacceptable and ridiculous," he said.
"So why is that the case with mental health services, especially when so many people are saying mental health is health?"
During the last election campaign, the Progressive Conservatives pledged $3.8 billion over 10 years for mental health.
The Ford government has spent additional millions for mental health supports in education, much of it pandemic-related, and has an associate minister of mental health and addictions, Michael Tibollo, who Schreiner said has been listening to the needs of Ontarians.
Schreiner said a Green government would make mental health spending about 10 per cent of the provincial budget, with an immediate eight per cent increase for community health services.
"This is the real implications of taking $1.1 billion out of the provincial budget," he said of the end of licence plate sticker fees.
"That's $6.6 billion over four years for mental health and addictions - $4.4 billion of that coming from the lost revenue from licence stickers. The rest is from the federal government fulfilling promises they made in the budget and their election platform."
He said there's a clear tie-in to communities and the environment, and that increasing access to "nature, parks, trails, green space - making investments in protecting green space, but also expanding things we have like parks, and trail networks, and community centres, youth wellness hubs" are proactive measures that will help people and, down the line, save money.
The Green plan for mental health and addictions would expand care under OHIP, as well as create a three-digit "crisis response" phone line" with specially trained staff, while also providing more training to Telehealth Ontario's staff.
It also promises to reduce wait lists for children to 30 days or less, while also providing more help to Indigenous-led clinics and healing programs and would also declare the opiod crisis a public health emergency to free up more funds.
The Green party also supports decriminalizing drug use and creating more safe consumption sites.
"Our vision is to transform mental health care in Ontario to ensure people requiring care receive the services they need when and where they need them from a system that is affordable, accessible, comprehensive, and easy to navigate," the Green platform says.
"Ontario Greens know that if we are hampered by high costs and inaccessible mental health care services, people and communities pay the price. The pandemic and the challenges of a changing climate are putting a strain on our mental health."
CAPTION: Guelph MPP Mike Schreiner is the only member of the Green party in the Ontario legislature.R.J. Johnston Toronto Star file photo
CREDIT: Kristin Rushowy Queen's Park Bureau
