Jean Charest mulls foray into Tory leadership race

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.12.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/jean-charest-mulls-foray-into-tory-leadership/docview/2635182061/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Jean+Charest+mulls+foray+into+Tory+leadership+race&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Longtime Quebec politician Jean Charest was greeted with hugs and applause late Wednesday in what was his first public foray into the leadership race for the federal Conservative party.
The stakes are high for the former federal Progressive Conservative leader, already being slammed as a Liberal by other federal Tories.
But Charest was jovial when asked on his way into the small reception - held in the aptly-named Quebec room of the famous Chateau Laurier hotel - whether he was going to run.
"Where to?" he joked.
In earnest, Charest said he was waiting for the rules of the race itself to be revealed before making a decision.
The party released a few details late Wednesday: The new leader will be selected by Sept. 10, and candidates will have until June 3 to sign up new members.
That deadline is key, sources close to Charest had said earlier, as it will help them decide whether they can sign up enough people in time to be able to win.
Charest said there is one thing he knows already.
"One thing that I believe to be very important is to have a national Conservative party that is able to represent every part of Canada," he said.
"It's really our responsibility to be that national political party."
Charest said the rules will tell him whether a campaign is viable - will he have enough time to sign up members is a key point, his team told the Star.
Charest's campaign already has the support of a number of Quebec MPs, but lawmakers from Nova Scotia, Ontario and Alberta were among those in the crowd.
He said he was there to hear from them about their concerns, and many said they were there to hear Charest's ideas.
Calgary MP Greg McLean said while some might knock Charest's progressive credentials, it's not a bad thing.
"It is something he brings to the table that is laudable," McLean said.
CAPTION: Jean Charest said he's waiting for the rules of the Tory leadership race to be revealed before making an official decision.
CREDIT: Stephanie Levitz Toronto Star

Zelenskyy asks Canada to up sanctions: UN demands Russia withdraw from Ukrainian territory

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.5.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/zelenskyy-asks-canada-up-sanctions-un-demands/docview/2635182007/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Zelenskyy+asks+Canada+to+up+sanctions%3A+UN+demands+Russia+withdraw+from+Ukrainian+territory%3A+UN+demands+Russia+withdraw+from+Ukrainian+territory&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.5&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Hours after the United Nations sided with Ukraine and demanded Russia withdraw from its territory, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy hailed the vote and appealed to Canada for more sanctions and "restrictive measures" to halt the bombardment of his country.
Zelenskyy, who is hunkered in Kyiv as Russian troops advance on the capital, took to Twitter to praise the UN's backing and then to say he had talked to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and "thanked him for the leadership in imposing anti-Russian sanctions."
He said he also "stressed the need to expand restrictive measures. The bombing of civilians in Ukraine must be stopped immediately," said Zelenskyy.
Zelenskyy has pleaded in vain with European leaders to create a no-fly zone over his country - a move NATO countries including Canada have rejected as one that would escalate to an all-out war with nuclear-armed Russia.
But the embattled Ukrainian leader welcomed the powerful show of support from the UN General Assembly, which voted 141-5 to condemn Russia's invasion and demanded Russia "immediately, completely and unconditionally withdraw all of its military forces from the territory of Ukraine within its internationally recognized borders."
Zelenskyy called it "unprecedented" and "a strong demand to Russia to immediately stop the treacherous attack." He said he was grateful to "everyone and every state that voted in favour. You have chosen the right side of history."
The Ukrainian president tweeted about his evening phone call with Trudeau - which took place around 10:30 p.m. Kyiv time.
Later, a senior Canadian government official said Zelenskyy pressed for more sanctions and more rapid implementation of those already announced, including the ban on major Russian banks dealing with the SWIFT international transaction system.
The SWIFT system is based in Brussels, and some European countries are still reluctant to include certain Russian banks that process their payments for Russian energy supplies.
To date, Canada has levied punitive sanctions alongside other G7 and NATO allies against Russian President Vladimir Putin, several of his top political lieutenants, including his foreign, finance, defence and justice ministers, Russian lawmakers in the Russian Duma or parliament, along with dozens of Russian oligarchs and their family members who are close to Putin's inner circle, some of whom hold his personal wealth.
Canada has also sent $19 million in lethal arms, including anti-tank weapons, and about $37 million in non-lethal gear, night vision gear, helmets, and body armour. The federal government has also provided more than $150 million in humanitarian assistance since the invasion began, and has fast-tracked study and work permits of Ukrainian nationals already in the pipeline or those who are here and looking to extend their stay.
Conservatives and New Democrats in Canada are pressing Trudeau for more sanctions directly on other Russian oligarchs who hold assets in Canada.
Conservative MP James Bezan used Commons parliamentary privilege, as British MPs have done, to name two individuals without fear of being sued, saying "Canada has yet to sanction some of his closest friends and advisers."
"Russian oligarch and politician Konstantin Babkin, director of Buhler Industries in Manitoba, said in 2014 that Russia should not stop at Crimea, and, last month, supported Russia's current actions. Putin insider Roman Abramovich, owner of Evraz, which has operations in Western Canada, is supplying steel to build Russian tanks," Bezan said. "When will the prime minister finally sanction Russian oligarchs for supporting Putin's war machine?"
Trudeau replied that Canada is moving in "alignment" with western allies, adding, "We continue to look for more people to sanction. We continue to look for next steps. We will make more steps, but we will do it in a co-ordinated fashion with all allies together, because that is what makes the biggest impact."
Canada's sanctions included the unprecedented move to oust major Russian banks and financial institutions from the SWIFT international transactions system which has jammed many banks - and Russians - from conducting business internationally, as well as a ban on the ability of the Russian central bank to access and use its foreign-denominated reserves to shore up its sagging currency, the ruble.
The Conservatives demand Ottawa evict Russia's ambassador, Oleg Stepanov, and other embassy personnel. All three opposition parties want to allow Ukrainians fleeing the war to have visa-free access to Canada, if they can make it this far.
CAPTION: Signs calling for a free Ukraine are installed on posts along Ottawa's Charlotte Street in front of the Russian Embassy on Wednesday.Justin TangTHE CANADIAN PRESS
CREDIT: Tonda MacCharles Toronto Star

NDP proposes bill to regulate pump prices: Legislation would give Ontario Energy Board power over mark-ups on petroleum products

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.3.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ndp-proposes-bill-regulate-pump-prices/docview/2635181922/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=NDP+proposes+bill+to+regulate+pump+prices%3A+Legislation+would+give+Ontario+Energy+Board+power+over+mark-ups+on+petroleum+products%3A+Legislation+would+give+Ontario+Energy+Board+power+over+mark-ups+on+petroleum+products&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.3&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Gas prices in Ontario are soaring - sitting at $1.60 or higher and set to keep rising - and the Opposition New Democrats are urging regulation of the cost of petroleum, a move the energy minister said wouldn't save drivers money.
The NDP introduced a private member's bill Wednesday on gas price regulation that they have tried to get passed on two previous occasions, saying it would prevent "gouging" at the pumps.
"We have other provinces in this country, other states in the U.S., that are regulating gas prices to make sure that they don't gouge you when a long weekend is coming, and that when you're travelling through, for example, northern Ontario or even through parts of the GTA, you're not seeing a huge discrepancy between gasoline prices," said NDP Leader Andrea Horwath.
"What the bill indicates is that you can't just increase it willy nilly before a long weekend ... So the price would be set, for example, on a Monday, and it would stay in place until the following Monday so that there's certainty about what the gas price is going to be."
The bill from New Democrat Gilles Bisson would give the Ontario Energy Board power to regulate the retail price and wholesale mark-up on petroleum products.
Energy Minister Todd Smith said the OEB has studies showing that regulation wouldn't actually lower gas prices. Instead, he said, gas prices should be lowered by the federal government cancelling a planned increase to the carbon tax.
"If we drop the price of a litre of gas in Ontario, there's nothing to say that the federal government or the gas companies (won't) fill that void," Smith said.
The Ontario government is giving drivers a break by eliminating the $120-a-year fee for licence plate renewal, he said.
But the government doesn't appear to be cutting the provincial fuel tax by 5.7 cents, as promised by Premier Doug Ford as recently as November.
The Progressive Conservatives promised in the 2018 election to cut gas prices by 10 cents. Ending the previous Liberal government's cap-and-trade system was to lower prices by 4.3 cents and the rest would come from lowering the provincial fuel tax.
They did end cap-and-trade, but that meant the federal carbon tax backstop kicked in, negating savings at the pump. Ford's government tried fighting it in court, but lost.
The provincial fuel tax rate remains unchanged from 2018, and the government is now saying it will follow through with that 5.7-cent cut if the federal government matches it.
"The (federal) government should also not go ahead with the planned increase to the carbon tax on April 1 this year, which will add another 2.2 cents a litre," Smith said.
"It doesn't sound like a lot, but that's 11 cents a litre in federal carbon tax. That's not only affecting you at the pumps, but it's affecting the price of the groceries that you buy and everything else that you consume."
Federal Environment Minister Steven Guilbeault told The Canadian Press in an interview that there is no discussion about delaying an increase to the carbon price in April.
"And in fact he knows better, that we're sending the revenues back to households in Ontario of carbon pricing. So this idea that somehow Ontarians are worse off because of carbon pricing is not true."
The high demand for oil combined with a shortage of supply has been pushing oil prices, and consequently, gas prices up for weeks. There is also still much uncertainty around how Russia's invasion of Ukraine will lead to a loss of oil supply.
In response, Industry Minister François-Philippe Champagne told reporters on Parliament Hill on Wednesday that he has asked the Competition Bureau to keep an eye on prices at the pumps and has spoken to companies about boosting domestic production to counteract any possible shortages.
CAPTION: The Ontario NDP introduced a private member's bill Wednesday that aims to prevent "gouging" at the gas pumps.Steve Russell Toronto Star File Photo

Cities need a new deal

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.15.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/cities-need-new-deal/docview/2635181549/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Cities+need+a+new+deal&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.15&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada has an urban crisis.
With that stark warning on Jan. 12, 2002, the Toronto Star launched a sweeping "New Deal for Cities" campaign. Citing the ongoing crises for affordable housing and funding for transit and social welfare systems, the paper urged Canadian cities be given new powers and new respect.
Today, some 20 years later, our cities are still in crisis - their finances in dire straits and their powers weak and ineffective.
Indeed, it's time for another "New Deal for Cities" campaign, one driven by forward-looking politicians, corporate executives and community leaders. That's because for the most part the mayors of our large cities - Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton, Winnipeg, Ottawa, Halifax and others - remain "beggars and whiners" when it comes to dealing with senior governments.
Worse, none of the current leaders of our major federal and provincial parties are talking these days about a renewed or revitalized "urban agenda."
Now is the ideal time to launch a new cities' campaign given that critical elections will be held in our three largest provinces in the coming months. Provincial legislatures hold huge sway over cities, with make-or-break powers that can affect almost every facet of life for urban residents.
A good example of provincial power came in 2018 when newly elected Ontario Premier Doug Ford slashed the size of Toronto City Council in half - in the midst of an election campaign. He did it as an act of revenge against Mayor John Tory and city councillors - but no one, not even the courts, could stop him.
Back in 2002, the Star kicked off its campaign with a front-page editorial written by then-publisher John Honderich, who died less than a month ago.
"As we begin a new century, we have a stark choice: either manage our cities' future and aspire to greatness, or manage their gradual decline," Honderich wrote. "We opt for greatness."
Honderich argued that any new deal must involve fundamental changes in government structure and finances. He stressed that no longer should large cities be deemed mere "creatures of the provinces," but rather distinct power centres with legitimate needs requiring attention.
The campaign never stopped. Day after day for several years the Star drummed the phrase "New Deal" into the public consciousness. Politicians in Ottawa and provincial capitals slowly started to pay attention. Community movers and shakers came on board, as did the heads of local boards of trade and chambers of commerce.
Gradually, cities from Halifax to Vancouver were granted some new powers, allowing them to think big at times. In Ontario, the province signed into law in 2006 the City of Toronto Act, which allowed the city to impose new taxes, such as the land-transfer tax, and to pass bylaws on local boards.
But the act didn't give Toronto the power to impose income and sales taxes, two measures considered vital in helping to stem the rot.
Sadly, our cities continue to fray. Streets are filled with potholes. Buses and subways are frequently "delayed." Public housing is plagued by years-long waiting lists and crumbling buildings. Park lawns are mowed less often and snow clearance is slow.
Ontario holds its provincial election on June 2. The Quebec election is on Oct. 3 and the Alberta vote will be held early next year.
In each of these coming elections, the future of our cities is an issue that can galvanize urban support. That's particularly true in Ontario where Liberal leader Steven Del Duca and NDP leader Andrea Horwath are searching for a powerful issue that clearly defines their party's campaign.
Back in 2002, Honderich asked in the front-page editorial: "Who stands up for Toronto? Where are the voices? Where are those elected to represent us?"
Those words are as true today as they were 20 years ago: Where are they?
Bob Hepburn is a Star politics columnist based in Toronto. Twitter: @BobHepburn
CAPTION: Hundreds gathered in 2018 to protest Premier Doug Ford's plan to cut the size of Toronto City Council.Steve Russell Toronto Star file photo
CREDIT: Bob Hepburn Toronto Star OPINION;

Ford foe mulls federal Tory leadership bid: Baber was ejected from PCs last year for questioning lockdowns

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 03 Mar 2022: A.12.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ford-foe-mulls-federal-tory-leadership-bid-baber/docview/2635181491/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ford+foe+mulls+federal+Tory+leadership+bid%3A+Baber+was+ejected+from+PCs+last+year+for+questioning+lockdowns%3A+Baber+was+ejected+from+PCs+last+year+for+questioning+lockdowns&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A maverick Toronto MPP ejected from Premier Doug Ford's caucus for questioning pandemic lockdowns is considering a bid for the federal Conservative leadership.
Roman Baber, the Independent York Centre MPP kicked out of the provincial Progressive Conservatives last year, said Wednesday he has "been receiving some calls encouraging me to run."
"I've also made some phone calls trying to determine the level of support and a lot of folks have been supportive," he told the Star.
Baber gained a national profile in January 2021 after Ford defenestrated him over a two-page open letter that maintained COVID-19 lockdowns, despite evidence of their public health benefits and widespread public support, were ineffective and caused more mental-health harm than public-health good.
"The medicine is killing the patient," the lawyer wrote at the time, noting the rise in suicides and opioid overdoses, among other apparent lockdown side effects.
Ford insisted that was an "irresponsible" stance, undermining the government's pandemic plan.
Baber - who is vaccinated but believes vaccines should be voluntary and is pushing "jobs and jabs" legislation Thursday to reinstate workers fired for not having their shots - said he has been heartened by the response from federal Tories.
"I think the party is looking for principled leadership and is looking for someone who stands up for what they believe in," he said, adding he backed centrist Peter MacKay in the 2021 CPC contest won by Erin O'Toole, who was dumped by the federal caucus last month.
"Like most Canadians, I'm right-of-centre fiscally and slightly left-of-centre socially," said the first-term MPP, whose family fled the former Soviet Union for Israel when he was nine years old. He arrived in Canada at 15.
"I'm Exhibit A for Canadian opportunity. I was lucky enough to get elected to represent the very same electoral district that welcomed me as an immigrant (26 years ago)."
Baber, who also opposed as "ineffective" the mandatory vaccine passport phased out in Ontario on Tuesday, said he would study the forthcoming federal Tory contest rules before making a final decision soon.
The rules - including the entry fee, deadline date to sign up new members and the date of the vote - are expected to be released as early as this Friday after the party's national council has signed off.
With files from Stephanie Levitz
CAPTION: Roman Baber said he would study the forthcoming federal Tory contest rules before making a final decision.
CREDIT: Robert Benzie Queen's Park Bureau Chief With files from Stephanie Levitz

With his law on the gig economy, Doug Ford is wooing working class voters

Publication info: Mar 1, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/with-his-law-on-gig-economy-doug-ford-is-wooing/docview/2635057504/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=With+his+law+on+the+gig+economy%2C+Doug+Ford+is+wooing+working+class+voters&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: With the June 2 Ontario election less than 100 days away, Premier Doug Ford was out again this week wooing working-class voters.
His recent transformation in this regard raises something of a dilemma. Is a political leader to be cheered or disdained if he’s doing praiseworthy things primarily for reasons of self-interest?
On the face of it, who could gainsay the Ford government’s proposed legislation to set a minimum wage of $15 an hour for workers in the so-called gig economy, to establish clarity of hours, protect against arbitrary dismissal, and safeguard tips?
As the Star’s Sara Mojtehedzadeh has diligently reported , workers in the growing gig sector have been sorely treated and inadequately compensated for their labours.
Working for app companies, deemed independent contractors rather than employees, such workers have lacked job security, benefits, and in many cases even reliable work schedules.
While the law introduced by Ford’s labour minister, Monte McNaughton would not address the employment status of gig workers, and applies only to hours spent “actively” driving customers or products, it does aim to establish a set of foundational rights, Mojtehedzadeh reported.
Still, the Ford government’s apparent conversion leaves labour economists, among others, more than a little suspicious.
In 2018, the government rolled back planned minimum-wage increases, eliminated paid sick days and equal pay for equal work.
That was then. Now, Ford has appointed himself champion of working men and women.
On Monday, he reviewed some of the pocketbook measures he has recently announced. He’s cutting the $120 licence sticker fee. He’s cutting tolls on Highways 412 and 418. Earlier, to the applause of union leaders, he raised the minimum wage to $15.
“Our government listens to workers,” he crowed. “We aren’t leaving any workers behind, absolutely no one.”
All of this prompted one reporter to ask this week if Ford had somehow found his inner liberal.
Well, the premier replied, “my kids call me a bleeding heart.”
Perhaps. But on an initiative so driven by timing, the premier’s may have been less than ideal.
David Doorey, an industrial relations professor at York University, said a decision issued by a labour ministry employment standards officer just days before Ford’s announcement may have actually blown it out of the water.
The decision, which found Uber Eats had violated the Employment Standards Act, deemed a Toronto Uber Eats driver an “employee” for the purposes of the act and said its protections apply.
Moreover, the decision said that “deemed working hours include time spent waiting or holding oneself ready to work.”
If that’s the case, Doorey argued, the proposed Ontario law would actually reduce protections for gig workers, not improve them.
Uber has said it plans to appeal the decision to the Ontario Labour Relations Board.
Ford, of course, is playing to a different market and timeline as his government nears election day.
As a political tactic, it is an understandable move.
The strategy goes back 40 years or so to the suburban fringe around Detroit, when the phenomenon of “Reagan Democrats” was first identified in Michigan’s Macomb County.
Blue-collar workers were — in large part for social and cultural reasons — voting Republican, feeling the Democrats they had traditionally supported had abandoned them.
That trend has continued in various ways across North America. And the premier is offering them a home in his Progressive Conservative party.
Even if he likely wouldn’t have known Woody Guthrie from Sam Walton.

Bob Hepburn: Needed: A new campaign for a New Deal for Cities

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/bob-hepburn-needed-new-campaign-deal-cities/docview/2634870844/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Bob+Hepburn%3A+Needed%3A+A+new+campaign+for+a+New+Deal+for+Cities&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada has an urban crisis.
With that stark warning on Jan. 12, 2002, the Toronto Star launched a sweeping “New Deal for Cities” campaign. Citing the ongoing crises for affordable housing and funding for transit and social welfare systems, the paper urged Canadian cities be given new powers and new respect.
Today, some 20 years later, our cities are still in crisis — their finances in dire straits and their powers weak and ineffective.
Indeed, it’s time for another “New Deal for Cities” campaign, one driven by forward-looking politicians, corporate executives and community leaders.
That’s because for the most part the mayors of our large cities — Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton, Winnipeg, Ottawa, Halifax and others — remain “beggars and whiners” when it comes to dealing with senior governments.
Worse, none of the current leaders of our major federal and provincial parties are talking these days about a renewed or revitalized “urban agenda.”
Now is the ideal time to launch a new cities’ campaign given that critical elections will be held in our three largest provinces in the coming months. Provincial legislatures hold huge sway over cities, with make-or-break powers that can affect almost every facet of life for urban residents.
A good example of provincial power came in 2018 when newly elected Ontario Premier Doug Ford slashed the size of Toronto City Council in half — in the midst of an election campaign. He did it as an act of revenge against Mayor John Tory and city councillors — but no one, not even the courts, could stop him.
Back in 2002, the Star kicked off its campaign with a front-page editorial written by then-publisher John Honderich, who died less than a month ago.
“As we begin a new century, we have a stark choice: either manage our cities’ future and aspire to greatness, or manage their gradual decline,” Honderich wrote. “We opt for greatness.”
Honderich argued that any new deal must involve fundamental changes in government structure and finances. He stressed that no longer should large cities be deemed mere “creatures of the provinces,” but rather distinct power centres with legitimate needs requiring attention.
The campaign never stopped. Day after day for several years the Star drummed the phrase “New Deal” into the public consciousness. Politicians in Ottawa and provincial capitals slowly started to pay attention. Community movers and shakers came on board, as did the heads of local boards of trade and chambers of commerce.
Gradually, cities from Halifax to Vancouver were granted some new powers, allowing them to think big at times. In Ontario, the province signed into law in 2006 the City of Toronto Act, which allowed the city to impose new taxes, such as the land-transfer tax, and to pass bylaws on local boards.
But the act didn’t give Toronto the power to impose income and sales taxes, two measures considered vital in helping to stem the rot.
Sadly, our cities continue to fray. Streets are filled with potholes. Buses and subways are frequently “delayed.” Public housing is plagued by years-long waiting lists and crumbling buildings. Park lawns are mowed less often and snow clearance is slow.
Ontario holds its provincial election on June 2. The Quebec election is on Oct. 3 and the Alberta vote will be held early next year.
In each of these coming elections, the future of our cities is an issue that can galvanize urban support. That’s particularly true in Ontario where Liberal leader Steven Del Duca and NDP leader Andrea Horwath are searching for a powerful issue that clearly defines their party’s campaign.
Back in 2002, Honderich asked in the front-page editorial: “Who stands up for Toronto? Where are the voices? Where are those elected to represent us?”
Those words are as true today as they were 20 years ago: Where are they?
Bob Hepburn is a Star politics columnist based in Toronto. Twitter: @BobHepburn

CAPTION: Hundreds gathered outside Toronto City Hall in 2018 to protest Premier Doug Ford's plan to cut the size of Toronto City Council down to 25 seats from the 47 seats.
CREDIT: Bob Hepburn;

Althia Raj: Pierre Poilievre offers right-wing populism to the Conservatives. Will they take him up on it?

Publication info: Mar 1, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/althia-raj-pierre-poilievre-offers-right-wing/docview/2634869936/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Althia+Raj%3A+Pierre+Poilievre+offers+right-wing+populism+to+the+Conservatives.+Will+they+take+him+up+on+it%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada’s Conservative party is changing. The question is whether it goes down a right-wing populist path — as Republicans south of the border have with Donald Trump — or whether it takes a centrist approach to appeal to a wider audience. In many ways, that question reveals the cracks in the nearly 20-year-old marriage of convenience between the Progressive Conservatives and the Canadian Alliance, one that risks ending up in a nasty divorce.
The only declared candidate, Carleton MP Pierre Poilievre, is a polarizing figure with a “take no prisoners” attitude. He recently called Europe’s response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine shockingly “ weak ,” embraced the so-called “Freedom Convoy,” and called COVID-19 public health measures a purposeful attempt by governments “ to try and take away our freedom and give themselves more power .”
In the past, Poilievre has attacked the media, made derogatory comments about Indigenous peoples , left the door open to a niqab ban in the public service , and broken the election law . Elected at age 25, the career MP is a forceful opposition critic who has railed against elites , placed the blame for rising inflation and house prices at the feet of the Liberals, and promised more energy projects. His campaign launch through a social media video on Feb. 5 garnered more than seven million views on Twitter, Facebook and YouTube. At least 26 Conservative caucus members have endorsed him.
Those who haven’t hope for a more mature candidate with a unifying message.
That’s what former Quebec premier Jean Charest, Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown and political commentator Tasha Kheiriddin want to offer. All three are current outsiders, and all hail from the Progressive Conservative side of the party.
Charest started his political career in 1984 under prime minister Brian Mulroney. He will meet with Conservative MPs — most of whom know little about him — on Wednesday in Ottawa. On Monday, Quebec’s anti-corruption unit (UPAC) ended its eight-year probe into allegations the Quebec Liberal party engaged in illegal financing when Charest was at the helm. It’s a welcome gift that clears the way for his candidacy.
Not that it will be a walk in the park. Jenni Byrne, Poilievre’s strategist, laid out the attacks against Charest on Twitter , describing him as a “Liberal who campaigned against [prime minister] Stephen Harper,” “ supported the long-gun registry , raised taxes, brought in a carbon tax & worked for Huawei while the Chinese Govt detained kidnapped Canadians.” Her offensive led to an ugly public dispute on Sunday with Charest organizer and Tory MP Alain Rayes .
Brown, a vocal opponent of Quebec’s Bill 21, was a Conservative MP from 2006 until 2015, when he became leader of the Ontario PCs. Before resigning over allegations of sexual misconduct, which he strenuously denies, he sought to expand the Ontario party’s tent by supporting carbon pricing and reaching out to ethnic communities.
Kheiriddin has never held elected office, but she is well known, bilingual, and has no baggage.
Their decisions about whether to enter the leadership contest depend on the rules of the game — which could be announced as early as Wednesday. Poilievre’s camp wants a June vote and a membership cut-off of mid-May, sources said, giving any opponents little time to organize. His challengers would benefit from a longer race, with more time to sell memberships to newcomers and more time to be heard by existing members.
Charest and Brown will likely need to change the current makeup of the party — around 200,000 members — if they are to succeed. The Tories pick leaders through a weighted ranked ballot, in which every riding with more than 100 members is worth 100 points. Unless Poilievre were to win a majority on the first round, a race that includes Charest, Brown and Kheiriddin could see any of them benefit from each other’s supporters.
Poilievre is already courting down-ballot support from social conservative favourite Leslyn Lewis, the Conservative MP for Haldimand—Norfolk. Independent York Centre MPP Roman Baber , a staunch opponent of COVID-19 restrictions, is also contemplating a run.
Back in 2017, Andrew Scheer was elected leader as the compromise candidate, supported by social conservatives, Quebec dairy farmers and members who didn’t trust Maxime Bernier. In 2020, Erin O’Toole was also the compromise candidate, acceptable to social conservatives, and less centrist than Peter MacKay. In 2022, Poilievre is modelling himself as that candidate. But it’s unclear that the parts of the party he’s already alienated — namely the Quebec branch and those uncomfortable with his courtship of People’s Party supporters — will be willing to unite behind him once this race is over.
In choosing a leader, the Conservatives must ask themselves what their winning formula will be —do they want to take votes from Bernier’s far-right party or from Justin Trudeau’s Liberals?
Althia Raj is an Ottawa-based national politics columnist for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @althiaraj

Ukraine's president asks Canada for more anti-Russian sanctions and 'restrictive' measures

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/ukraines-president-asks-canada-more-anti-russian/docview/2634867221/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ukraine%27s+president+asks+Canada+for+more+anti-Russian+sanctions+and+%27restrictive%27+measures&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA—Hours after the United Nations sided with Ukraine and demanded Russia withdraw from its territory, Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy hailed the vote and appealed to Canada for more sanctions and “restrictive measures” to halt the bombardment of his country.
Zelenskyy, who is hunkered in Kyiv as Russian troops advance on the capital, took to Twitter to praise the UN’s backing and then to say he had talked to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, and “thanked him for the leadership in imposing anti-Russian sanctions.”
He said he also “stressed the need to expand restrictive measures. The bombing of civilians in Ukraine must be stopped immediately,” said Zelenskyy.
Zelenskyy has pleaded in vain with European leaders to create a no-fly zone over his country — a move NATO countries including Canada have rejected as one that would escalate to an all-out war with nuclear-armed Russia.
But the embattled Ukrainian leader welcomed the powerful show of support from the UN General Assembly which voted 141-5 to condemn Russia’s invasion and demanded Russia “immediately, completely and unconditionally withdraw all of its military forces from the territory of Ukraine within its internationally recognized borders.”
Zelenskyy called it “unprecedented” and “a strong demand to Russia to immediately stop the treacherous attack.” He said he was grateful to “everyone and every state that voted in favour. You have chosen the right side of history.”
The Ukrainian president tweeted about his evening phone call with Trudeau — which took place around 10:30 p.m. Kyiv time.
Later a senior Canadian government official said Zelenskyy pressed for more sanctions and more rapid implementation of those already announced, including the ban on major Russian banks dealing with the SWIFT international transaction system.
The SWIFT system is based in Brussels, and some European countries are still reluctant to include certain Russian banks that process their payments for Russian energy supplies.
To date, Canada has levied punitive sanctions alongside other G7 and NATO allies against Russian President Vladimir Putin, several of his top political lieutenants, including his foreign, finance, defence and justice ministers, Russian lawmakers in the Russian Duma or parliament, along with dozens of Russian oligarchs and their family members who are close to Putin’s inner circle, some of whom hold his personal wealth.
Canada has also sent $19 million in lethal arms including anti-tank weapons, and about $37 million in non-lethal gear night vision gear, helmets, and body armour; more than $150 million in humanitarian assistance since the invasion began, and has fast-tracked study and work permits of Ukrainian nationals already in the pipeline or those who are here and looking to extend their stay.
Conservatives and New Democrats in Canada are pressing Trudeau for more sanctions directly on other Russian oligarchs who hold assets in Canada.
Conservative MP James Bezan used Commons parliamentary privilege, as British MPs have done, to name two individuals without fear of being sued, saying “Canada has yet to sanction some of his closest friends and advisers.”
“Russian oligarch and politician Konstantin Babkin, director of Buhler Industries in Manitoba, said in 2014 that Russia should not stop at Crimea, and, last month, supported Russia’s current actions. Putin insider Roman Abramovich, owner of Evraz, which has operations in Western Canada, is supplying steel to build Russian tanks,” Bezan said. “When will the prime minister finally sanction Russian oligarchs for supporting Putin’s war machine?”
Trudeau replied that Canada is moving in “alignment” with Western allies, adding, “We continue to look for more people to sanction. We continue to look for next steps. We will make more steps, but we will do it in a co-ordinated fashion with all allies together, because that is what makes the biggest impact.”
Canada’s sanctions included the unprecedented move to oust several major Russian banks and financial institutions from the international transactions system known as SWIFT which has jammed many banks — and Russians — from transacting business internationally, as well as a ban on the ability of the Russian Central Bank to access and use its foreign-denominated reserves to shore up its sagging currency, the ruble.
The Conservatives demand Ottawa evict Russia’s ambassador Oleg Stepanov and other embassy personnel. All three opposition parties want to allow Ukrainians fleeing the war to have visa-free access to Canada, if they can make it this far.
Trudeau told the Commons Wednesday his government continues to look at “all different ways that we can make positive impacts in the lives of Ukrainians, and in ending this.”
The federal government sent conflicting signals Wednesday about whether it would compensate Canadian companies or industries hurt by sanctions imposed on Russians or Russian companies.
Earlier in the day, Trudeau said sanctions “obviously have a cost at home. That’s how international trade works,” echoing a warning a day earlier by Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland.
Freeland had said Canadians should be prepared for that impact as the cost of fighting for democracy and a global rules-based order.
But Trudeau suggested in French that because punitive sanctions are necessary to persuade Putin to reverse his decision to invade Ukraine, the government could try to offset the pain that might be felt here in Canada.
“Yes, there will be industries and people who are going to be affected. We are going to see what we can do to compensate, but we also know that we have friends, partners, allies in Europe who are going to suffer a lot more, and our concern is to be there for each other,” Trudeau said on his way into a national caucus meeting.
Requests for clarification to Trudeau’s and Freeland’s offices were not immediately answered, and an afternoon news conference was abruptly cancelled, rescheduled for Thursday.
However, Industry Minister François-Philippe Champagne downplayed the need for compensation and the extent of Canada’s trade with Russia, saying it represents less than one per cent of Canadian imports and exports.
“Of course, we expect a certain impact on the price of gas” at the pump, Champagne said, because it is tied to global prices “which can fluctuate.”
There will also probably be impacts on wheat and food commodity prices, he said, adding that he has already flagged to the Competition Bureau that price changes in Canada should be based on global market changes.
Overall, Champagne said, the impact for Canada “will probably be very moderate.”
With files from Stephanie Levitz
Tonda MacCharles is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @tondamacc

Doug Ford foe Roman Baber considers federal Conservative leadership bid

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/doug-ford-foe-roman-baber-considers-federal/docview/2634866332/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Doug+Ford+foe+Roman+Baber+considers+federal+Conservative+leadership+bid&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A maverick Toronto MPP ejected from Premier Doug Ford’s caucus for questioning pandemic lockdowns is considering a bid for the federal Conservative leadership.
Roman Baber, the Independent York Centre MPP kicked out of the provincial Progressive Conservatives last year, said Wednesday he has “been receiving some calls encouraging me to run.”
“I’ve also made some phone calls trying to determine the level of support and a lot of folks have been supportive,” he told the Star.
Baber gained a national profile in January 2021 after Ford defenestrated him over a two-page open letter that maintained COVID-19 lockdowns, despite evidence of their public health benefits and widespread public support, were ineffective and caused more mental-health harm than public-health good.
“The medicine is killing the patient,” the lawyer wrote at the time, noting the rise in suicides and opioid overdoses, among other apparent lockdown side effects.
Ford insisted that was an “irresponsible” stance, undermining the government’s pandemic plan.
Baber — who is vaccinated but believes vaccines should be voluntary and is pushing “jobs and jabs” legislation Thursday to reinstate workers fired for not having their shots — said he has been heartened by the response from federal Tories.
“I think the party is looking for principled leadership and is looking for someone who stands up for what they believe in,” he said, adding he backed centrist Peter MacKay in the 2021 CPC contest won by Erin O’Toole, who was dumped by the federal caucus last month.
“Like most Canadians, I’m right-of-centre fiscally and slightly left-of-centre socially,” said the first-term MPP, whose family fled the former Soviet Union for Israel when he was nine years old. He arrived in Canada at 15.
“I’m Exhibit A for Canadian opportunity. I was lucky enough to get elected to represent the very same electoral district that welcomed me as an immigrant (26 years ago).”
Baber, who also opposed as “ineffective” the mandatory vaccine passport phased out in Ontario on Tuesday, said he would study the forthcoming federal Tory contest rules before making a final decision soon.
The rules — including the entry fee, deadline date to sign up new members and the date of the vote — are expected to be released as early as this Friday after the party’s national council has signed off.
So far, the only declared candidate is Carleton MP Pierre Poilievre , a career politician with significant caucus support. He’s already holding rallies — including one this week in Saskatchewan. His supporters are pushing hard for a swift contest, with a vote as early as June so a new leader would have the summer to get organized.
But some prominent Tories are kicking the tires on a bid, including former Quebec premier Jean Charest, who used to lead the old federal Progressive Conservatives. Charest is hosting a meet-and-greet with MPs in Ottawa late Thursday. His campaign is supported by a number of Quebec Conservatives, including the party’s former Quebec lieutenant Alain Rayes.
Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown, a one-time Ontario PC leader, and conservative strategist Tasha Kheiriddin are also making calls, as is rookie MP Leslyn Lewis, who placed third in the 2020 leadership contest.
With files from Stephanie Levitz
Robert Benzie is the Star’s Queen’s Park bureau chief and a reporter covering Ontario politics. Follow him on Twitter: @robertbenzie

Votes drive pitch to workers

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 02 Mar 2022: A.16.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/votes-drive-pitch-workers/docview/2634760666/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Votes+drive+pitch+to+workers&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.16&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: With the June 2 Ontario election less than 100 days away, Premier Doug Ford was out again this week wooing working-class voters.
His recent transformation in this regard raises something of a dilemma. Is a political leader to be cheered or disdained if he's doing praiseworthy things primarily for reasons of self-interest?
On the face of it, who could gainsay the Ford government's proposed legislation to set a minimum wage of $15 an hour for workers in the so-called gig economy, to establish clarity of hours, protect against arbitrary dismissal, and safeguard tips?
As the Star's Sara Mojtehedzadeh has diligently reported, workers in the growing gig sector have been sorely treated and inadequately compensated for their labours.
Working for app companies, deemed independent contractors rather than employees, such workers have lacked job security, benefits, and in many cases even reliable work schedules.
While the law introduced by Ford's labour minister, Monte McNaughton would not address the employment status of gig workers, and applies only to hours spent "actively" driving customers or products, it does aim to establish a set of foundational rights, Mojtehedzadeh reported.
Still, the Ford government's apparent conversion leaves labour economists, among others, more than a little suspicious.
In 2018, the government rolled back planned minimum-wage increases, eliminated paid sick days and equal pay for equal work.
That was then. Now, Ford has appointed himself champion of working men and women.
On Monday, he reviewed some of the pocketbook measures he has recently announced. He's cutting the $120 licence sticker fee. He's cutting tolls on Highways 412 and 418. Earlier, to the applause of union leaders, he raised the minimum wage to $15.
"Our government listens to workers," he crowed. "We aren't leaving any workers behind, absolutely no one."
All of this prompted one reporter to ask this week if Ford had somehow found his inner liberal.
Well, the premier replied, "my kids call me a bleeding heart."
Perhaps. But on an initiative so driven by timing, the premier's may have been less than ideal.
David Doorey, an industrial relations professor at York University, said a decision issued by a labour ministry employment standards officer just days before Ford's announcement may have actually blown it out of the water.
The decision, which found Uber Eats had violated the Employment Standards Act, deemed a Toronto Uber Eats driver an "employee" for the purposes of the act and said its protections apply.
Moreover, the decision said that "deemed working hours include time spent waiting or holding oneself ready to work."
If that's the case, Doorey argued, the proposed Ontario law would actually reduce protections for gig workers, not improve them.
Uber has said it plans to appeal the decision to the Ontario Labour Relations Board.
Ford, of course, is playing to a different market and timeline as his government nears election day.
As a political tactic, it is an understandable move.
The strategy goes back 40 years or so to the suburban fringe around Detroit, when the phenomenon of "Reagan Democrats" was first identified in Michigan's Macomb County.
Blue-collar workers were - in large part for social and cultural reasons - voting Republican, feeling the Democrats they had traditionally supported had abandoned them.
That trend has continued in various ways across North America. And the premier is offering them a home in his Progressive Conservative party.
Even if he likely wouldn't have known Woody Guthrie from Sam Walton.

Will Tories take up populism?

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 02 Mar 2022: A.10.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/will-tories-take-up-populism/docview/2634760651/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Will+Tories+take+up+populism%3F&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Canada's Conservative party is changing. The question is whether it goes down a right-wing populist path - as Republicans south of the border have with Donald Trump - or whether it takes a centrist approach to appeal to a wider audience. In many ways, that question reveals the cracks in the nearly 20-year-old marriage of convenience between the Progressive Conservatives and the Canadian Alliance, one that risks ending up in a nasty divorce.
The only declared candidate, Carleton MP Pierre Poilievre, is a polarizing figure with a "take no prisoners" attitude. He recently called Europe's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine shockingly "weak," embraced the so-called "Freedom Convoy," and called COVID-19 public health measures a purposeful attempt by governments "to try and take away our freedom and give themselves more power."
In the past, Poilievre has attacked the media, made derogatory comments about Indigenous peoples, left the door open to a niqab ban in the public service and broken the election law. Elected at age 25, the career MP is a forceful opposition critic who has railed against elites, placed the blame for rising inflation and house prices at the feet of the Liberals and promised more energy projects. His campaign launch through a social media video on Feb. 5 garnered more than seven million views on Twitter, Facebook and YouTube. At least 26 Conservative caucus members have endorsed him. Those who haven't hope for a more mature candidate with a unifying message.
That's what former Quebec premier Jean Charest, Brampton Mayor Patrick Brown and political commentator Tasha Kheiriddin want to offer. All three are current outsiders, and all hail from the Progressive Conservative side of the party.
Charest started his political career in 1984 under prime minister Brian Mulroney. He will meet with Conservative MPs - most of whom know little about him - on Wednesday in Ottawa. On Monday, Quebec's anti-corruption unit (UPAC) ended its eight-year probe into allegations the Quebec Liberal party engaged in illegal financing when Charest was at the helm. It's a welcome gift that clears the way for his candidacy.
Not that it will be a walk in the park. Jenni Byrne, Poilievre's strategist, laid out the attacks against Charest on Twitter, describing him as a "Liberal who campaigned against (prime minister) Stephen Harper," "supported the long-gun registry, raised taxes, brought in a carbon tax & worked for Huawei while the Chinese Govt detained kidnapped Canadians." Her offensive led to an ugly public dispute on Sunday with Charest organizer and Tory MP Alain Rayes.
Brown, a vocal opponent of Quebec's Bill 21, was a Conservative MP from 2006 until 2015, when he became leader of the Ontario PCs. Before resigning over allegations of sexual misconduct, which he strenuously denies, he sought to expand the Ontario party's tent by supporting carbon pricing and reaching out to ethnic communities.
Kheiriddin has never held elected office, but she is well known, bilingual, and has no baggage.
Their decisions about whether to enter the leadership contest depend on the rules of the game - which could be announced as early as Wednesday. Poilievre's camp wants a June vote and a membership cut-off of mid-May, sources said, giving any opponents little time to organize. His challengers would benefit from a longer race, with more time to sell memberships to newcomers and more time to be heard by existing members.
Charest and Brown will probably need to change the current makeup of the party - around 200,000 members - if they are to succeed. The Tories pick leaders through a weighted ranked ballot, in which every riding with more than 100 members is worth 100 points. Unless Poilievre were to win a majority in the first round, a race that includes Charest, Brown and Kheiriddin could see any of them benefit from each other's supporters.
Poilievre is already courting down-ballot support from social conservative favourite Leslyn Lewis, the Conservative MP for Haldimand-Norfolk. Independent York Centre MPP Roman Baber, a staunch opponent of COVID-19 restrictions, is also contemplating a run.
Back in 2017, Andrew Scheer was elected leader as the compromise candidate, supported by social conservatives, Quebec dairy farmers and members who didn't trust Maxime Bernier. In 2020, Erin O'Toole was also the compromise candidate, acceptable to social conservatives, and less centrist than Peter MacKay. In 2022, Poilievre is modelling himself as that candidate. But it's unclear that the parts of the party he's already alienated - namely the Quebec branch and those uncomfortable with his courtship of People's Party supporters - will be willing to unite behind him once this race is over.
In choosing a leader, the Conservatives must ask themselves what their winning formula will be -do they want to take votes from Bernier's far-right party or from Justin Trudeau's Liberals?
Twitter: @althiaraj
CAPTION: Like Andrew Scheer and Erin O'Toole before him, Pierre Poilievre is presenting himself as the compromise candidate. But it's unclear that the parts of the Conservative party he's already alienated will be willing to unite behind him once this race is over, Althia Raj writes.Adrian Wyld THE CANADIAN PRESS

Was having a very large City Council really a good idea?

Publication info: Mar 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/was-having-very-large-city-council-really-good/docview/2634760487/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Was+having+a+very+large+City+Council+really+a+good+idea%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ford’s opposition should vow to restore city council, Feb. 26
Sean Micallef makes the suggestion that the opposition parties should have an election plank to restore Toronto to 44 or 47 councillors.
Although I am not totally opposed to having more than the current 25 councillors, plus the Mayor, I would suggest that what was really wrong with Doug Ford’s decision in 2018 was the fact that he made the change without discussion and in the middle of an election campaign.
The result was making a change to one part of an interconnected system without looking at what councillors actually do and the role of Community Councils and Council, itself.
If a change is necessary, it should be made by Toronto, not the Province and should only occur after there has been a deep discussion of what the role of councillors should be and whether there are other and better systems.
The discussion needs to happen before we simply go back to “the good old days.”
These were really not as good as some people remember.
David Crawford, Toronto

Ontario government ads criticized as 'partisan'

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 02 Mar 2022: A.10.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ontario-government-ads-criticized-as-partisan/docview/2634760139/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ontario+government+ads+criticized+as+%27partisan%27&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Premier Doug Ford's government is defending its "Ontario is getting stronger" TV commercial amid charges it's a thinly veiled, feel-good campaign ad at public expense.
With the provincial election coming June 2 - and the official campaign kicking off in two months - the ad that has appeared on the Super Bowl and other prime-time programs is an abuse of taxpayers' money, opposition parties said Tuesday.
And it has the Liberals facing a share of the blame for easing restrictions on government advertising in 2015, eliminating the power of the auditor general's office to veto ads for issues of factual accuracy, tone, context and political partisanship.
"If the previous rules were in place, we'd at least have the auditor reviewing the ads before they go out," Green Leader Mike Schreiner said. "That prevents government from engaging in using public dollars for partisan purposes."
While Ford's Progressive Conservatives campaigned in 2018 on a promise to restore the auditor general's advertising review powers, the premier's office signalled late last year it will not be doing so.
Finance Minister Peter Bethlenfalvy told reporters the upbeat ad that shows blue-collar workers on the job, an electric vehicle being plugged in, public transit lines and highways without traffic jams are meant to convey a "sense of optimism" in the wake of challenging times.
New Democrat Leader Andrea Horwath described the ad as clearly designed to "pump up the government," and said that is "really problematic."
Specific costs for the ad campaign were not disclosed.

Double fares for trips linking to GO Transit nixed

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 02 Mar 2022: A.12.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/double-fares-trips-linking-go-transit-nixed/docview/2634760138/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Double+fares+for+trips+linking+to+GO+Transit+nixed&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.12&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The province is making public transportation more affordable by eliminating fares for trips that connect to GO Transit on most local services across the Greater Golden Horseshoe.
But while the policy will give riders in places like Brampton, Mississauga and Hamilton a break, it won't apply to TTC customers in Toronto.
Associate Transportation Minister Stan Cho announced the policy, which goes into effect March 14, at a bus garage in Mississauga on Tuesday morning.
He said that in addition to the Ontario PC government's recent decisions to eliminate tolls on Highways 412 and 418 in Durham and scrap licence plate sticker renewal fees for drivers, cutting transit fares is another way the province is making it more affordable for Ontarians struggling with rising costs to get around.
"Since Day One, our government has been making it easier for people to get from Point A to Point B," he said, noting that under Premier Doug Ford the province is investing billions in new public transit lines.
"We know that effective transit infrastructure means more than just laying subway track. It must be accessible and that's why today we're cutting the cost of taking transit," Cho said.
The province's announcement means trips connecting to GO Transit will be free on city transit agencies that have co-fare agreements with GO: Durham Region Transit, Milton Transit, Grand River Transit, Guelph Transit, Oakville Transit, MiWay, Brampton Transit, Hamilton Street Railway, Burlington Transit, Bradford West Gwillimbury Transit, York Region Transit and Barrie Transit. Riders transferring between the local services and GO would still have to pay the GO fare.
The province estimates a Mississauga resident who commutes three days a week using MiWay and GO would save about $250 a year as a result of the new co-fare policy.
The cost of the program to the province would depend on the extent to which ridership rebounds from COVID-19, but Metrolinx, the provincial agency that operates GO, has budgeted $1.5 million annually.
In 2020, the Ontario PC government pulled the plug on a popular program introduced by the previous Liberal government that provided discounts of $1.50 for riders transferring between the TTC and GO or the UP Express. The discounted double fare, which cost more than $18 million a year, was pitched by the Liberals as a crucial step in regional fare integration, but the Ontario PCs let its funding expire.
Cho didn't rule out extending the new discount to the TTC, which is by far the largest local transit agency in the region, at some point in the future.
"A project of this size and the changes we're making do take a little bit of time, so the discussions with the TTC will be ongoing. The ultimate goal is to make sure we connect the entire grid," he said.
Ontario Liberal Leader Steven Del Duca, who was transportation minister when the province introduced the TTC-GO discounted double fare in 2018, said Ford's decision to scrap that policy was "reckless." He called Tuesday's announcement a transparent attempt to win votes ahead of the June 2 provincial election.
With just over three months until the vote, "suddenly Doug Ford has seen the light and has decided that he has to make transit more affordable," Del Duca said.
"I think people can see that for what it is. It's electioneering. It's trying to convince people to not remember the brutal mistakes that Doug Ford has made consistently over the past four years."
CREDIT: Ben Spurr Toronto Star

Opposition demands additional aid: Parties back government actions but call on Liberals to drop visa requirement for Ukrainians

Full text: Canada's opposition lawmakers are backing the Liberal governent's response to the crisis in Ukraine - for now. But their calls for further action hint at political fault lines that could crack that united front.
The Conservative interim leader, Candice Bergen, told the Commons during a parliamentary debate Monday night that the Official Opposition "fully supports the actions of the government of Canada taken so far" in response to the Russian invasion.
But Conservatives are demanding additional steps. Those include the expulsion of Russia's ambassador to Canada and the recall of Canada's envoy in Moscow, which the Liberal government has rejected saying it's important to have diplomatic eyes and ears in Moscow in a war fuelled by disinformation.
The Tories want the federal government to "direct" the CRTC to revoke the broadcasting licence of RT, formerly Russia Today (which has been dropped by Rogers, Bell, Telus and Shaw), notwithstanding the independence of Canada's broadcast media regulator. The Trudeau government is asking the CRTC to review the licence.
Bergen called on Trudeau to work to evict Russia from multilateral forums like the G20 and the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe - something Foreign Affairs Minister Mélanie Joly said Monday is under discussion.
Meanwhile, on Tuesday, Joly along with her Danish counterpart led a walkout in Geneva to protest a broadcast of Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov's speech to the UN Human Rights Council.
Joly told reporters it was to protest Lavrov's "false" version of what was happening in Ukraine.
She said Canada on Tuesday would "petition the International Criminal Court of Justice against Russia for crimes against humanity and war crimes."
Canada and global allies have already targeted sanctions at Russian President Vladimir Putin, his inner governing circle, key ministers, Russian parliament members, Putin's allies in nearby Belarus, Russian financial institutions and companies connected to Russian billionaires - the oligarchs and ruling elite who Trudeau said profit from the economic stability and systems that western democracies have built.
Ottawa has also sent lethal and non-lethal military aid, including anti-tank weapons and defensive gear like armoured vests, helmets, and goggles.
The Conservatives, Bloc Québécois and the NDP are calling for Canada to offer visa-free travel to Ukrainians who are fleeing the conflict - a step the Liberal government hasn't yet taken.
Bergen also used the Ukraine crisis to highlight the Conservative party's long-standing criticisms of Liberal policies on defence spending and procurement, a call to update northern warning capabilities, to protect the Arctic, and to build more oil and gas pipelines.
She said when "the Liberals stop, delay and hamstring Canadian oil and gas from being extracted, transported and sold both at home and abroad, the biggest winner in every way, shape and form is Putin."
"We need to get new pipelines built, so that we can sell our energy to Europe and others and end Russia's monopoly on natural gas."
The U.S. has been co-ordinating for weeks with various allies to ensure there are backup energy supplies for Europe during a conflict.
Although Canada has oil and natural gas supplies, it does not yet have liquefied natural gas (LNG) refining capacity. While Canadian LNG could be shipped south via rail, U.S. refineries are already running at full capacity, senior government officials told the Star.
Conservative leadership candidate Pierre Poilievre posted a video using the Ukraine crisis as part of his leadership campaign, saying "as prime minister" he'd quickly approve Canadian oil and gas projects and refineries.
Poilievre lambasted the Trudeau government and said "major" European countries are "cowering" in the face of Putin's aggression. The "weakest" are those that depend on Russian oil and gas.
"Europe is filling Putin's war chest," says Poilievre.
New Democrat Leader Jagmeet Singh called on the Trudeau government to sharply increase its humanitarian aid in addition to lifting visas for Ukrainians.
On Tuesday, the UN issued an urgent appeal for more than $2 billion to urgently deliver humanitarian support to people in Ukraine and refugees in neighbouring countries.
In the past two weeks Canada has approved more than 4,000 applications from Ukrainians who'd already applied to come to or remain in Canada, Immigration Minister Sean Fraser said Monday.
The Bloc Québécois - which up to two weeks ago criticized the Trudeau government for "crying wolf" and "alarmist" rhetoric about Putin's intentions - on Monday supported Canada's response to date, while calling for the lifting of visas, and rejecting the need to build more pipelines.
CREDIT: Tonda MacCharles Toronto Star
