____________________________________________________________

This GO stop was brought to you by ..

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 01 Mar 2022: A.1.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/this-go-stop-was-brought-you/docview/2634384956/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=This+GO+stop+was+brought+to+you+by+..&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Imagine hopping a train from Coca-Cola Exhibition to Tim Hortons Oakville. Or hitching a ride from Scotiabank Whitby to Shoppers Drug Mart Clarkson.
The map of the GO Transit network could soon look a little different, as Metrolinx moves ahead with plans to sell the naming rights for stops on the regional rail service.
In February, the agency issued a request for expressions of interest for a "station naming rights opportunity" at four rail stops - Whitby, Exhibition, Clarkson and Oakville.
The organization says it chose the four stations based on a combination of high ridership and strategic location, but the solicitation, which was posted to Metrolinx's procurement website on Feb. 15, says the agency "will consider proposals for other stations at the request of interested parties."
Metrolinx, the Ontario Crown corporation that oversees GO and the Union-Pearson Express, first proposed selling the rights to name stations in 2019. In a statement attributed to a Metrolinx spokesperson, the agency said the most recent posting is a continuation of that original effort and "part of a strategy to enhance transit and the customer experience by generating new forms of non-fare revenue."
The organization has previously estimated that letting companies put their names on train stations could generate up to $500,000 per station per year. Although it has yet to announce any naming deals, it says there has been ample interest from potential sponsors.
"We are particularly encouraged by these new revenue opportunities as we start to recover from the effects of the pandemic on our ridership," it said.
The agency believes riders won't be confused by any changes to station names because the branded stops would retain their current titles, with the sponsor's name added in front.
No specific types of companies - liquor or cannabis brands, for instance - would be prohibited from making offers for naming rights, but it would be up to Metrolinx whether to negotiate a deal.
A request for information that Metrolinx posted in 2019 listed a fifth station, Pickering, that isn't included in the new solicitation. The 2019 request closed in October 2021. Metrolinx wouldn't say why Pickering has been left out of the new request.
When the Star asked Ontario Transportation Minister Caroline Mulroney for comment on the station rights issue Friday, her spokesperson sent a statement nearly identical to the one provided by Metrolinx, an ostensibly arm's-length agency of the province, with the words "provincial government" exchanged for "Metrolinx."
Mulroney has previously shown support for the naming rights plan, saying in 2019 that it aligned with the Ontario PC government's vision of ensuring the province is "open for business."
On Friday, Ontario Green Party Leader Mike Schreiner criticized the idea of selling the naming rights for publicly funded transit stops, arguing that "governments shouldn't be in the business of supporting corporate interests like this."
"If the Ford government wants to raise funds, they should cancel the $10-billion climate disaster Highway 413 and the $1-billion licence sticker election gimmick and invest those funds towards affordable and accessible transit instead," he said.
Since Metrolinx first proposed selling station rights, COVID-19 has caused a dramatic drop in ridership on transit networks all over the world. Ridership on GO is now at about 24 per cent of pre-pandemic levels, while volumes on the UP Express are at 30 per cent. Fewer people riding could theoretically make the naming rights for stations less attractive to potential sponsors.
However, before the Omicron wave hit last year, ridership had rebounded to about 50 per cent of normal, and Metrolinx is confident ridership will return to normal over the next one to two years.
The organization expects opportunities for private sector partnerships to ramp up as it pursues strategies like transit-oriented development, in which companies agree to build transit infrastructure in exchange for benefits like development rights near the lines.
The request for expressions of interest for naming rights closes at the end of 2022.
CREDIT: Ben Spurr Toronto Star

Subject: Pandemics; COVID-19

Ford revs up rhetoric with election three months away

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 01 Mar 2022: A.10.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/ford-revs-up-rhetoric-with-election-three-months/docview/2634384902/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ford+revs+up+rhetoric+with+election+three+months+away&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Let the campaign begin.
An imminent deal with Ottawa on $10-a-day child care, a good-news budget put off until the eve of the election and a bevy of big-spending announcements as the COVID-19 pandemic appears to be winding down.
With Ontario voters headed to the polls in just three months, Premier Doug Ford is hitting the hustings and revving up the rhetoric.
"On June 2, people are going to have a choice," Ford told reporters Monday at a campaign-style announcement on improving wages and working conditions for gig employees.
"Either (they) want to move forward with making sure that we build roads and bridges and hospitals and schools, putting money back into people's pockets, have the economy going," the premier said, before taking a shot at the Liberal government of former premiers Kathleen Wynne and Dalton McGuinty.
"Or do you want to go back 15 years of the previous government that lost 300,000 jobs in this province, highest hydro rates, red tape and regulations. It was an absolute disaster under the previous government. So people will have a choice."
Beyond the partisan talking points, the Progressive Conservative premier stressed an agreement with the federal Liberal government to deliver $10-a-day child care "is very, very close."
"That's all I can tell you. It's going to get done as sure as we're standing here, but as I said, I'm not going to do a deal just for making a deal," he said.
A senior provincial government official, speaking confidentially in order to discuss the negotiations, said that an accord will be inked well before the June 2 election.
NDP Leader Andrea Horwath said it is "a shame" that Ontario is the only province to not yet sign on.
"It's just not a priority for Doug Ford," Horwath said.
"Meanwhile, people were actually getting cheques in other provinces to rebate the amount of child care that they have paid for between June and the end of the year," she said.
Time is of the essence, because Ontario risks missing out on a year's worth of funding if it waits until Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland's federal budget, which is expected in the spring.
In the legislature, Wynne, the Liberal MPP for Don Valley West, said "every other (provincial and territorial) government has managed to reach a deal before the end of the fiscal year on March 31 so that they could receive the money earmarked for this year."
Last week, Ford amended his own law to move the provincial budget deadline to April 30 from March 31.
That means the budget, which will serve as the Tories' re-election platform, can be delivered days before the official start of the campaign in May.
"I can't say we did it just because of that," the premier insisted of the new Fewer Fees, Better Services Act, which also eliminated licence plate sticker renewal fees of up to $120 annually, which will cost $1 billion a year, and removed tolls from Durham's Highways 412 and 418.
Changing the law he introduced in 2019 means Ford and Finance Minister Peter Bethlenfalvy won't face financial penalties of 10 per cent of their cabinet top-up pay for not meeting a March 31 deadline.
"I paid $10,000 back into the government when we didn't meet the budget time frame before - and so did the previous finance minister (Rod Phillips)," he noted, referring to the $9,200 and $4,900 they repaid the treasury because the pandemic delayed the 2020 budget.
With files from Kristin Rushowy
CREDIT: Robert Benzie Queen's Park Bureau Chief With files from Kristin Rushowy

Subject: Provincial budget; Child care; Pandemics; Roads & highways; COVID-19

Full text: Ford cares little about schools, health care
A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
Let's face the fact that Doug Ford wants to be remembered as the man who put a $1-billion hole in the Ontario budget.
In Ford's Ontario, funding for education and health care are already near the lowest, per capita, in Canada.
One billion dollars of decreased funding will result in a decreased number of staff in our medical system.
Our children will be crowded into even fewer classrooms, and post-secondary education funding will still be ranked as the lowest in Canada.
Reducing the income of our provincial government by $1 billion will not result in better outcomes in our health or educational systems. It will make a name for Ford: the Billion-dollar Man.
Allan Baker, Scarborough
Patients, nurses need help of Ontario's IENs
This initiative is opening doors for hundreds of Ontario's internationally educated nurses, Feb. 13
Chandra Kafle's story is an important reminder that Ontario must recognize the experience of internationally educated nurses (IEN).
There are over 22,000 IENs living in Ontario who are eager to nurse. Their expertise is desperately needed.
It is imperative that the College of Nurses of Ontario (CNO) expedite applications so IENs are not waiting on the sidelines.
Ontario is in the midst of a nursing crisis and expediting the processing of applications is one key solution. It is great to see hospitals such as Sunnybrook supporting IENs.
Nurses on the front lines are exhausted. Patients are suffering. Wait times for procedures and surgeries are catastrophic. Residents in long-term-care homes need more nursing care.
We must enable that all IENs, who are eagerly waiting, can join the nursing workforce more quickly.
Doris Grinspun, Registered Nurses' Association of Ontario (RNAO)
What other sites did Metrolinx examine, reject?
Secretive Metrolinx has it backward, Feb. 24
I am curious to know what other sites Metrolinx examined and rejected, and why?
For example, it would be feasible to expand the railway corridor and lay extra tracks between Dawes and Victoria Park using existing land and expropriating open space from the Shoppers World retail plaza, just east of the Danforth GO station.
Our governments have a history of taking the valuable parklands and ravines and using them for new projects instead of expropriating private property; it is cheaper, perhaps, but, as a result, the Don Valley is a mess criss-crossed by highways and railways and utility corridors with most of its recreational value lost or compromised.
Brian Graff, Toronto
Palestinians are wrongly accused of antisemitism
Letter, Presenting three sentences that teach us about antisemitism, Feb. 24
Anti-Zionism is not antisemitism.
Zionists originally claimed that Israel was a "land with no people for a people with no land," but this was not true.
There were lots of Palestinians there.
So now the Zionists claim to be a "liberation movement."
But they are "liberating" the land from Palestinians who had nothing to with oppressing Jews.
Palestinians, quite rightly, are resisting the Jews' "self-determination" at their expense, and, for this, they are wrongly accused of antisemitism.
Wolfe Erlichman, Godfrey, Ont.

Next stop - Tim Hortons Oakville? Metrolinx on track to sell off naming rights to GO stations

Publication info: Mar 1, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/next-stop-tim-hortons-oakville-metrolinx-on-track/docview/2634384435/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Next+stop+-+Tim+Hortons+Oakville%3F+Metrolinx+on+track+to+sell+off+naming+rights+to+GO+stations&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-03-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Imagine hopping a train from Coca-Cola Exhibition to Tim Hortons Oakville. Or hitching a ride from Scotiabank Whitby to Shoppers Drug Mart Clarkson.
The map of the GO Transit network could soon look a little different, as Metrolinx moves ahead with plans to sell the naming rights for stops on the regional rail service.
In February, the agency issued a request for expressions of interest for a “station naming rights opportunity” at four rail stops — Whitby, Exhibition, Clarkson and Oakville.
The organization says it chose the four stations based on a combination of high ridership and strategic location, but the solicitation, which was posted to Metrolinx’s procurement website on Feb. 15, says the agency “will consider proposals for other stations at the request of interested parties.”
Metrolinx, which is the Ontario Crown corporation that oversees GO and the UP Express, first proposed selling the rights to name stations in 2019 . In a statement attributed to a Metrolinx spokesperson, the agency said the most recent posting is a continuation of that original effort and “part of a strategy to enhance transit and the customer experience by generating new forms of non-fare revenue.”
The organization has previously estimated that letting companies put their names on train stations could generate up to $500,000 per station per year. Although it has yet to announce any naming deals, it says there has been ample interest from potential sponsors.
“We are particularly encouraged by these new revenue opportunities as we start to recover from the effects of the pandemic on our ridership,” it said.
The agency believes riders won’t be confused by any changes to station names because the branded stops would retain their current titles, just with the sponsor’s name added in front.
No specific types of companies — liquor or cannabis brands for instance — would be prohibited from making offers for naming rights, but it would be up to Metrolinx whether to negotiate a deal.
A request for information that Metrolinx posted in 2019 listed a fifth station, Pickering, that isn’t included in the new solicitation. The 2019 request closed in October 2021. Metrolinx wouldn’t say why Pickering has been left out of the new request.
When the Star asked Ontario Transportation Minister Caroline Mulroney for comment on the station rights issue Friday, her spokesperson sent a statement nearly identical to the one provided by Metrolinx, an ostensibly arm’s-length agency of the province, with the words “provincial government” exchanged for “Metrolinx.”
Mulroney has previously shown support for the naming rights plan, saying in 2019 that it aligned with the Ontario PC government’s vision of ensuring the province is “open for business.”
On Friday, Green Party Ontario Leader Mike Schreiner criticized the idea of selling the naming rights for publicly funded transit stops, arguing that “governments shouldn’t be in the business of supporting corporate interests like this.”
“If the Ford government wants to raise funds, they should cancel the $10 billion climate disaster Highway 413 and the $1 billion licence sticker election gimmick and invest those funds towards affordable and accessible transit instead,” he said.
Since Metrolinx first proposed selling station rights, COVID-19 has caused a dramatic drop in ridership on transit networks all over the world. Ridership on GO is now at about 24 per cent of pre-pandemic levels, while volumes on the UP Express are at 30 per cent. Fewer people riding could theoretically make the naming rights for stations less attractive to potential sponsors.
However, before the Omicron wave hit last year ridership had rebounded to about 50 per cent of normal, and Metrolinx is confident ridership will return to normal over the next one to two years.
The organization expects opportunities for private sector partnerships to ramp up as it pursues strategies like transit-oriented development , in which companies agree to build transit infrastructure in exchange for benefits like development rights near the lines.
The request for expressions of interest for naming rights closes at the end of 2022.
Ben Spurr is a Toronto-based reporter covering transportation for the Star. Reach him by email at bspurr@thestar.ca or follow him on Twitter: @BenSpurr

CAPTION: Metrolinx has said it is looking at selling the naming rights to GO Transit stops, including Clarkson station.
CREDIT: Ben Spurr

Subject: Pandemics; COVID-19

Full text: The latest coronavirus news from Canada and around the world Monday. This file will be updated throughout the day. Web links to longer stories if available .
7:20 p.m. British Columbia says another 22 deaths linked to COVID-19 were recorded over a three-day period, bringing the death toll to 2,873.
A statement from the Health Ministry says the number of people in hospitals due to COVID-19 declined again with 549 patients in hospital as of Monday, a drop from 599 on Friday.
Of those in hospital, it says 85 were in intensive care.
The province also reported 974 new cases of COVID-19 over the three-day period ending Monday, although health officials have said the number is likely higher due to testing capacity limits.
4:41 p.m. Health officials in Prince Edward Island reported one more death related to COVID-19 on Monday.
Officials say the death involves a resident 80 years old or older.
A total of 16 people have died on the Island as a result of the disease.
Officials also reported 933 new infections since their last update on Friday.
There are six people in hospital with COVID-19, including four admitted because of the disease and two patients who tested positive for COVID-19 after being admitted for other medical reasons.
Officials say there has been an average of 314 new infections per day over the last seven days.
2:40 p.m. A group of Canadian Rangers will be helping an Ontario First Nation as it battles a COVID-19 outbreak.
The Canadian Armed Forces say about eight rangers will be providing food, water and care packages to Kasabonika Lake First Nation, located roughly 450 kilometres northeast of Sioux Lookout, Ont.
They say the rangers will also help with transportation and distributing COVID-19 information in the community. The support will be in place until March 10, but can be extended upon request.
In a tweet, Public Safety Minister Bill Blair says the rangers were “activated” after a request for assistance from the Ontario government.
2:39 p.m. Three more people have died as a result of COVID-19 in New Brunswick.
The latest deaths involve a person over the age of 90 in the Bathurst region, one person in their 70s in the Moncton area and someone also in their 70s in the Edmundston region.
There have been 304 COVID-19-related deaths in New Brunswick since the start of the pandemic.
There are 89 people in hospital with the disease — an increase of 17 since Friday — including three people in intensive care.
2:35 p.m. The end of mask mandates in Ontario is “not far away,” and could come as early as after March Break, Premier Doug Ford said Monday.
Ontario’s COVID-19 vaccine certificate system is set to end Tuesday, and all remaining capacity limits for indoor public settings will be lifted as well, but Ford has said mask rules would be in place for “just a little bit longer.”
Ford said he will wait for the recommendation of the chief medical officer of health, Dr. Kieran Moore, who said a few days ago that he would have an update in the coming weeks.
“What I’m hearing over the next few weeks, maybe after March Break when kids get back, but we’ll see. I don’t want to set a date,” Ford said at a news conference on Monday.
“We aren’t far away.”
2:07 p.m. With one small jab, Eugena Bryan made history.
It was Dec. 31, 2020 and COVID-19 had already ravaged long-term-care facilities across the province as it swiftly infected residents and care staff, leaving thousands dead in its wake. This vulnerable group had become a top priority for vaccination.
Bryan, a registered nurse who was involved in COVID-19 testing, and her colleagues at the Toronto Western Family Health Team, were asked if they wanted to help administer shots at the beginning of the vaccine rollout. They jumped at the chance and were dispatched to a Toronto long-term-care home.
“It was really devastating what was happening in long-term care … So, we made a pledge to help as much as we could,” said Bryan.
Read more from the Star’s Bailey Martens.
2 p.m. New Zealand is ending a requirement that incoming travellers isolate themselves as it continues to remove coronavirus border protections in the face of a growing domestic outbreak.
Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern on Monday said the requirement that vaccinated travelers isolate for a week after arriving would end on Wednesday. Initially the changes will apply only to returning New Zealanders, as tourists are still not allowed to visit.
Travelers will still need to test negative for the virus before leaving and after arriving.
The changes were welcomed by the tourism industry, although leaders wanted more certainty over when tourists could return. International tourism used to account for about 20% of New Zealand’s foreign income but has evaporated since the pandemic began.
12:45 p.m. Saskatchewan lifted its remaining COVID-19 restrictions today — the first province in Canada to do so.
Residents no longer have to wear masks in indoor public places and are not required to self-isolate for five days if they test positive for the virus.
Saskatchewan ditched its vaccine passport on February 14th.
12:40 p.m. Eased border restrictions came into effect this morning, lifting the requirement for fully vaccinated travellers to take a pre-departure COVID-19 molecular test.
The federal government announced earlier this month that double-vaccinated air and land travellers no longer need to present a negative molecular test result, such as a PCR test before departure for Canada.
Unvaccinated children under 12 also no longer need to self-isolate upon return to the country, and Ottawa has lifted its blanket advisory against trips abroad.
Potentially cheaper and easier-to-access rapid antigen tests administered by a health professional remain mandatory for Canadians 12 and over who want to avoid quarantining at home for 10 days upon return to the country.
12:15 p.m. Quebec is reporting seven more deaths linked to the novel coronavirus today and a drop of 10 COVID-19 hospitalizations.
The Health Department says 1,446 patients are in hospital with the disease, after 59 people were admitted in the last 24 hours and 69 were discharged.
Officials say the number of people in intensive care declined by four, to 94.
Authorities are reporting 845 new cases detected through PCR testing, which is reserved for certain high-risk groups.
11:49 a.m. Patti LuPone won’t be lunching for the foreseeable future.
The Broadway icon announced Sunday that she has tested positive for COVID-19 and will miss more than a week of shows of “Company” on the Broadway stage.
“Hi Dolls. I showed up for Saturday’s matinee, tested positive for Covid with 3 tests,” the 72-year-old singer tweeted. “Unfortunately, I’ll be out of the show for 10 days. I’m so sorry.”
11:43 a.m. Some establishments in Ontario will maintain proof-of-vaccine requirements even after the province ends its vaccine certificate system on Tuesday, saying they want to ensure that people feel safe and comfortable coming through their doors.
Jan Campbell-Luxton, owner of De La Terre Bakery + Café in St. Catharines, Ont., said he and front-of-house staff came to a joint decision to keep checking for proof of vaccination against COVID-19.
Maintaining the policy feels like “a fairly small price” to pay to ensure both staff and customers feel safe, he said.
“We felt like at the moment, it seemed a bit premature to simply abolish the vaccine requirements and just throw everything open,” said Campbell-Luxton. “We’re certainly not interested in kicking people out, so just as it is today, after March 1, if you’re unvaccinated and want to get something to go, you just have to wear a mask and we also do curbside pickup.”
Campbell-Luxton noted the business will also keep a capacity limit of 50 per cent for the time being, despite the province lifting capacity limits in all remaining indoor public settings as of Tuesday as well.
10:47 a.m. Omicron is fading away, and so are Americans’ worries about COVID-19.
As coronavirus pandemic case numbers, hospitalizations and deaths continue to plummet, fewer people now than in January say they are concerned that they will be infected after the rise and fall of the wildly contagious virus variant, according to a new poll from The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research.
Just 24% say they are “extremely” or “very” worried about themselves or a family member contracting COVID-19, down from 36% in both December and January, when Omicron caused a massive spike in infections and taxed public health systems. Another 34% say they are somewhat worried. More than 140,000 deaths in the U.S. have been attributed to COVID-19 since omicron became the dominant strain of the coronavirus in mid-December.
10:17 a.m. (updated): Ontario is reporting 279 people in ICU due to COVID-19 and 849 in hospital overall testing positive for COVID-19, according to its latest report released Monday morning.
The numbers represent a less than a one per cent decrease in the ICU COVID-19 count and a one per cent increase in hospitalizations overall. 28.7 per cent of the province’s 2,343 adult ICU beds remain available for new patients.
Given new provincial regulations around testing that took effect Dec. 31, 2021, case counts — reported at 1,315 on Monday, down 34.3 per cent from the previous day — are also not considered an accurate assessment of how widespread COVID-19 is right now. Three new deaths were reported in the latest numbers.
Not all hospitals report data to the province early in the week.
Read more from the Star’s Mariam Nouser.
9:15 a.m. A group of congressional Republicans has drafted legislation designed to force the Biden administration to abandon COVID-19 travel restrictions at the Canada-U.S. border.
New York Rep. Chris Jacobs hosted a news conference Sunday to unveil what he’s calling the Northern Border Reopening Act.
Canadian visitors would no longer need to be vaccinated to enter the U.S. or, in the case of air travel, show proof of a negative COVID-19 test, in the unlikely event the bill were to become law.
Democrats currently have control of the House of Representatives and hold the tiebreaker vote in the 50-50 Senate, although that’s expected to change after the November midterms.
The bill is co-sponsored by several House Republicans whose opposition to travel restrictions are well known, including fellow New Yorkers Elise Stefanik and Lee Zeldin, as well as Minnesota Rep. Pete Stauber.
8:53 a.m . Life is getting a little more back to normal today in Quebec. Bars and casinos can operate at half capacity and the province is ending its COVID-19 mandatory teleworking order on Monday. Cinemas, theatres, places of worship and sports arenas holding fewer than 10-thousand people can operate at full capacity.
8:33 a.m. For two years, Ontarians were told to keep at least six feet apart from others, wear a mask in public spaces, get vaccinated and wash their hands vigorously to protect themselves and loved ones from catching COVID-19 .
But as the latest Omicron wave dips, the province is now making the boldest moves toward reopening yet. On March 1, all vaccine mandates in Ontario will be lifted, meaning people no longer have to provide proof of vaccination to eat at a restaurant or watch a movie. Later in the month, Ontario’s top doctors hinted at a review of mask mandates, which have been in place since May 2020.
By and large, many governments are signalling a transition toward a post-pandemic life. But experts in psychology say people’s views on reopening will vary widely, based on both their lived experience and their attitude toward risky behaviours. Some have developed a stress response to the possibility of exposure to the virus, while others have tuned out any fears related to COVID-19.
Read more from the Star’s Nadine Yousif.
8:22 a.m. Japan this week will ease tough coronavirus border controls that have been criticized as xenophobic and damaging to the economy. The new rules, however, provide only a slight improvement: 5,000 new entrants per day, instead of the current 3,500, and nowhere near the estimated 64,000 a day that were entering for long-term visits before the pandemic.
The 5,000 daily arrivals also includes Japanese nationals returning to the country, which means hundreds of thousands of foreigners will still struggle to enter.
An estimated half million foreign students, teachers, workers accredited as technical interns and business travelers have been locked out and waiting to get in for nearly two years. Under the policy that takes effect Tuesday, it would take several more months of patience before everyone can get in.
8:15 a.m. South Korea will no longer require people to show proof of vaccination or negative tests to enter any indoor space starting Tuesday, removing a key preventive measure during a fast-developing omicron surge that’s elevating hospitalizations and deaths.
The Health Ministry’s announcement on Monday came as the country set another one-day record in COVID-19 deaths with 114, breaking the previous high of 112 set on Saturday. More than 710 COVID-19 patients were in critical or serious conditions, up from 200-300 in mid-February, while nearly half of the country’s intensive care units designated for COVID-19 were occupied.
Park Hyang, a senior health ministry official, said rescinding the “anti-epidemic pass” would free more health workers to help monitor nearly 800,000 virus patients with mild or moderate symptoms who have been asked to isolate at home to save hospital space.
7:10 a.m. New York state’s mandate requiring mask use at schools will end on Wednesday, Gov. Kathy Hochul said.
She cited steep declines in COVID-19 numbers in announcing the move. Cities and counties can keep mask mandates in place as they see fit, she added.
On Friday, New York Mayor Eric Adams announced the end of mandatory mask use in outdoor settings at city schools.
7:05 a.m. The pandemic put the tourism industry in a holding pattern, but some attractions pushed through and planned their debuts despite the uncertainty. Fresh new offerings — including a mind-bender on International Drive and a simulated intergalactic experience — are beginning to blossom in Central Florida.
Worldwide conditions played ever-changing roles in their creations, from supply-chain issues to the fluid public mindset.
“We opened to that unsure crowd that wanted to do … something,” said Marc Gregory Tipton, sales and marketing manager of Museum of Illusions Orlando, which came to Icon Park in January 2021.
But before welcoming visitors, parts of the attraction had to be assembled. The museum features artistic brain teasers, using angles and mirrors to create visual trickery and photo opportunities. But the company, created in Croatia in 2015, was unable to send a setup team to Florida because of travel restrictions.
5:51 a.m.: Dead bodies are piling up on gurneys in hospital hallways as Hong Kong’s health system is overloaded by its biggest COVID-19 outbreak of the pandemic.
Officials said they are struggling to move the dead to the city’s public morgues quickly enough after more than 400 people died from COVID-19 last week, according to the latest official statistics. The news comes as the city is struggling to tamp down on an omicron-fueled outbreak, with more than 26,000 cases and 83 deaths reported Sunday.
The city’s hospital authority blamed transportation delays for the situation. “That is why some bodies that were planned to be transported stayed in the hospital,” said Lau Ka-hin, the chief manager of quality and standards at Hong Kong’s hospital authority.
Monday 5:40 a.m.: Speaking about his government’s decision to lift various public health restrictions ahead of schedule, Premier Doug Ford expressed a popular sentiment about COVID-19 as the pandemic’s second anniversary nears.
“Everyone’s done with this ,” he said on Feb. 15. “Like, we are done with it … Thank God, on March 1 we’re moving out of this, and I just can’t wait.”
Not everyone shares the premier’s enthusiasm, however.
Katie Babcock wishes she could be “done” with COVID and all the disruption it has caused her life, but the 42-year-old marketing and communications professional knows that immunocompromised people like her can’t simply wish their risk away. “I don’t have the privilege not to live in fear,” she said.
Babcock’s life will actually become more constrained on March 1, when the province eliminates proof-of-vaccination requirements and capacity limits, because she will be deepening her isolation in order to protect herself. If masking is no longer required indoors, her world will shrink even further.
The public health measures some see as restrictive and inconvenient, she considers potentially life-saving.
Read Brendan Kennedy’s piece here .

Full text: Action is needed, before it's too late
Cold War-era thinking fuelling Putin's actions , Feb. 25
What no one seems to be mentioning is the similarity between Putin's action in Ukraine and Hitler's actions against Poland in 1939. In fact, Hitler's expansionist policies throughout the 1930s are similar to those of Putin's in the past five or so years.
Hitler was successful because the major powers were preoccupied with the depression and were, to a large extent divided in their actions, with the result that no actions were taken until it was too late.
It would seem Putin is a good student of history, and the arrests in Moscow of dissenters is indicative of the kind of policies associated with totalitarian regimes.
It is absolutely essential Western democracies take firm action now - before history is allowed to repeat itself completely.
Stephen Bloom, Toronto
Del Duca must step up to plate
Can Del Duca pull off a miracle?, Hepburn, Feb. 24
What an excellent article by Star columnist Bob Hepburn.
I agree completely with his points and I do hope the Liberal strategists will take the advice to heart.
I especially agree Del Duca needs to "show energy, hire an image consultant and highlight the team of candidates" and I would add I hope he will run a positive campaign, emphasizing what he will do as premier as opposed to flooding the airwaves with negative attack ads between now and June 2.
Any citizen who has been observing what has happened in our province during these past four years knows what we need in a leader for the future.
So please, step up to the plate, Steven Del Duca.
Pam Tomasevic, Mississauga

Give plate rebates to local hospitals
Ontario vehicle owners will get rebates for licence plate renewal fees, Doug Ford says, Feb. 22
I've been thinking about how to spend Premier Doug Ford's publicly funded attempt at winning the next election via elimination of driver's licence fee.
I've decided to donate that money to our local hospital, where the funds should have gone in the first place.
Julie Pingree, Toronto
Reverse the licence-fee cut, and repurpose these funds to our nurses and ailing health-care system!
I'm confident this would be unanimously supported.
Dr. Darryl Jordan Gebien,
Toronto
I am not for sale. If Premier Doug Ford refunds my licence renewal fee, I will donate it to the candidate most likely to defeat him.
Kate Chung, Toronto
Struggling to provide support
Mental health services dealing with rising calls for help, as staff are leaving, Feb. 21
Thank you for your article highlighting the current challenges within our mental-health system.
Family service agencies are also experiencing difficulties in keeping and recruiting staff and an increase in service demand combined with a decrease in funding.
Family service agencies play a vital role in Ontario's mental-health ecosystem. Individuals, couples and families come to us for a variety of reasons, but often because the services they need do not exist for those without the means to pay for a private therapist.
With years of mandated wage freezes, no funding increases and a decline in charitable dollars, family service agencies have struggled to keep up with competitive salaries. As a result, many agencies are bleeding staff, while the demand for service has doubled.
Those most affected by the pandemic are also our most vulnerable - and the ones left behind in accessing services, because the counsellors are not there to provide it, and the funding is not there to keep them.
As a network, we are committed to work together with our community partners and government to find solutions so no one is left behind.
Susan Wells, chief executive officer, Family Service Ontario

Antisemitism not hard to sum up
TDSB urged to act against antisemitism, Feb. 23
Is it enough to teach about the Holocaust in the face of antisemitic actions by TDSB students and anti-Zionism at the University of Toronto?
Or do students need to learn that the Holocaust was the worst manifestation of a centuries-long history of continuing antisemitism due to Jews being othered because of their religious beliefs, by both Christians and Muslims?
And that Jews are a multiracial, multinational people, bound by culture and history as well as religion?
And that Zionism is the national liberation movement of the Jewish nation, with a return to their Jewish homeland from which they were forcibly expelled in 60 CE, a place where they can practise self-determination like other nations, and offer shelter to Jews still experiencing antisemitism post-Holocaust, including those from Egypt, Syria, Iraq, Iran, Russia and France?
It took me three sentences to state it. Should be manageable to teach it.
Marcia Zalev, Toronto
What did kids learn at protest?
Ottawa protest ends on
saddest of notes, Raj, Feb. 19
Althia Raj correctly describes the sad situation in Ottawa. I heartily agree on so many levels.
Sad at the deaths due to COVID-19, sad for our flailing health-care system and medical professionals, and so sad to see so many misguided Canadians continue to resort to TikTok to receive and spew misinformation.
Most of all, I'm saddened by the children being used as pawns in the protest.
As a former nurse at the Hospital for Sick Children, I was mandated to uphold the safety of children. If a child came under my care that had been taken from his home, removed from school, was being sheltered in a vehicle and subjected to 24-hour horns and raucous parties, it would be my responsibility to report this to the police and Childrens Aid immediately as an emergency.
What are these poor children being taught in Ottawa?
That might is right? That obstruction of justice is acceptable? That laws are meant to be broken?
The entire situation is profoundly sad on so many levels, but most of all, these children, used as pawns are more than just collateral damage. These children are our future.
Heaven help us!
Sharon Pitto, Aurora
Toxic protest became intolerable
Where should we stand on the Emergencies Act?, Feb. 18
I can't help but wonder how these protesters would have been managed in an undemocratic country, like Russia or China.
Yes, it took too long to end this occupation, but at the end of the day they made themselves heard, they voiced their opinions and were actually given too much freedom to do so.
True freedom comes with a price, often paid for with lives lost, as seen in history.
Lets honour our freedom, so expensively paid for by the fallen, by peacefully voicing our opinion.
This protest was not peaceful; if it was, the protesters would have left when first asked to do so.
It became a horn-blaring, diesel-fumed, toxic occupation of public space.
Would the protesters tolerate the same behaviour in front of their own homes? I hardly think so.
Kelly Vig, Barrie

____________________________________________________________

Martin Regg Cohn: Russia is showing convoy protesters what an attack on freedom really looks like

Publication info: Feb 25, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/martin-regg-cohn-russia-is-showing-convoy/docview/2633331051/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Martin+Regg+Cohn%3A+Russia+is+showing+convoy+protesters+what+an+attack+on+freedom+really+looks+like&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-25&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The question, after the unthinkable invasion of Ukraine: What was Vladimir Putin thinking?
Here’s a related question: What were Canadians thinking during their own conflict of the last few weeks?
Amid the Russian mystery, any clarity here in Canada? For this is a fateful time to reflect on questions of sovereignty, democracy and “freedom.”
What do these values really mean? Or are they now meaningless — devalued by disinformation and dissembling?
Consider the front page of Thursday’s Toronto Star, which juxtaposed Canada’s recent domestic conflict versus the larger battle for the soul of Europe. Here’s how the two developing stories looked side by side:
Canada “revokes emergency measures,” declared the headline on the right-hand column, as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau gave the all-clear.
Ukraine “declares state of emergency” announced the left side of the front page, in the aftermath of Russia’s invasion.
Two countries, two realities, two emergencies. One internal, one external.
In democratic Canada, a contorted cry for “freedom” from the fringe. In democratic Ukraine, a desperate quest for freedom in the face of a totalitarian invasion.
On the same day, on the same front page.
At the very time Ukraine was buttressing its frontier against the threat of outside invaders, Canada was securing its own undefended border from within. Ontario’s Premier Doug Ford declared his own state of emergency to liberate a bridge — and an economy — held hostage.
It is easy enough to belittle the blockade at the bridge, to understate the occupation of Ottawa , and to exaggerate the danger of emergency declarations in Canada. But that would be a misreading of what happened here, how events are unfolding elsewhere — and where freedom truthfully fits in.
The special powers proclaimed by both federal and provincial governments succeeded where regular measures failed (someone had to compel the tow trucks that went AWOL). When the disruptions were removed, the declarations were rescinded.
Despite dire warnings of damage to democracy from limiting the “freedoms” of fringe leaders who flout laws and public health measures enacted by elected leaders, both levels of government did as promised: They dialed back their special powers ahead of schedule.
Once normality was restored, they returned to democratic norms.
Those democratic norms are the cornerstone of a democracy. When they are upended — as in Donald Trump’s America in the aftermath of the last election — no clauses in the Constitution or Charter of Rights will protect us.
That reality is worth repeating as we witness the dismantling and dismemberment of Ukraine’s democracy by an army commanded by a Russian dictator. For most people, where they stand on this international crisis depends on where their national interests lie.
The fault lines of democracy and disunity run deep. Not just across our country but around the world.
Under Trump’s successor as president, Joe Biden, America leads the way with the toughest economic sanctions and biggest military aid. Canada and the rest of the West are falling into line, more or less.
But other countries, and some other democracies, are finding their own balance between diplomacy and clarity:
India, the world’s largest democracy, made its decision early on. It chose to remain in the Russian camp, mindful of its military ties to supply lines dating to the Soviet era.
Israel, which styles itself the Middle East’s sole democracy, was also walking a fine line for fear of offending the Russian dictator who also calls the shots in neighbouring Syria. Turkey, which imagines itself a bulwark in the region, kept its distance.
While one democracy after another lost its voice, China’s autocracy was quietly clearing its throat. National sovereignty and territorial integrity are the bedrock of China’s foreign policy edifice — its rulers insisting that outsiders refrain from meddling in internal matters such as the so-called “renegade province” of Taiwan, or the supposedly autonomous regions of Hong Kong, Tibet and Xinjiang.
But after Putin dropped in on his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, breaking the diplomatic boycott over the Winter Olympics, Beijing now is looking the other way on sovereignty, and going its own way on sanctions. China is poised to profit from expanded trade with Russia, dealing a fatal blow to the West’s economic retaliation.
All that said, the unspoken reality is that sanctions were always symbolic. For all the Western unity, there is no international unanimity and thus no efficacy.
Sanctions were a deterrent, but they were discounted by a dictator who is not accountable to his people, and therefore impervious to pressure. He has already taken into account the benefits and costs of conquest, built up his financial reserves, rebuilt his military, and made his calculation in advance.
Canada, the first western country to recognize Ukrainian independence in 1991, has now joined in the sanctions and added to the condemnations. Canadians of Ukrainian descent, who make up the world’s largest diaspora outside of Eastern Europe, will be watching the death spiral of democracy in their ancestral land.
Amid the calamity, clarity emerges: Ukraine’s genuine struggle for sovereignty puts the lie to the false clamour for “freedom” from a fringe group at home.
Canada’s emergency has ended and its democracy endures. The same cannot be said for Ukraine’s emerging democracy and enduring emergency.
Martin Regg Cohn is a Toronto-based columnist focusing on Ontario politics and international affairs for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @reggcohn

CAPTION: Two demonstrators ride horses past parked trucks and Parliament Hill during a protest against COVID-19 restrictions in Ottawa on Feb. 5, 2022. Ukraine's genuine struggle for sovereignty puts the lie to the false clamour for "freedom" from a fringe group at home, Martin Regg Cohn writes.
CREDIT: Martin Regg Cohn

Shawn Micallef: To defeat Doug Ford in June, the opposition should defend local democracy by pledging to restore Toronto's city council

Publication info: Feb 26, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/shawn-micallef-defeat-doug-ford-june-opposition/docview/2633269396/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Shawn+Micallef%3A+To+defeat+Doug+Ford+in+June%2C+the+opposition+should+defend+local+democracy+by+pledging+to+restore+Toronto%27s+city+council&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ottawa city council held an absolutely bananas meeting during the occupation of their city two weeks ago. The mayor had just summarily removed members of Ottawa’s police board and the meeting was in desperate shambles, with some councillors begging for something to be done to help the under-siege residents of their city.
It’s common for people to tune out their own city council meetings, but this one had Ottawans and, more astoundingly, people from across the country tuning in. The stakes and drama were high.
As I watched from Toronto, I couldn’t help but notice how many councillors there are in Ottawa. A city of one million people, it has 23 councillors, plus a mayor. That’s just about the same as Toronto with its 25 councillors plus mayor. Difference is, Toronto has nearly three million people.
The reason for the discrepancy is well known: during the 2018 municipal elections happening across Ontario, Premier Doug Ford’s government chose to cut Toronto’s council in half, and only Toronto’s.
It can’t be overstated that this was during a supposedly democratic election.
Last week it was rich, then, when Ford answered a question about why he and his government didn’t act sooner to intervene in the Ottawa occupation by saying he didn’t like to barge into another jurisdiction . Rich, condescending and a plain false statement, but it’s also an opportunity.
The provincial election is in June so here’s a free platform for any of the opposition parties: pledge to reinstate Toronto’s full council. Doing so could endear them to many Torontonians. A stand for process-oriented and orderly democracy, when it’s under attack in so many places around the world, could also win people farther afield.
Only Toronto was targeted by Ford in 2018, proving it was his vendetta against old colleagues and communities, but everyone in Ontario should understand that what happened to Toronto’s local democracy could happen to theirs.
Suggesting that the recent Ottawa council meeting was bananas isn’t hyperbole — it was totally bananas — but it also isn’t a slight against Ottawa. Local councils across the country often look incredibly messy and argumentative at first glance. Short video clips of such moments are often the only council proceedings the average person sees. This was especially true during the Rob Ford era when there were many such moments.
It’s important to remember that municipal government works differently than either provincial or federal governments, where policy is largely formed behind closed doors, in caucus, before it’s presented, fully formed, for debate in the commons. At the municipal level there are no political parties or caucus, so everything happens in front of us: we get to see how the entire sausage is made, and sometimes it’s messy. A sausage factory will turn anyone into a vegetarian.
Don’t tune it out, though.
The mess has always made it easy for cynics, or those with political interest in keeping city councils weak, to disparage local government. And to be sure, it is unnecessarily messy and bananas at times, but that’s the price of democracy, democracy that is closest to the everyday lives of citizens. Less mess is less democracy.
Speaking of democracy, in pledging to return Toronto’s council to its pre-Ford-cut state, this doesn’t mean back up to 44 councillors and a mayor, as it was prior to the 2018 election. Rather, council was set to expand to 47 council seats so there were actually 47 council races thrown into turmoil back then.
Unlike the Ford cut, the decision to increase the number of city councillors was not arbitrary but the result of a years-long study and public consultation process undertaken by city staff to ensure better democratic balance and representation .
You may not like it, but a democratic process was followed, and to honour democracy and fair play, despite the constitutional power the province has over municipalities, it ought to be reset. Want fewer councillors? Then go through the process again. That’s how democracy works.
Some, even I, might be tempted to call for further election promises that give municipalities even more autonomy. That’s a sentiment I’ve long been sympathetic to, even supported. Perhaps not the “Province of Toronto,” but something toward that.
However, as the housing crisis and other politicized issues have increased in consequence, I’m not sure Toronto and other municipalities are ready to make the kinds of decisions needed when power is so vested in homeowners and councillors who are beholden to them — where, say, objecting to new housing developments is routine.
It’s all the same voters, of course, but a higher level of government can sometimes make harder decisions than the lower one. This is a reason why the old Metro Toronto government worked so well, dividing up these powers.
Finding that balance is the hard part, and the solution isn’t clear. What is clear is a good faith pledge to restore democratic order to Canada’s biggest city, and a pledge to protect democracy in other Ontario cities, would be a welcome part of this upcoming provincial election.
Shawn Micallef is a Toronto-based writer and a freelance contributing columnist for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @shawnmicallef

Althia Raj: Now that Justin Trudeau has restored order in Ottawa, he needs to work on trust in government

Publication info: Feb 26, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/althia-raj-now-that-justin-trudeau-has-restored/docview/2633267768/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Althia+Raj%3A+Now+that+Justin+Trudeau+has+restored+order+in+Ottawa%2C+he+needs+to+work+on+trust+in+government&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: For weeks now, Liberals and Conservatives have accused each other of dividing the country, of playing wedge politics on COVID-19 vaccinations, of pouring gasoline on a fire by either rejecting calls to meet so-called “Freedom Convoy” demonstrators or cheering them on and refusing to ask the blockaders to go home.
Now, as parliamentarians prepare to review the federal government’s first invoking of the Emergencies Act, both parties remain entrenched in their corners, unwilling to put water in their wine and seek consensus for the good of the country.
At issue is the makeup of a special committee charged with reviewing the government’s actions. When the Emergencies Act was adopted in 1988, supervision of Parliament was a key facet. Parliament was given the ability to revoke a declaration of emergency (a vote in support happened Monday) and it was charged with reviewing the order after the fact.
After Prime Minister Justin Trudeau revoked the emergency measures on Wednesday, saying they were no longer necessary, he thankfully agreed scrutiny should still follow. Unfortunately, there’s disagreement on who should provide that scrutiny.
Liberal House Leader Mark Holland says the Tories are making “unreasonable” demands. Conservative House Leader John Brassard calls the government’s offer “absurd.”
The Liberals want a committee of three Grit MPs, two Conservatives, one Bloc Québécois, one NDP, and four senators, representing the major groups in the Senate, with the Bloc, the NDP and a senator acting as co-chairs.
“The chair would be neither a Liberal, whose government invoked [the] Emergencies Act,” Holland tweeted Thursday, “or a Conservative, whose party led the way in supporting protesters.”
Brassard said it’s disingenuous for the Liberals to suggest the Conservatives’ “implied support for the convoy” means their position would be prejudiced.
“This is an oversight committee,” he told me. “It’s not an opportunity for the government to stack the deck.” He believes the Grits’ offer gives the government “effectively the majority,” though it’s unclear what bias most senators hold.
The Tories originally proposed a 16-member committee modelled on another joint committee that would have given them at least a co-chair position. But the Liberals countered with the above offer after securing support from the NDP.
Upset, the Conservatives came back suggesting a five-person committee that met the strict definition of the act: at least one MP from each recognized party, and at least one senator from each party in the Senate that’s represented on the committee by an MP.
Because the act wasn’t updated after Trudeau came to office in 2015 with a pledge to make the Senate less partisan and more independent, the Conservatives argue this gives them one MP and the only senator, and both committee co-chairs.
“This is the prime minister’s problem,” Brassard said. “They’ve had six years to amend the act to reflect the current composition of the Senate, and they haven’t done that .”
It’s unrealistic to suggest the Liberals should have seen this coming, but now the Grits want to put their suggestion up for a vote — one they are likely to win. The Tories don’t seem upset by that. Brassard said he welcomes the debate — “I’ve got a lot to say.” The result is more division.
It’s discouraging and foreshadows more partisan games on a committee that should set the tone for how reviews are done in the future.
It’s imperative the use of the Emergencies Act is not normalized, that this be a rigorous exercise, and frankly, the Liberals should accept an opposition chair. There are worthwhile questions to be probed. Could the government have achieved its objectives through other means? Was the response — freezing bank accounts, for example — proportionate to the threat at hand?
“It’s a bit ridiculous at the moment,” the Bloc press secretary Julien Coulombe-Bonnafous told me. “What we are hoping for is a consensus. That this isn’t adopted by a vote after a debate, that everyone agrees together who the chair will be, and that it be as neutral as possible.”
What shook many Canadians to the core during the convoy’s occupation of Ottawa was the perceived breakdown of government institutions. The police weren’t seen to do their job, nor was the province of Ontario. The federal government seemed to act late, and then perhaps too heavy-handedly. Now that order is restored, confidence also needs to be restored. The best way for that to happen is a truly transparent and neutral process: a full public inquiry, and a committee process free of partisan bickering.
At least we now know that all the regulations and proclamations made under the Emergencies Act were published, which means the parliamentary committee has few reasons to meet behind closed doors.
Althia Raj is an Ottawa-based national politics columnist for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @althiaraj

Experience of my hockey league shows we need proof of vaccination

Publication info: Feb 26, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/experience-my-hockey-league-shows-we-need-proof/docview/2633206340/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Experience+of+my+hockey+league+shows+we+need+proof+of+vaccination&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: World is ‘done’ with COVID and it’s time to move on from restrictions: Ford, Feb. 15
While Doug Ford has stated that he and the world are done with COVID-19, it is most certainly not done with us.
I hold up my own experience with my pickup hockey league as evidence. At my local arena just one week after dropping the COVID-19 pre-screening form, 16 of 20 fully vaccinated players have tested positive. These positive tests have spread into extended families.
Come next week, the unvaccinated will be allowed to enter restaurants and public venues with the rest of us.
For nearly two years we’ve been asked to make sacrifices for the greater good and next week those who didn’t will share the same air space as those who did.
Ford is less interested in COVID-19 than his fortunes in the upcoming provincial election.
Joe Bezubiak, Brougham, Ont.
A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
I am wondering how I can best channel the frustration and despondency I feel as I witness the Ford government’s crass decision to cancel the $120-licence fee and to rebate the amount to Ontarians just before the election.
For sure, I will cast my vote for one of the other parties, but I will also donate whatever refund I receive to one of the many services that will experience the reduced funding which will be the result of this billion-dollar election ploy. I may not be able to stop this populist electioneering, but I will not allow myself to personally profit from it.
Joseph Vorstermans, Toronto
A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
I have never seen such a blatant buying of votes as Doug Ford’s government scrapping and refunding the licence plate renewal fee and dropping of tolls on some provincial highways.
This is targeted to his support base in suburban Ontario where multiple vehicle ownership is necessary because of the inadequacy of public transit and poor community design resulting in a lack of walkability.
Given the climate crisis, we should not be giving private car ownership any financial incentives.
I think the province spending that billion dollars on affordable housing would have a much bigger impact on the quality of life of all our communities.
The Ford government says their priorities are climate, education, health and housing, but they would give away a billion dollars to support the driving of cars and their production of greenhouse gases to buy your vote.
I hope Ontarians will remember how two-faced this government is when it is time to vote.
Lynn Armstrong, Ottawa

Ford's opposition should vow to restore city council

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 26 Feb 2022: A.23.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/fords-opposition-should-vow-restore-city-council/docview/2633204818/se-2?accountid=15090

You may not like it, but a democratic process was followed, and to honour democracy and fair play, despite the constitutional power the province has over municipalities, it ought to be reset. Want fewer councillors? Then go through the process again. That's how democracy works.
Some, even I, might be tempted to call for further election promises that give municipalities even more autonomy. That's a sentiment I've long been sympathetic to, even supported. Perhaps not the "Province of Toronto," but something toward that.
However, as the housing crisis and other politicized issues have increased in consequence, I'm not sure Toronto and other municipalities are ready to make the kinds of decisions needed when power is so vested in homeowners and councillors who are beholden to them - where, say, objecting to new housing developments is routine.
It's all the same voters, of course, but a higher level of government can sometimes make harder decisions than the lower one. This is a reason why the old Metro Toronto government worked so well, dividing up these powers.
Finding that balance is the hard part, and the solution isn't clear. What is clear is a good faith pledge to restore democratic order to Canada's biggest city, and a pledge to protect democracy in other Ontario cities, would be a welcome part of this upcoming provincial election.
Twitter: @shawnmicallef

Full text: Pickup game shows the need for proof
of vaccination
World is 'done' with COVID and it's time to move on from restrictions: Ford, Feb. 15
While Doug Ford has stated that he and the world are done with COVID-19, it is most certainly not done with us.
I hold up my own experience with my pickup hockey league as evidence. At my local arena just one week after dropping the COVID-19 pre-screening form, 16 of 20 fully vaccinated players have tested positive. These positive tests have spread into extended families.
Come next week, the unvaccinated will be allowed to enter restaurants and public venues with the rest of us.
For nearly two years we've been asked to make sacrifices for the greater good and next week those who didn't will share the same air space as those who did.
Ford is less interested in COVID-19 than his fortunes in the upcoming provincial election.
Joe Bezubiak, Brougham, Ont.
I refuse to profit from this populist electioneering
A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
I am wondering how I can best channel the frustration and despondency I feel as I witness the Ford government's crass decision to cancel the $120-licence fee and to rebate the amount to Ontarians just before the election.
For sure, I will cast my vote for one of the other parties, but I will also donate whatever refund I receive to one of the many services that will experience the reduced funding which will be the result of this billion-dollar election ploy. I may not be able to stop this populist electioneering, but I will not allow myself to personally profit from it.
Joseph Vorstermans, Toronto
I hope people will remember Ford's two-faced regime
A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
I have never seen such a blatant buying of votes as Doug Ford's government scrapping and refunding the licence plate renewal fee and dropping of tolls on some provincial highways.
This is targeted to his support base in suburban Ontario where multiple vehicle ownership is necessary because of the inadequacy of public transit and poor community design resulting in a lack of walkability.
Given the climate crisis, we should not be giving private car ownership any financial incentives.
I think the province spending that billion dollars on affordable housing would have a much bigger impact on the quality of life of all our communities.
The Ford government says their priorities are climate, education, health and housing, but they would give away a billion dollars to support the driving of cars and their production of greenhouse gases to buy your vote.
I hope Ontarians will remember how two-faced this government is when it is time to vote.
Lynn Armstrong, Ottawa

What assault on freedom really looks like

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 26 Feb 2022: A.10.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/what-assault-on-freedom-really-looks-like/docview/2633204780/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=What+assault+on+freedom+really+looks+like&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-02-26&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The question, after the unthinkable invasion of Ukraine: What was Vladimir Putin thinking?
Here's a related question: What were Canadians thinking during their own conflict of the last few weeks?
Amid the Russian mystery, any clarity here in Canada? For this is a fateful time to reflect on questions of sovereignty, democracy and "freedom."
What do these values really mean? Or are they now meaningless - devalued by disinformation and dissembling?
Consider the front page of Thursday's Toronto Star, which juxtaposed Canada's recent domestic conflict versus the larger battle for the soul of Europe. Here's how the two developing stories looked side by side:
Canada "revokes emergency measures," declared the headline on the right-hand column, as Prime Minister Justin Trudeau gave the all-clear.
Ukraine "declares state of emergency" announced the left side of the front page, in the aftermath of Russia's invasion.
Two countries, two realities, two emergencies. One internal, one external.
In democratic Canada, a contorted cry for "freedom" from the fringe. In democratic Ukraine, a desperate quest for freedom in the face of a totalitarian invasion.
On the same day, on the same front page.
At the very time Ukraine was buttressing its frontier against the threat of outside invaders, Canada was securing its own undefended border from within. Ontario Premier Doug Ford declared his own state of emergency to liberate a bridge - and an economy - held hostage.
It is easy enough to belittle the blockade at the bridge, to understate the occupation of Ottawa, and to exaggerate the danger of emergency declarations in Canada. But that would be a misreading of what happened here, how events are unfolding elsewhere - and where freedom truthfully fits in.
The special powers proclaimed by both federal and provincial governments succeeded where regular measures failed (someone had to compel the tow trucks that went AWOL). When the disruptions were removed, the declarations were rescinded.
Despite dire warnings of damage to democracy from limiting the "freedoms" of fringe leaders who flout laws and public health measures enacted by elected leaders, both levels of government did as promised: They dialed back their special powers ahead of schedule.
Once normality was restored, they returned to democratic norms.
Those democratic norms are the cornerstone of a democracy. When they are upended - as in Donald Trump's America in the aftermath of the last election - no clauses in the Constitution or Charter of Rights and Freedoms will protect us.
That reality is worth repeating as we witness the dismantling and dismemberment of Ukraine's democracy by an army commanded by a Russian dictator. For most people, where they stand on this international crisis depends on where their national interests lie.
The fault lines of democracy and disunity run deep. Not just across our country but around the world.
Under Trump's successor as president, Joe Biden, the United States leads the way with the toughest economic sanctions and biggest military aid. Canada and the rest of the West are falling into line, more or less.
But other countries, and some other democracies, are finding their own balance between diplomacy and clarity:
India, the world's largest democracy, made its decision early on. It chose to remain in the Russian camp, mindful of its military ties to supply lines dating to the Soviet era.
Israel, which styles itself the Middle East's sole democracy, was also walking a fine line for fear of offending the Russian dictator who also calls the shots in neighbouring Syria. Turkey, which imagines itself a bulwark in the region, kept its distance.
While one democracy after another lost its voice, China's autocracy was quietly clearing its throat. National sovereignty and territorial integrity are the bedrock of China's foreign policy edifice - its rulers insisting that outsiders refrain from meddling in internal matters such as the so-called "renegade province" of Taiwan, or the supposedly autonomous regions of Hong Kong, Tibet and Xinjiang.
But after Putin dropped in on his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, breaking the diplomatic boycott over the Winter Olympics, Beijing now is looking the other way on sovereignty, and going its own way on sanctions. China is poised to profit from expanded trade with Russia, dealing a fatal blow to the West's economic retaliation.
All that said, the unspoken reality is that sanctions were always symbolic. For all the western unity, there is no international unanimity and thus no efficacy.
Sanctions were a deterrent, but they were discounted by a dictator who is not accountable to his people, and therefore impervious to pressure.
He has already taken into account the benefits and costs of conquest, built up his financial reserves, rebuilt his military, and made his calculation in advance.
Canada, the first western country to recognize Ukrainian independence in 1991, has now joined in the sanctions and added to the condemnations. Canadians of Ukrainian descent, who make up the world's largest diaspora outside of Eastern Europe, will be watching the death spiral of democracy in their ancestral land.
Amid the calamity, clarity emerges: Ukraine's genuine struggle for sovereignty puts the lie to the false clamour for "freedom" from a fringe group at home.
Canada's emergency has ended and its democracy endures. The same cannot be said for Ukraine's emerging democracy and enduring emergency.
Twitter: @reggcohn
CAPTION: Ukrainians wait in the customs area to get their documents checked before entering Slovakia from Ukraine on Friday. Ukraine's genuine struggle for sovereignty puts the lie to the false clamour for "freedom" from a fringe group at home, Martin Regg Cohn writes.Zuzana GogovaGETTY IMAGES
