Convoy protests: Ottawa police say over 100 people arrested; convoy organizer Chris Barber released on bail

Publication info: Feb 18, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/convoy-protests-ottawa-police-say-over-100-people/docview/2630322184/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Convoy+protests%3A+Ottawa+police+say+over+100+people+arrested%3B+convoy+organizer+Chris+Barber+released+on+bail&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Police began their crackdown in downtown Ottawa as trucker-led convoy protesters continue to cause chaos in the city. Arrests were made on Thursday including convoy organizer Tamara Lich. Follow the Star’s live coverage.
10 p.m. Government House leader Mark Holland says the House of Commons will resume debate Saturday on the use of the Emergencies Act to respond to the illegal blockades.
This morning the Speaker and House leaders from all parties agreed to cancel today's (Friday's) sitting on the advice of parliamentary security.
Holland says on Twitter that the safety of MPs and all employees on Parliament Hill is paramount.
The House began debating the government's decision to invoke the Emergencies Act on Thursday.
Earlier, Holland said the pause would not affect the outcome and MPs who want to speak will do so.
He said MPs will vote early next week on the Emergencies Act motion.
8 p.m. (UPDATED) The Ottawa Police Service says officers have arrested more than 100 people in the crackdown on anti-government protesters in the city.
Police also say more than 20 vehicles have been towed in the push to end the three-week occupation of the capital.
Chris Barber, a protest organizer arrested yesterday, has been released on bail on the conditions he leaves Ontario by Wednesday and not publicly endorse the convoy or have any contact with the other major protest organizers.
Tamara Lich, another protest organizer who was arrested yesterday, is to appear in Ottawa court tomorrow morning for her bail hearing.
7:35 p.m. On Thursday they were told they would be arrested if they did not end their illegal occupation of Ottawa.
The next day hundreds of heavily armed police moved in to make good on that warning. Yet even as several of the convoy’s leaders were detained, and trucks began to be towed, many protesters and their supporters seemed undeterred by the growing police presence. As their fellow occupiers were arrested, some said they didn’t believe it would happen to them. Others said they were willing to fight for their cause.
On Wellington Street in front of Parliament Hill, the convoy’s infamous bouncy castle — now deflated — sits across from a makeshift daycare, with lawn games for kids and a box holding what looked like children’s toys. Children could be seen playing in the area Friday afternoon.
The Star’s Jenna Moon reports from Ottawa: Protesters play music and dance as police close in
5:55 p.m. (UPDATED) In two tweets posted early Friday evening , Ottawa police said protesters had assaulted officers and attempted to remove their weapons .
As the “assaultive behaviour” continued, police sent in mounted officers to separate protesters from the police line.
“As this was happening a bicycle was thrown at the feet of one of the horses in an attempt to injure it,” one tweet read. “One person was arrested for intentionally harming a police service animal.”
Earlier in the day, interim police chief Steve Bell said aside from a minor injury sustained by one officer, there were no other injuries so far despite several scuffles between demonstrators and police.
Riot squads and mounted police continue to slowly advance westbound toward Parliament Hill, an operation police said will continue around the clock.
5:00 p.m. A group involved in the anti-government protest against COVID-19 measures in Ottawa is asking a court to put the brakes on federal use of the Emergencies Act to clamp down on demonstrators.
In a filing in Federal Court today, Canadian Frontline Nurses and member Kristen Nagle seek an injunction staying the Liberal government's use of the emergencies law and associated measures while their full case plays out in court.
The nurses group and Nagle say they are opposed to unreasonable COVID-19-related mandates and restrictions that have been implemented by various levels of Canadian governments.
They want a court declaration that the federal government strayed beyond its jurisdiction in declaring a public order emergency earlier this week, saying the move was unconstitutional.
They also seek all orders-in-council, minutes of meetings, cabinet submissions, memorandums, agreements and constituting documents relating to the public order emergency proclamation.
The court filing comes as police officers make arrests and tow vehicles in downtown Ottawa in an effort to end what police call an illegal protest.
4:45 p.m. The street in front of Parliament Hill is clearer than it was this morning after a handful of vehicles departed.
At least three semis that were parked parallel to the Centre Block left during the day, with one remaining driver saying the vehicles relocated elsewhere.
Where he didn't say.
Police are warning anyone remaining downtown could have their vehicle towed, even if they want to leave but are boxed in.
Protesters, meanwhile, have set up snow barricades across roads just south of Wellington Street, including one outside Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's office that has hockey sticks poking out the top.
3:50 p.m. Police have arrested 70 people as they clear the protests in Ottawa, interim chief Steve Bell said at a news conference. Police set up 100 checkpoints Thursday night and started making arrests Friday. Those arrested include “key individuals who were responsible for organizing these unlawful activities,” who have been charged with “various offences, including mischief.”
“These are not the images Ottawa wants to see,” said Bell, who added that police will continue the operation “until residents and citizens have their city back.”
Asked if police used new powers granted under the Emergency Measures Act, Bell said the police had used new and existing powers to clear the protest and this “could not have been done without these powers.”
“We will move slowly and safely and respect people’s Charter rights,” Bell added.
He commended police officers for their professionalism in the face of “taunts and slurs.”
“It shocks and surprises me that people put children in harm’s way, in the middle of a police operation,” Bell said
3:15 p.m. An Ontario judge has extended an order to keep a busy international bridge clear, The Canadian Press reports.
Ontario Superior Court Chief Justice Geoffrey Morawetz has granted an extension of an injunction that prohibits blocking access to the Ambassador Bridge after his previous order was set to expire Monday, according to CP.
Canada-bound traffic was blocked for a week at the bridge that connects Windsor, Ont., with Detroit by protesters who oppose COVID-19 measures and vaccine mandates.
The city argued there was an imminent threat by protesters to block the bridge again.
3:04 p.m. Protest organizers sent conflicting signals of defiance and retreat to so-called “Freedom Convoy” demonstrators, who remained dug in around Parliament Hill on Friday, as hundreds of police officers started to clear the 22-day occupation, forcing both Houses of Canada’s federal legislature to shut down, the Toronto Star’s Rob Ferguson reports.
Just moments after Ottawa police accused protesters of using children as shields from law enforcement, some convoy organizers took to social media to call on convoy demonstrators to stand down, according to the Star’s Ferguson.
In a video posted on Facebook, organizer Pat King said protesters who don’t want to face the police crackdown should leave, and that he had spoken with local police whom he said confirmed they would be allowed to drive their trucks out of the downtown core.
“We’re not retreating, we’re regrouping,” King said, telling protesters to drive to a truck stop in Arnprior, a town west of Ottawa, before returning to the city at some unspecified time.
Moments later, King appeared to livestream a video of his own arrest as he drove his truck. “I’m being arrested, we’ll talk to you guys soon,” he said before signing off.
Ottawa police would not immediately confirm that King had been arrested, though they later stated 21 people had been arrested by mid-afternoon Friday, and that 21 vehicles had been towed.
3 p.m. Police continue to push back a crowd gathered at a major intersection near Parliament Hill, The Canadian Press reports.
Shouting at protesters to move back officers formed a line across Sussex Drive, according to CP.
Those in the crowd were warned through a speaker to move back or face being arrested.
The crowd watched as police ordered a camper van be towed whose windows had been smashed in.
2:47 p.m. Just north of the Rideau Centre, a number of flatbed tow trucks now occupy the space previously taken up by protesters and their trucks and vehicles. The tow trucks appear to have City of Ottawa logos on the side of them. The private tow trucks appear to have either had their decals removed or masked.
On his Facebook livestream, Pat King urged drivers in the area to use their vehicles to block a road where he said tow trucks were amassing to help police clear the parked protesters.
King threatened tow truck operators working with police that he would find out who they are.
2:40 p.m. Ottawa police say 21 people have been arrested and 21 vehicles have been towed as the force steps up enforcement against anti-government protesters who have been camped outside Parliament Hill, The Canadian Press reports.
The force made the announcement after police clad in riot gear and touting gas masks and tear-gas guns converged on a large crowd of protesters to contain them near the Westin Hotel in downtown Ottawa, according to CP.
2:10 p.m. (update) Ottawa police say 21 people have been arrested and 21 vehicles have been towed Friday. Police say Nicholas Street is clear, and that operations continue on Rideau and Sussex.
More than a dozen trucks appear to have left the area where occupiers have been camped out for weeks in Ottawa.
Police towed trucks away from an area on the eastern edge of Ottawa’s downtown core. Tow trucks could be seen moving the vehicles from Nicholas Street after making arrests there earlier this morning.
1:53 p.m. Two blocks west of where police have amassed in riot gear, there are children playing with toys in one of the makeshift play areas set up by protesters on Wellington Street in front of the West Block. The Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa is working closely alongside police to help ensure the safety and well-being of children who are a part of the occupation. The organization says that as police action unfolds, parents who are involved should make the necessary alternate care arrangements for their children should they be arrested or detained. On Thursday, Bill Blair, the federal emergency preparedness minister, again told parents to take their children home, “This is no place for children, take them home immediately. Take them to a safe place.”
1:39 p.m. There are new reports that one of the key security figures who was part of the convoy organization has been arrested. Daniel Bulford’s spouse said in a Facebook live video that Bulford turned himself in and has been arrested.
1:32 p.m. Premier Doug Ford, who endorsed Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s Emergencies Act, touts “permanent” measures to prevent protests like the recent Ambassador Bridge siege. “Absolutely no way that people are going to go there and block a trading corridor ... It’s unacceptable,” said Ford.
1:14 p.m. There are reports that several of the trucks and cabs that have blocked downtown Ottawa streets for weeks have been abandoned by their drivers and left unlocked. Protesters have reportedly passed this information along to police.
1:11 p.m. Heavily-armed Quebec provincial police officers in tactical gear have gathered near Chateau Laurier, several hundred meters Parliament Hill.
12:59 p.m. In a video posted on Facebook, organizer Pat King said protesters who don’t want to face the police crackdown should leave, and that he had spoken with local police whom he said confirmed they would be allowed to drive their trucks out of the downtown core.
“We’re not retreating, we’re re-grouping,” King said, telling protesters to drive to a truck stop in Arnprior, a town west of Ottawa, before returning to the city at some unspecified time.
“Those that do now want to take part and do not want to hold the line, you have the option to pull out,” he said.
“We’re going to be the ones to turn around and walk away, because we don’t want violence.”
Moments later, King appeared to livestream a video of his own arrest as he drove his truck. “I’m being arrested, we’ll talk to you guys soon,” he said, before signing off.
12:55 p.m. Protesters appear to be using road pylons and shovels in order to build what some believe is snow wall to keep police at bay.
12:49 p.m. (update) The line of police on Rideau Street has expanded and also includes officers from Toronto police, Sudbury police and York police.
12:44 p.m. Pat King, organizer and supporter of convoy protests appears to have been arrested based off claims King made on his Facebook live stream.
12:43 p.m. Protestors are reportedly piling up snow in an effort to block the central blockade off from the police who are moving in from the east just a few blocks away.
12:26 p.m. More protesters have joined a group facing off with heavily-armed police officers on Rideau Street in Ottawa. A small number appear to have been detained and taken away. Many are lined up, some on their knees and hugging and holding hands. Experts have said this is a tactic by protesters to argue that their occupation is peaceful and within their constitutional right to gather in protest.
One family, with several crying young children in tow, were led away by police after it appeared someone familiar to the family was arrested by police.
12:10 p.m. Ottawa police say “some protestors have put children in between police operations and the unlawful protest site. The children will be brought to a place of safety,” according to a tweet Friday afternoon.
11:58 a.m. Ottawa police say 15 people have been arrested and at least four vehicles towed on Friday. Police say Nicholas Street has been “cleared” as “police operations continue on Rideau St.”
Some protesters are linking hands, chanting “stand with us” at the approaching police units. Elsewhere, near the intersection of Metcalfe and Wellington, music has stopped and an emcee alerted protesters that police were headed their way, according to Star journalists on the ground. “We’re not doing anything wrong, as long as we stay peaceful, we’re allowed to be here,” said a protestor on a mic at the makeshift soundstage.
11:31 a.m. (updated) Heavily armed RCMP officers in armoured vehicles appear to be moving in near the Rideau Centre in Ottawa, followed by a long line of police SUV vehicles. A large number of police officers have gathered on the street. A handful of people have linked arms at the front of the blockade singing Oh Canada, some on their knees, met with a wall of police officers in bright yellow vests on Rideau Street between Sussex Drive and Nicholas Street.
Protesters appear to be sharing information among themselves of the heavy police presence and towing of vehicles, with some making their way towards where police and protesters are facing off.
11:15 a.m. The Children’s Aid Society of Ottawa says it is working closely alongside police to help ensure the safety and well-being of children in downtown Ottawa.
The society says it has not yet had to intervene with regard to children or youth connected to the demonstration, nor have any been transferred to the care of the society.
It says that as police action unfolds, parents involved should make the necessary alternate care arrangements for their children.
11:13 a.m. Police have started towing trucks away from an area on the eastern edge of Ottawa’s downtown core.
Tow trucks could be seen moving the vehicles from Nicholas Street after making arrests there earlier this morning.
Police say other people who have taken part in the three-week-long protest in Ottawa have decided to leave on their own accord.
They are warning anyone who doesn’t leave may be arrested.
But not everyone is ready to leave.
One trucker parked by the city’s Rideau Centre shopping mall says he is willing to get arrested before moving.
On Kent Street, near the western edge of the core, two protesters say they don’t plan to leave either.
One, who only provided his first name, Dave, says he expects thousands of people to pour back into the core this weekend despite the 100 checkpoints that police have set up to prevent anyone from joining the convoy.
Asked about the police warnings, Dave says it’s a little nerve-racking, but adds that protesters are peaceful people.
11:10 a.m. In Coutts, Alberta RCMP seized a number of weapons, firearms ammunition, as well as police-issued body armour in an overnight raid on a number of trailers associated with blockade. A number of people were arrested and taken into custody. An RCMP spokesperson also said one its officers was nearly struck when someone tried to ram a police cruiser and attempted to drive through a police blockade on Friday.
11:03 a.m. (updated) Ottawa police are warning once again of a “concerted effort to flood our 911” lines, adding that this puts lives in danger.“It is a crime to unnecessarily call 911 or our non-emergency number… We track calls and will charge anyone deliberately interfering with emergencies,” they said on Twitter.
Police say they are tracking calls and will charge anyone who is deliberately interfering with emergencies.
Police also say that if protesters choose to leave the area but cannot move their vehicles, they will be towed to a location where protesters can pick them up.
10:40 a.m. Pat King, another organizer and prominent supporter of the protests, streamed a video on Facebook Friday morning, during which he called for demonstrators to take cabs and Uber rides into the downtown core and to lie at checkpoints to say they live or work in the area.
He also urged any drivers in the area to use their vehicles to block a road where he said tow trucks were amassing to help police clear the parked protesters.
King threatened tow truck operators working with police that he would find out who they are.
“Your soul just got sold to the devil, and you’re going to find out whose tow trucks did what,” he said. “You’re committing friggin’ career suicide right now... They paid you a s—-ton of cash, and we know it. Bad, bad, bad.”
King also mentioned organizers have a “contingency plan” and asked protesters to follow it if needed, suggesting they might call on them to “move.”
10:24 a.m. Protesters who are part of the convoy of trucks and other vehicles occupying Ottawa’s downtown area don’t appear to be in a hurry to leave. Occupiers can be seen dancing to music and enthusiastically waving Canadian flags in an intersection near Wellington Street.
9:38 a.m. (updated) Officials are warning Ottawa residents about commuting into the downtown core. LRT service has been paused with shuttle buses in operation, and access to the downtown area remains limited.
The OPP are informing drivers of ongoing road closures. A number of Highway 417 exits to downtown Ottawa are closed, including eastbound at Rochester, Kent, Metcalfe and Nicholas, and westbound at Bronson, Metcalfe, Nicholas and Vanier. The OPP say these closures are not checkpoints.
So far, the downtown streets are remarkably empty of people and other non-occupation vehicles. The majority of the people there are occupiers, police and journalists.
9:33 a.m. A line of police officers separate media from the convoy along Nicholas Street at the Mackenzie King Bridge in Ottawa. A heavy police presence is developing as more officers arrive. Some protesters are leaving willingly.
8:16 a.m. Ottawa police warned people on Friday about a large police presence on Nicholas Street. “Protesters are being advised to leave immediately. Some protesters are surrendering and are being arrested. We ask protesters to remain peaceful and lawful,” reads the tweet .
8:10 a.m. The lights on police vehicles are flickering in intersections across Ottawa’s downtown core Friday morning.
Officers are checking every vehicle looking to get into the secure area that spans roughly four square kilometres. Officers from provincial, national and other municipal forces are policing the perimeter with about 100 checkpoints to keep out anyone intent on joining the protest.
Trucks are idling on the street in front of Parliament Hill as a bitter winter storm pummels the national capital, covering vehicles in snow and ice.
8 a.m. Ottawa police say Tamara Lich, a key organizer of the convoy protest that has seized the city for weeks, has a court appearance scheduled Friday.
Police say Lich, 49, from Medicine Hat, Alta., has been charged with counselling to commit mischief.
Police say they issued a notice to protesters Thursday advising that anyone blocking streets or helping others to block them is committing a criminal offence and could be arrested. Protesters were also told to cease unlawful activity or they would face charges or fines.
7:40 a.m. Both chambers of Canada’s Parliament cancelled sittings Friday due to the ongoing police operation in Ottawa’s downtown city core.
The Commons was set to continue a historic second day of debate on the proclamation of a “public order emergency.” But on the advice of parliamentary security, both the Senate and the Commons have suspended work Friday.
Ottawa police, bolstered by outside forces, set up more than 100 checkpoints around the city, trying to prevent additional protesters from joining the convoy protest over the long weekend.
Ramps and routes into downtown Ottawa were closed overnight, with checkpoints set up and slowing traffic into the area. Only those who live or work there are permitted into the massive secure zone.
Read the full story from the Star’s Tonda MacCharles
6:55 a.m. The father of a man facing a charge of conspiracy to commit murder says his son had become increasingly radicalized online before he was arrested and accused of plotting to kill police officers in connection with the border blockade in Coutts, Alta.
In an hour-long interview at the Lethbridge home they share, Mike Lysak described the frustration he says he’s felt over the past two years watching his son, Chris, fall further and further into an online world of COVID-19 misinformation.
The Star spoke to Lysak and others connected to the arrests this week, in interviews that open a window into the journey that has led some of the accused to this point. Police have described the arrests as focusing on “a small, organized group” engaged in “dangerous criminal activity occurring away from the TV cameras” that “could have been deadly for citizens, protesters and officers.” Some of those interviewed called into question or outright rejected the RCMP’s characterization of events.
Read the full story from the Star’s Kieran Leavitt and Omar Mosleh
6:45 a.m. The Canadian Civil Liberties Association is taking the federal government to court over what it calls an “unprecedented” use of government powers by activating the Emergencies Act to end the protest that’s been occupying downtown Ottawa for more than two weeks.
The CCLA argues that Ottawa has bypassed democratic norms in using the act to deal with the protest, and that the situation hasn’t met the threshold needed to justify it, said spokesperson Abby Deshman. The association is now seeking to nullify the use of the act.
“We believe the federal government invocation of these power is unlawful and unconstitutional,” Deshman said Thursday.
Read the full story from the Star’s Jeremy Nuttall and Tonda MacCharles
6:41 a.m. An Ottawa judge has frozen the bank accounts and digital “wallets” of convoy leaders believed to hold more than $1 million in bitcoin and cryptocurrency after an extraordinary secret hearing.
Late Thursday, Ontario Superior Court Justice Calum MacLeod granted an injunction to a private citizens’ effort to stanch the flow of money that was a lifeline for the 21-day occupation of Ottawa.
MacLeod issued the sweeping order freezing all the digital assets and bank accounts of convoy leaders, several of whom are directors of a corporation they created three weeks ago.
Read the full story from the Star’s Tonda MacCharles
Friday 6 a.m. Ottawa is holding its collective breath as police appear ready to finally end the so called Freedom Convoy protest that has paralyzed a good chunk of the capital city’s downtown core for the past three weeks.
With significantly bolstered ranks municipal, provincial and national police officers have established a perimeter with about 100 checkpoints covering Ottawa’s downtown to keep out anyone intent on joining the protest this weekend.
They have also arrested a number people, including two organizers of the protest against COVID-19 public health measures. Tamara Lich was in custody Thursday night charged with counselling to commit mischief, while Chris Barber was also facing that charge along with charges of obstruction and counselling to commit obstruction.
As snow blanketed the city Thursday police spent much of the day going around warning protesters, once again, to pack up and pullout now, or else risk arrest and other tough sanctions.
But many demonstrators still refused to budge. And city residents, who have grown increasingly frustrated with their lives being upended by the protest, are now waiting to see if police will back up their words with action to take back the streets.
Thursday 10:40 p.m. Police in Ottawa have set up checkpoints throughout the downtown area to prevent protesters from entering the core of the capital.
Officers stationed throughout downtown can be seen peering into vehicle windows with their flashlights to ask travellers where they’re headed.
Interim police Chief Steve Bell says only people who aren’t protesting will be able to get downtown this weekend.
The police also appear to have shut down highway exits and light rail stops downtown.
Meanwhile, a lawyer for Tamara Lich, one of the protest organizers, says she has been charged with one count of counselling mischief and was still in custody following her arrest earlier tonight.

Police arrest two protest organizers: Officers patrol downtown Ottawa in greater numbers as force promises 'imminent' crackdown

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 18 Feb 2022: A.4.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/police-arrest-two-protest-organizers-officers/docview/2629658598/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Police+arrest+two+protest+organizers%3A+Officers+patrol+downtown+Ottawa+in+greater+numbers+as+force+promises+%27imminent%27+crackdown%3A+Officers+patrol+downtown+Ottawa+in+greater+numbers+as+force+promises+%27imminent%27+crackdown&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-02-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Parliament Hill now exists in two different - and conflicting - realities.
In one, a dangerous group of unlawful protesters face an "imminent" crackdown as police flex their muscle and politicians warn of grave consequences for those who don't leave now.
In the other: defiance, dancing and devotion to a cause that many in the remaining "Freedom Convoy" crowd see as a struggle between good and evil.
By late Thursday, police were patrolling the streets around Parliament Hill in greater numbers, issuing tickets to parked and idling vehicles, and had made several arrests.
Tamara Lich, a key convoy organizer who on Wednesday night suggested in an online video that her arrest was "inevitable," was taken into custody by police Thursday evening according to images posted on social media. Another top organizer, Chris Barber, was also arrested several hours earlier, according to media reports.
Keith Wilson, the lawyer representing the convoy, confirmed the arrests to The Canadian Press.
After allowing a protest against COVID-19 vaccination mandates and public health restrictions to turn into a weeks-long occupation of the capital's downtown, Ottawa police trumpeted a "hardened" stance on Thursday, armed with the special powers granted by the federal government's invocation for the first time of the Emergencies Act.
Interim Ottawa police Chief Steve Bell announced Thursday afternoon that "action is imminent" as officers from his and other police forces set up a perimeter around Parliament Hill and established a secured zone across a wide swath of downtown streets.
Ottawa police said only people who live or work in businesses in the city's downtown core will be allowed to go there.
Highway access into the city centre will also be restricted, with 100 police checkpoints scattered across the core to ensure additional protesters cannot descend on the capital for the fourth straight weekend of noisy and disruptive demonstrations.
"What I can tell you is that this weekend will look very different from the past three weekends," Bell said.
The province passed emergency regulations last week that declared 400-series highways as critical infrastructure, and allow police extraordinary powers to secure traffic flow.
Many more security fences were erected around Parliament and served as the backdrop to a bitterly divisive debate on the Trudeau government's declaration of a national "public order emergency."
Lawmakers will continue debating the need for emergency powers almost around the clock until it comes to a vote on Monday. The Sergeant at Arms sent MPs a note saying a police action would be happening on Friday.
While the vote could revoke the federal emergency proclamation, the new police powers it grants to establish no-go zones and ban travel to and from "unlawful assemblies" are already in force.
Emergency Preparedness Minister Bill Blair warned the protesters that the demonstration site was "no place for children."
"Take them home immediately," Blair said. "Take them to a safe place."
Outside, among the trucks on Wellington Street, two men laughed and played with toy trucks in a small, inflatable hot tub filled with bubbling water - a sight that the former chair of Ottawa's police board described in exasperation this week as a symbol of Ottawa's "carnival of chaos."
Elsewhere, protesters cooked food on a barbecue while parked transport trucks periodically erupted in bursts of honking. In front of the Prime Minister's Office, a man played a tuba in a crowd of dancing protesters. Another man with a harmonica and guitar delivered a rendition of Bob Dylan's "Blowin' In the Wind" from a stage beneath a Canadian flag flapping from the end of a large crane.
Derek Barnett, who came to the protest on Thursday from Orangeville, was walking near the Prime Minister's Office with his mother and her friend. Barnett wore a red baseball cap with the slogan, "Drain the Swamp!" - a phrase associated with former U.S. president Donald Trump that refers to alleged government corruption.
Barnett said he joined the protests because he wants all pandemic health restrictions lifted and questioned whether the police warnings about imminent arrests were real.
He also slammed Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for invoking the Emergencies Act to deal with what he believes to be a peaceful protest.
Asked whether he is willing to be arrested, Barnett said he would consider that a badge of honour.
"That would be my Purple Heart," he said, referring to an American military award given to those injured or killed in combat. "I'm a casualty of war at that point ... It does feel like 'good versus evil.'"
At 1 p.m., a solid cacophony of horns and train whistles blasted in unison for several minutes. It was a show of support to mark the prayers of a group of Christian protesters who had been walking around Parliament Hill every afternoon for the past seven days - a reference, some demonstrators explained, to the Biblical story of how the Israelites marched around the walls of Jericho before God made them fall.
"The Lord is on our side. We don't worry about it. I know Trudeau will come down too," said John Jonker, who owns a trucking company in Guelph, Ont., and came to the protests with a fleet of his fellow drivers.
In his view, the protesters' opposition to COVID-19 health restrictions is part of a "religious struggle" and he said he is convinced the "truth" of their cause will prevail, regardless of what police do.
Jonker said he was not worried about the police, expressing doubts that they would follow through on their threat to take action against the demonstrators.
"The police helped us get in here," he said, referring to a deal made by Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson that allowed truckers to move onto the street in front of Parliament from the residential streets where they initially parked.
Jonker also dismissed any concerns about warnings that the federal government could freeze assets such as his trucking company and personal bank accounts.
"We're not worried about that. You know why? They took our jobs away" - referring to the federal quarantine requirement for unvaccinated truckers crossing the Canada-U. S. border - "so our bank accounts are empty anyway.
"So what can they freeze? As long as we are honest, as long as we really speak the truth, we tell the truth, then we don't worry about it at all. They may take everything away."
A citizens' effort to oust the occupation also continued Thursday, with a class-action lawsuit expanded to include a number of individual protesters who publicly spoke out over the past three weeks, and 62 unnamed participants, identified as John or Jane Doe.
The lawsuit is seeking $306 million in damages, as well as legal costs.
Meanwhile, the federal government tried to make its case in the House of Commons for why it is necessary to resort to exceptional emergency powers to end the protest.
It presented documents accompanying the motion to support the emergency declaration that said the "situation across the country remains concerning, volatile and unpredictable."
For the first time, the government said, "threats were also made to block railway lines, which would result in significant disruptions" to trade corridors that carry $310 billion in goods each year.
While border blockades had been cleared and traffic had resumed at Coutts, Alta., and Emerson, Man., the government signalled the overall threat has not ended, and that democratic institutions in Canada were under attack.
"The protests have become a rallying point for anti-government and anti-authority, anti-vaccination, conspiracy theory and white supremacist groups throughout Canada and other Western countries. The protesters have varying ideological grievances, with demands ranging from an end to all public health restrictions to the overthrow of the elected government," the documents said.
Describing the chaos in Ottawa, it cited the resignation of Ottawa police chief Peter Sloly "in response to criticism of the police's response to the protests."
Several premiers opposed the use of the Emergencies Act within their territories, including Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Quebec. New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and PEI have said they don't believe their provinces require it. Others like Ontario and Newfoundland and Labrador supported the federal government's response.
While the Conservatives and Bloc Québécois oppose the move by Trudeau's minority government, it has the support of the New Democrats.
With files from Althia Raj and Robert Benzie

Tories send warning as debate over act begins

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 18 Feb 2022: A.6.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/tories-send-warning-as-debate-over-act-begins/docview/2629659137/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Tories+send+warning+as+debate+over+act+begins&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-02-18&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: The political division over the use of the federal Emergencies Act became as solidly entrenched as the concrete blocks now ringing Parliament Hill as debate over the unprecedented use of the law began Thursday in the House of Commons.
Where the Liberals argued threats to national security are so severe as to require time-limited but sweeping new powers for police and other authorities, the Conservatives saw a national unity crisis being fanned by the prime minister himself.
Using the act to create new rules and regulations aimed at ending a three-week-long occupation of the national capital is an erosion of the rights and freedoms of Canadians and a complete overreach, the Conservatives said Thursday.
"This is not a game," said interim Conservative Leader Candice Bergen as she laid out the reasons her party won't support the declaration of a public order emergency.
"It comes at the cost to Canadians' rights and freedoms," she said. "Parliament should not allow the prime minister to avoid responsibility in this way. I urge all members of this House, proceed with extreme caution."
But the Conservatives' own position did not escape attacks from the Liberals or the NDP, who continued to point out that many MPs have vocally supported the so-called Freedom Convoy in recent weeks, even as its rhetoric and harassment of local residents heated up.
A truck parked just across the street from the House of Commons bears a flag calling for Conservative MP Pierre Poilievre to become the next prime minister. Poilievre is so far the only candidate in the race to become his party's next leader.
What MPs will vote on specifically is a motion confirming a declaration of a public order emergency, a requirement of the Emergencies Act that was invoked on Monday night. With it came a slew of new policing and other powers to cut off and criminalize sources of funding for the protesters, as well as the ability for people to join in further protests and blockades.
Liberals insist that the Charter of Rights and Freedoms will be upheld and peaceful protests will be allowed to continue, but say the economic and social threats posed by the "Freedom Convoy" demonstrators must come to an end.
"We are not limiting people's freedom of expression. We are not limiting freedom of peaceful assembly. We are not preventing people from exercising their right to protest legally. We are, in fact, reinforcing the principles, values and institutions that keep all Canadians free," Trudeau said.
If MPs fail to vote in favour of the declaration, it would be revoked immediately.
For now, the New Democrats are on side, although Bloc Québécois Leader Yves-François Blanchet - who opposes the declaration - said he was going to talk to NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh to see if they could reach a "mutual understanding."
The Bloc opposes the emergency declaration on the grounds that it steps too far into Quebec's jurisdiction, and that the border blockades in Alberta and Windsor that have been used in part to justify its invocation were cleared without using any of the extra powers provided by the act.
The government could have found a strategy somewhere "between playing Pontius Pilate and attacking with the atomic bomb," Bloc MP Alain Therrien said at one point during the debate.
Singh has been pressed to defend his support of invoking the act by the Tories and BQ. They noted that then-NDP leader Tommy Douglas had opposed the use of the War Measures Act - the precursor to the Emergencies Act - in 1970, when prime minister Pierre Trudeau invoked it in response to the kidnapping and eventual murder of Quebec's deputy premier.
Singh said that while what's happening in the streets of Ottawa goes beyond a peaceful protest, questions must be asked about the failure of local police to solve the problem - and why it appeared some may even be in support of the demonstrations.
"Occupiers get hugs from the police, while Indigenous and racialized protesters are met with the barrel of a gun," he said.
The daylong debate seized on many elements of law, and the new rules, including pressure for the Liberals to provide further proof of their allegations of foreign extremist funding, and evidence of other steps they'd taken to try and solve the various protests prior to bringing out what the Tories called a "sledgehammer."
The debate will continue throughout the weekend, with the vote scheduled for 8 p.m. Monday.
CREDIT: Stephanie Levitz Toronto Star

Protesters remain defiant as police tighten ring around Parliament Hill

Publication info: Feb 17, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/protesters-remain-defiant-as-police-tighten-ring/docview/2629418180/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Protesters+remain+defiant+as+police+tighten+ring+around+Parliament+Hill&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA — Parliament Hill now exists in two different — and conflicting — realities.
In one, a dangerous group of unlawful protesters face an “imminent” crackdown as police flex their muscle and politicians warn of grave consequences for those who don’t leave now.
In the other: defiance, dancing and devotion to a cause that many in the remaining “Freedom Convoy” crowd see as a struggle between good and evil.
By late Thursday, police were patrolling the streets around Parliament Hill in greater numbers, issuing tickets to parked and idling vehicles, and had made several arrests.
Tamara Lich, a key convoy organizer who on Wednesday night suggested in an online video that her arrest was “inevitable,” was taken into custody by police Thursday evening according to images posted on social media. Another top organizer, Chris Barber, was also arrested several hours earlier, according to media reports that Ottawa police would not confirm.
After allowing a protest against COVID-19 vaccination mandates and public health restrictions to turn into a weeks-long occupation of the capital’s downtown, Ottawa police trumpeted a “hardened” stance on Thursday, armed with the special powers granted by the federal government’s invocation for the first time of the Emergencies Act.
Interim Ottawa police Chief Steve Bell announced Thursday afternoon that “action is imminent” as officers from his and other police forces set up a perimeter around Parliament Hill and established a secured zone across a wide swath of downtown streets.
Ottawa police said only people who live or work in businesses in the city’s downtown core will be allowed to go there.
Highway access into the city centre will also be restricted, with 100 police checkpoints scattered across the core to ensure additional protesters cannot descend on the capital for the fourth straight weekend of noisy and disruptive demonstrations.
“What I can tell you is that this weekend will look very different from the past three weekends,” Bell said.
The province passed emergency regulations last week that declared 400-series highways as critical infrastructure, and allow police extraordinary powers to secure traffic flow.
Many more security fences were erected around Parliament and served as the backdrop to a bitterly divisive debate on the Trudeau government’s declaration of a national “public order emergency.”
Lawmakers will continue debating the need for emergency powers almost around the clock until it comes to a vote on Monday. The Sergeant at Arms sent MPs a note saying a police action would be happening on Friday.
While the vote could revoke the federal emergency proclamation, the new police powers it grants to establish no-go zones and ban travel to and from “unlawful assemblies” are already in force.
Emergency Preparedness Minister Bill Blair warned the protesters that the demonstration site was “no place for children.”
“Take them home immediately,” Blair said. “Take them to a safe place.”
Outside, among the trucks on Wellington Street, two men laughed and played with toy trucks in a small, inflatable hot tub filled with bubbling water — a sight that the former chair of Ottawa’s police board described in exasperation this week as a symbol of Ottawa’s “carnival of chaos.”
Elsewhere, protesters cooked food on a barbecue while parked transport trucks periodically erupted in bursts of honking. In front of the Prime Minister’s Office, a man played a tuba in a crowd of dancing protesters. Another man with a harmonica and guitar delivered a rendition of Bob Dylan’s “Blowin’ In the Wind” from a stage beneath a Canadian flag flapping from the end of a large crane.
Derek Barnett, who came to the protest on Thursday from Orangeville, was walking near the Prime Minister’s Office with his mother and her friend. Barnett wore a red baseball cap with the slogan, “Drain the Swamp!” — a phrase associated with former U.S. president Donald Trump that refers to alleged government corruption.
Barnett said he joined the protests because he wants all pandemic health restrictions lifted, and questioned whether the police warnings about imminent arrests were real.
He also slammed Prime Minister Justin Trudeau for invoking the Emergencies Act to deal with what he believes to be a peaceful protest.
Asked whether he is willing to be arrested, Barnett said he would consider that a badge of honour.
“That would be my Purple Heart,” he said, referring to an American military award given to those injured or killed in combat. “I’m a casualty of war at that point … It does feel like ‘good versus evil.’”
At 1 p.m., a solid cacophony of horns and train whistles blasted in unison for several minutes. It was a show of support to mark the prayers of a group of Christian protesters who had been walking around Parliament Hill every afternoon for the past seven days — a reference, some demonstrators explained, to the Biblical story of how the Israelites marched around the walls of Jericho before God made them fall.
“The Lord is on our side. We don’t worry about it. I know Trudeau will come down too,” said John Jonker, who owns a trucking company in Guelph, Ont. and came to the protests with a fleet of his fellow drivers.
In his view, the protesters’ opposition to COVID-19 health restrictions is part of a “religious struggle” and he said he is convinced the “truth” of their cause will prevail, regardless of what police do.
Jonker said he was not worried about the police, expressing doubts that they would follow through on their threat to take action against the demonstrators.
“The police helped us get in here,” he said, referring to a deal made by Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson that allowed truckers to move onto the street in front of Parliament from the residential streets where they initially parked.
Jonker also dismissed any concerns about warnings that the federal government could freeze assets such as his trucking company and personal bank accounts.
“We’re not worried about that. You know why? They took our jobs away” — referring to the federal quarantine requirement for unvaccinated truckers crossing the Canada-U. S. border — “so our bank accounts are empty anyway.
“So what can they freeze? As long as we are honest, as long as we really speak the truth, we tell the truth, then we don’t worry about it at all. They may take everything away.”
A citizens’ effort to oust the occupation also continued Thursday, with a class-action lawsuit expanded to include a number of individual protesters who publicly spoke out over the past three weeks, and 62 unnamed participants, identified as John or Jane Doe.
The lawsuit is seeking $306 million in damages, as well as legal costs.
Meanwhile, the federal government tried to make its case in the House of Commons for why it is necessary to resort to exceptional emergency powers to end the protest.
It presented documents accompanying the motion to support the emergency declaration that said the “situation across the country remains concerning, volatile and unpredictable.”
For the first time, the government said, “threats were also made to block railway lines, which would result in significant disruptions” to trade corridors that carry $310 billion in goods each year.
While border blockades had been cleared and traffic had resumed at Coutts, Alberta, and Emerson, Manitoba, the government signalled the overall threat has not ended, and that democratic institutions in Canada were under attack.
“The protests have become a rallying point for anti-government and anti-authority, anti-vaccination, conspiracy theory and white supremacist groups throughout Canada and other Western countries. The protesters have varying ideological grievances, with demands ranging from an end to all public health restrictions to the overthrow of the elected government,” the documents said.
Describing the chaos in Ottawa, it cited the resignation of Ottawa Police chief Peter Sloly “in response to criticism of the police’s response to the protests.”
Several premiers opposed the use of the Emergencies Act within their territories, including Alberta, Saskatchewan, Manitoba and Quebec. New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and PEI have said they don’t believe their provinces require it. Others like Ontario and Newfoundland and Labrador supported the federal government’s response.
Trudeau again emphasized in his speech to the House of Commons on Thursday morning that the powers are both time-limited and targeted to certain regions.
While the Conservatives and Bloc Québécois oppose the move by Trudeau’s minority government, it has the support of the New Democrats, with NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh pointing to the convoy organizer’s stated goal of overthrowing the government.

Meet the top five Canadian donors to the 'Freedom Convoy'

Publication info: Feb 16, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/meet-top-five-canadian-donors-freedom-convoy/docview/2629418146/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Meet+the+top+five+Canadian+donors+to+the+%27Freedom+Convoy%27&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A B.C. gun range owner, a twice-bankrupt charity founder from Durham Region, a Donald Trump fan who owns a national chain of industrial cleaning warehouses and a former lawyer who now operates a popular lodge in Killarney are among the top five Canadian donors to the Ottawa “ Freedom Convoy. ”
Together, these five have donated more than $225,000 to the protesters who have occupied parts of downtown Ottawa for more than two weeks. They used the online platform GiveSendGo, which had its donor list leaked after being hacked last weekend.
The Star obtained the hacked donor data from the online whistleblower DDoSecrets, a website that hosts leaked data. The Star has independently confirmed the identities of many of the top donors.
In total, more than $10.7 million was donated through the GiveSendGo campaign, which said it was for food, fuel and shelter for the protesters. Of that total, $5.5 million came from Canadian sources. The bulk of the remaining money, some 40 per cent of the $10.7 million, was donated by Americans. (All donations were made in American funds.)
More than 36,000 Canadian donated, the vast majority in sums of $126 (that is, $100 US) or less. There were a small number of large donations. Eight people gave $12,691 or more.
Trevor Farrow, a professor at the Osgoode Hall Law School at York University, said crowdfunding has become an essential tool for many social movements and protest groups that otherwise have no access to the money needed to pay for things such as legal advice.
As part of the invoking of the Emergencies Act, the federal government is now requiring websites such as GiveSendGo to report more information to authorities investigating the protest.
Farrow said the federal government is understandably examining how the protests are being funded. However, he cautioned that using a hammer instead of scalpel when regulating crowdfunding could have a detrimental impact on legitimate protest movements.
Brad Howland
The single largest Canadian donor to the campaigns was Brad Howland, 54, the owner of Easy Kleen Pressure Systems, a large power-washing company in Sussex Corner, N.B. The company also has offices in Edmonton and Red Deer, Alta., as well as in Cambridge and Concord, Ont.
Howland donated about $95,000 to the GiveSendGo campaign, writing “HOLD THE LINE!!!” in the comments.
An unabashed fan of former U.S. president Donald Trump, Howland has posted photos of himself on social media wearing a Trump baseball cap. The profile photo on his Facebook page is of Howland standing at a replica of the lectern at the White House press room beside a cardboard cutout of Trump.
Howland declined to be interviewed for this story. However, in a statement posted to the Easy Kleen website, he said he donated in part because so many truckers have used his company’s services and “how the government and the media portray them is not true.”
While the protest-turned-occupation are not representative of the trucking industry — some 90 per cent of Canadian truckers are vaccinated and working — Howland states he believes he is supporting them in their time of need.
“We thank them when we can, but rarely get to support them when they are in need, and they are in need right NOW,” wrote Howland. “We drove to Ottawa and witnessed the protest for ourselves. They have a beautiful, legal peaceful protest that overwhelmed us with emotion.”
From 2008 until 2021, Easy Kleen was awarded more than $92,000 in federal contracts. The last contract was a 2021 deal with Parks Canada for more than $13,000 in parts and equipment, according to federal records.
According to federal government records, the company also received money under the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy to offset pandemic losses in revenue. The records do not show how much money the company received.
Anonymous
The GiveSendGo data shows that a donation of more than $50,000 was made by a person who entered a postal code from Coldwater, Ont. However, the Star has not been able to reach this person or confirm their identity. The fundraising data shows this person made two donations of about $25,000, the first on Feb. 5 and the second on Feb 6.
Holden Rhodes
Ex-lawyer Holden Rhodes, who made a fortune when his car history company was sold for $650 million in 2015, is the source of the third largest Canadian donation on the list.
The owner of several outdoor resorts on Georgian Bay, including The Sportsman Inn and the Killarney Mountain Lodge , donated about $31,000.
Rhodes, 55, added a comment to his donation: “Freedom first. All else follows.”
Contacted by the Star, Rhodes defended the “Freedom Convoy” against the negative characterizations made by politicians and the media.
The protest “is hardly a ‘fringe minority’ as our prime minister has been calling the folks who believe in freedom,” Rhodes wrote in an email. “While there have (been) a few large donations like mine and larger, most of the donations are smaller showing the magnitude and breadth of the people financially supporting this movement.”
“While it started as a protest to the Jan 15 federal requirement that truckers had to prove vaccination when crossing the CDN/US border … the movement has exponentially grown and at the core it is about freedom,” he wrote. “As of today, 90% of all eligible Ontarians are double vaccinated — what more does the government want?”
“The overreach on the last two years has been astounding, but in the last two weeks in Canada it has been absolutely alarming for anyone believes in a peaceful and free society,” wrote Rhodes. “Freedom is rightfully restricted by reasonable laws that have at their core protections that are framed by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. I am not prepared to accept a country without freedom for my family, my children, my friends, my neighbours and every other Canadian. That is why I am doing what I am doing.”
Rhodes has made several political donations in recent years, both to the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario. In 2017, he donated $1,200 to the provincial London North-Centre PC riding association. In 2016, he donated $500 to the PC Party of Ontario.
David Slabodkin
David Slabodkin, a philanthropist and former insurance executive who was found by a judge to have cheated an elderly woman out of her house decades ago, made a donation of over $25,000.
Slabodkin, 64, now lives in Cannington, Ont., just southeast of Lake Simcoe, where he has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to local charities and founded one of his own, through a trust fund set up in his name.
The Nourish and Develop Foundation runs a food bank, women’s shelter and community garden as part of its anti-poverty work in Cannington. In a statement posted to its website, the organization said Slabodkin made the convoy donation with “personal funds” and it “is not connected in any way to TNDF values or operations.”
Slabodkin did not respond to emails or messages from the Star.
Provincial records show he has donated to all three political parties. In 2018, he gave a total of $3,666 to the provincial NDP, its Sudbury riding association and now-MPP Jamie West. The same year, he gave $1,222 to the Haliburton-Kawartha Lakes-Brock PC Riding Association and another $1,222 to PC candidate and now-MPP Laurie Scott. In 2017, he gave $1,200 to the Ontario Liberal party.
In 2017, Slabodkin sent $30,000 to Wapekeka First Nation in northern Ontario after hearing about the deaths by suicide of two 12-year-old girls. He later pledged $380,000 for a suicide-prevention plan, but revoked the donation after learning that the federal government would fund the project, according to the CBC.
Prior to starting his own insurance business, Canada Protection Plan (which he has now sold), Slabodkin appeared to have had a more difficult time with money. In the 1980s, while working as a contractor, he declared bankruptcy. Several years later, he was sued by an 88-year-old woman after her granddaughter found her forged signature on a sales document that transferred her house to Slabodkin.
He testified that he had brought her $175,000 in cash in a paper bag before she signed over the Toronto house. Slabodkin later took out a $150,000 mortgage on the property in Lawrence Park.
A judge ruled that it was impossible to believe that Slabodkin paid the “confused” woman who “could only read with the assistance of an illuminated magnifying glass and who was hard of hearing.”
A judge reversed the sale of the house to Slabodkin and ordered him to pay the mortgage provider $191,000. A year after the judgment, Slabodkin declared bankruptcy again, with $569,400 in debts.
Dustin Sikora
Dustin Sikora, the 40-year-old owner of an indoor shooting range in Langley, B.C., donated about $23,000.
Sikora posted his business’s name — The Range Langley — with his donation, adding a quote attributed to Benjamin Franklin: “Those who would give up essential liberty, to purchase a little temporary safety, deserve neither liberty nor safety.”
Sikora did not respond to repeated requests for comment.
The range’s website states that it is “owned and operated by active and retired Canadian military and law enforcement.” The Department of Defence was unable to confirm whether Sikora had served with Canada’s military before deadline.
Earlier this week, a statement on the donation was posted to the website.
“Our donation to the Freedom Convoy 2022 is our way of peacefully participating in democracy. For whatever reason, some may disagree with our beliefs and support for this cause. That is their Right. We will always defend the Rights of those that disagree with us,” it read. “We warn all Canadians to be aware of anyone that accuses their dissenters as being ‘dangerous’ and use such labels as justification to take their Right to peaceful protest away.”
Correction — Feb. 17, 2022: This article was edited to correct that Holden Rhodes is owner of the Killarney Mountain Lodge. A previous version stated it was the Killarney Lodge.
With files from Josh Rubin

Martin Regg Cohn: We should judge Doug Ford on his record as premier, not on his daughter's behaviour

Publication info: Feb 16, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/martin-regg-cohn-we-should-judge-doug-ford-on-his/docview/2629418179/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Martin+Regg+Cohn%3A+We+should+judge+Doug+Ford+on+his+record+as+premier%2C+not+on+his+daughter%27s+behaviour&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-16&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: For the first time as premier, Doug Ford has publicly acknowledged the personal family matter that has long been public knowledge.
In fact, he raised it himself — not in answer to a reporter’s question, more in reply to his own daughter’s public questioning.
Reading from a teleprompter, Ford talked about the latest anti-government protests in Windsor and Ottawa. Then he raised his own family strife closer to home.
The premier never mentioned Krista Ford Haynes by name, but he sent a message to his adult daughter all the same.
“One of the hardest things about this pandemic is the way it’s fractured us as a society,” he said at a Monday news conference .
“I’ve experienced this in my own family. It’s been one of the hardest things my family and I have ever gone through.”
Speaking the next day, Ford even had trouble getting out the word “family” when describing the impact, briefly choking up in front of reporters: “Man it’s challenging, especially on the fam... on the family side.”
The public taunting by the 30-year-old daughter of Ontario’s 26th premier is an old story, long circulating on social media where she posts anti-vax, anti-lockdown messages that accuse those in authority — that would be her father — of overreacting to what she views as an overstated risk of COVID-19 and an underrated danger of vaccines.
Her early musings were picked up by small media outlets, but as she has become evermore vocal, the story has creeped into coverage by major publications.
The Star and the Globe and Mail wrote about her antics late last year, when the attacks escalated after her husband Dave Haynes was put on unpaid leave by the Toronto police for refusing to disclose his vaccination status. In one post, she poses on her exercise bicycle for the camera, pedalling and perspiring while peddling conspiracy theories and denouncing evildoers.
It is uncomfortable viewing for the leader of the province.
“I do believe the people behind all of this will be held accountable — don’t know when, but I truly believe God wins,” she says into the camera. “Evil does not win.”
Along the way, she has capitalized on the attention she gets from the Ford family name. At one public protest, she was advertised as “Krista Haynes, family of the premier Doug Ford.”
More recently, she has publicly supported the anti-government protests and posted a photo of herself on Instagram holding a Canadian flag scrawled with the words, “F - - - Trudeau.”
If you want to see for yourself, you can search for yourself online. But that hasn’t stopped those who follow such matters from accusing the mass media of protecting the premier and his family from public ridicule by somehow suppressing the details.
In truth, I haven’t written about it until now because I’ve never believed the sins of the father should be visited upon the son — or daughter. Nor should the online spin of the progeny be visited upon the premier.
There’s also a logical contradiction: If she keeps complaining that the father isn’t abiding by her views, then it’s hard to accuse the premier of being under her influence, let alone prone to a conflict of interest.
In any case, the premier did distance herself from his eldest daughter in December by pointedly avoiding the customary family photo with all four daughters in his annual Christmas card. As the Star’s Robert Benzie wrote at the time , the omission and the situation were “personally painful” to him.
While the premier has not denounced her, he has pointedly bounced other members of his wider political family — Progressive Conservative MPPs and staff — for contradicting government policy: on Tuesday, his government parted ways with a senior member of the solicitor general’s political staff over a $100 donation to the convoy protest; previously, Ford’s Tories expelled MPP Rick Nicholls from caucus for refusing to get vaccinated, and Belinda Karahalios for opposing pandemic restrictions.
Asked for comment about the father-daughter conflict, the premier’s office said his public statement speaks for itself. Also, “his actions speak for themselves.”
But at a certain point, I believe readers deserve to understand the background references in a public conversation, notably when the premier talks about it at a public event.
All that said, many a Ford critic has insisted in emails and tweets that too much has been left unsaid. They argue that the public has a right to know precisely how the premier has been influenced by his adult daughter in the pandemic decision-making process.
Whatever one thinks of Ford’s policies and politics, they do not line up with his daughter’s posts. Even if he has been personally affected by the dispute, there are no signs he has been deflected off course by her arguments.
The premier is not the first political leader to wrestle with the balance between publicity and privacy. They all walk a fine line — one moment trotting out family for platitudes and photo-ops, years later retreating to expectations of privacy.
One Christmas it’s a family photo. The next Christmas the daughters are out of the picture.
For whatever reason — perhaps trying to get the story out there and behind him with an election campaign looming, or possibly just to get it off his chest — Ford has opened the door and, in his own way, invited Ontarians to once again peer into the family’s internal tensions. Now that we know more about what the father thinks of his eldest daughter’s thoughts, back to the bigger question of where the premier is taking the province.
If Ford the elder falls short on COVID-19 or other measures, it surely has more to do with his own shortcomings than those of his eldest daughter.
Martin Regg Cohn is a Toronto-based columnist focusing on Ontario politics and international affairs for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @reggcohn

CREDIT: Martin Regg Cohn

'Proceed with extreme caution': Conservatives send warning as Emergencies Act debate begins

Publication info: Feb 17, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/proceed-with-extreme-caution-conservatives-send/docview/2629418102/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=%27Proceed+with+extreme+caution%27%3A+Conservatives+send+warning+as+Emergencies+Act+debate+begins&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA — The political division over the use of the federal Emergencies Act became as solidly entrenched as the concrete blocks now ringing Parliament Hill as debate over the unprecedented use of the law began Thursday in the House of Commons.
Where the Liberals argued threats to national security are so severe as to require time-limited but sweeping new powers for police and other authorities, the Conservatives saw a national unity crisis being fanned by the prime minister himself.
Using the act to create new rules and regulations aimed at ending a three-week-long occupation of the national capital is an erosion of the rights and freedoms of Canadians and a complete overreach, the Conservatives said Thursday.
“This is not a game,” said interim Conservative Leader Candice Bergen as she laid out the reasons her party won’t support the declaration of a public order emergency.
“It comes at the cost to Canadians’ rights and freedoms,” she said. “Parliament should not allow the prime minister to avoid responsibility in this way. I urge all members of this House, proceed with extreme caution.”
But the Conservatives’ own position did not escape attacks from the Liberals or the NDP, who continued to point out that many MPs have vocally supported the so-called Freedom Convoy in recent weeks, even as its rhetoric and harassment of local residents heated up.
A truck parked just across the street from the House of Commons bears a flag calling for Conservative MP Pierre Poilievre to become the next prime minister. Poilievre is so far the only candidate in the race to become his party’s next leader.
What MPs will vote on specifically is a motion confirming a declaration of a public order emergency, a requirement of the Emergencies Act that was invoked by the government on Monday night.
With it came a slew of new policing and other powers to cut off and criminalize sources of funding for the protesters, as well as the ability for people to join in further protests and blockades.
Liberals insist that the Charter of Rights will be upheld and peaceful protests will be allowed to continue, but say the economic and social threats posed by the “Freedom Convoy” demonstrators must come to an end.
“We are not limiting people’s freedom of expression. We are not limiting freedom of peaceful assembly. We are not preventing people from exercising their right to protest legally. We are, in fact, reinforcing the principles, values and institutions that keep all Canadians free,” Trudeau said.
If MPs fail to vote in favour of the declaration, it would be revoked immediately.
For now, the New Democrats are on side, although Bloc Québécois Leader Yves-Francois Blanchet — who opposes the declaration — said he was going to talk to NDP Leader Jagmeet Singh to see if they could reach a “mutual understanding.”
The Bloc opposes the emergency declaration on the grounds that it steps too far into Quebec’s jurisdiction, and that the border blockades in Alberta and Windsor that have been used in part to justify its invocation were cleared without using any of the extra powers provided by the act.
The government could have found a strategy somewhere “between playing Pontius Pilate and attacking with the atomic bomb,” Bloc MP Alain Therrien said at one point during the debate.
Singh has been pressed to defend his support of invoking the act by the Tories and BQ. They noted that then-NDP leader Tommy Douglas had opposed the use of the War Measures Act — the precursor to the Emergencies Act — in 1970, when prime minister Pierre Trudeau invoked it in response to the kidnapping and eventual murder of Quebec’s deputy premier.
Singh said that while what’s happening in the streets of Ottawa goes beyond a peaceful protest, questions must be asked about the failure of local police to solve the problem — and why it appeared some may even be in support of the demonstrations.
“Occupiers get hugs from the police, while Indigenous and racialized protesters are met with the barrel of a gun,” he said.
The daylong debate seized on many elements of law, and the new rules, including pressure for the Liberals to provide further proof of their allegations of foreign extremist funding, and evidence of other steps they’d taken to try and solve the various protests prior to bringing out what the Tories called a “sledgehammer.”
The debate will continue throughout the weekend, with the vote scheduled for 8 p.m. Monday.
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

Doug Ford's shell game involving licence stickers fools no one

Publication info: Feb 17, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/doug-fords-shell-game-involving-licence-stickers/docview/2629283866/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Doug+Ford%27s+shell+game+involving+licence+stickers+fools+no+one&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-17&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: A billion for re-election, Feb. 10
This shameless intent of vote-buying by Doug Ford is reminiscent of when Jean Chrétien came to power federally, with the promise to scrap the hated GST; but, Chrétien had added as a qualifier: “I need the money.”
So the politicians just get the same money, or more, elsewhere, from the beleaguered taxpayer.
What a shameful distortion of democracy!
If his scheme carries the day (election), we certainly won’t be any better of, be it financially or politically.
Wulf Graunitz , Palgrave, Ont.
