____________________________________________________________

For the Conservatives, firing Erin O'Toole is an opportunity, not a crisis

Publication info: Feb 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/conservatives-firing-erin-otoole-is-opportunity/docview/2625375778/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=For+the+Conservatives%2C+firing+Erin+O%27Toole+is+an+opportunity%2C+not+a+crisis&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Since the Conservative caucus dumped Erin O’Toole as leader on Wednesday, some have suggested the party is now doomed — that its best chance for mainstream electability was thrown out the window, and that by courting its populist and social conservative flanks, the party relegates itself to a longer stint on the opposition benches. I believe this is too simplistic a read on what happened and ignores the opportunity ahead.
The move to show O’Toole the door was an overwhelming condemnation of O’Toole himself. As one caucus member put it to me Thursday, “He’s a hypocrite.” The vote was not a condemnation of the more centrist approach O’Toole espoused, it was a denunciation of his performance. Yes, social conservatives are upset with O’Toole. But he betrayed them by courting their support during the leadership race by pretending to be a candidate he had no plans to be.
Discussions about the Conservative party often focus on the challenge of having a large base of social conservatives. They are very influential, and they are organized. Activists dominate many riding associations. They stack delegate nomination meetings to ensure their own supporters vote at party conventions. They’re important volunteers who can either help elect candidates or mount challenges against sitting MPs during nomination battles. They are also an important donor base.
But they have not — yet —been the majority of the party.
If O’Toole ran his leadership campaign in 2020 on the platform he presented to Canadians during the 2021 election campaign — pro-choice, in favour of carbon pricing and a temporary ban on assault-style weapons —he would have run to the left of Peter MacKay, a pro-choice candidate, and lost.
O’Toole only became leader by being the second choice of supporters of Derek Sloan and Leslyn Lewis. With two pro-choice candidates, it’s safe to assume social conservatives would have left the rest of their preferential ballots blank.
The last time abortion was debated at a Conservative convention was in 2018. The motion, to delete a line in the policy book stating a Conservative government will not support any legislation to regulate abortion, was defeated by a vote of 53 per cent against. Tight, uncomfortably so, but still a defeat. In 2016, 70 per cent of Conservative delegates voted to strike the definition of marriage as a union between one man and one woman from the Tories’ policy book.
The message here is clear: the party belongs to those who show up. The fight for what becomes of the Conservative party will happen over the next several months. The next leader will set the tone, the policy priorities, and the parameters of the party’s coalition.
If those who are socially progressive and fiscally conservative sit out the fight, that coalition may be dominated by the social conservatives and far-right populists who some in the party now seem preoccupied in courting. So, find desirable candidates. Sell memberships. The formula is not complicated.
It took the Liberals two tries and a near-death experience after Paul Martin to land on Justin Trudeau. The Conservatives are not doomed. They just need to find someone willing to step up and do the work that’s required to build a party that reflects the country.
There should be a Conservative leader unafraid to denounce the truck convoy occupying Ottawa. Someone willing to say people have the right to peaceful assembly, but it doesn’t look like this. A leader who expresses alarm at the presence of Nazi and Confederate flags, and doesn’t just refer to the people waving them as “bad apples.”
It should also be possible to have a leader capable of empathy —one who says people who lose their jobs because they refuse to be vaccinated, for whatever reason, should have access to a job bank where employers don’t require vaccinations. That the country’s safety net includes all Canadians, not just those whose views we agree with.
(To be clear, I remain convinced that not getting vaccinated is a selfish position. The “freedom” signs lining the fence of the parliamentary precinct might as well say “Let more people die” or “Undermine health care.” But I also think many who refuse to get vaccinated are scared and misinformed, and I don’t think they should lose their houses or have their children go hungry.)
Some of the names currently being tossed around as potential Conservative leaders concern me. I hope the Tories don’t settle on a divisive leader who spreads misinformation convincingly.
Canada needs a broad-based party that can challenge the Liberals for power. Not only do the voters deserve choice, but this will help prevent the Grits from being lazy and ensure more accountable government.
It is in all our interests that the Tories pick well.
Althia Raj is an Ottawa-based national politics columnist for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @althiaraj

Mississauga city officials must be held accountable for failing to support Karen Ras after repeated harassment

Publication info: Feb 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/mississauga-city-officials-must-be-held/docview/2625375956/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Mississauga+city+officials+must+be+held+accountable+for+failing+to+support+Karen+Ras+after+repeated+harassment&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Mississauga councillor Ron Starr needs to resign and city officials — including Mayor Bonnie Crombie — must be held accountable for failing to support Karen Ras .
Crombie, who never shies from journalists, TV cameras or scrums, is suddenly unavailable for media interviews.
She seems to be taking a page from Premier Doug Ford’s playbook.
This comes following allegations of harassment and vandalism by Starr, which contributed to Ras’s abrupt resignation last month , to the dismay of her Ward 2 constituents.
Council met on Feb. 2, planning to discuss whether the next Ward 2 councillor will be appointed or elected in a byelection.
To no one’s surprise, council appointed a familiar face to fill in ahead of the Oct. 24 election: Pat Mullin.
She preceded Ras, and spent 29 years in office before retiring in 2014.
But a CBC News story released early that morning accused a sitting councillor of harassing and intimidating Ras — without initially naming him .
Throughout the day, details emerged and further investigation — including one by Torstar — identified Starr as the alleged vandal caught on camera keying Ras’s SUV in an underground parking garage at the civic centre in April 2021.
He’s now taking a leave of absence at the request of council.
There were eight documented cases of vandalism, violence and harassment in the workplace.
Ras contacted Peel Regional Police and complained to city hall security, leading to cameras being installed.
Criminal charges weren’t laid. Ras told Torstar the $1,250 repair bill was paid by Starr. How noble of him.
Reimbursement aside, this is hardly behaviour one would deem appropriate from a long-time city councillor. If Starr worked in the private sector, he’d already be fired.
The Municipal Act encompasses a code of conduct addressing respectful behaviour by council. Ras, however, has been shown nothing but disrespect.
Mayor Crombie’s silence and failure to demonstrate leadership during this debacle is damning. Meanwhile, the city’s corporate communications team is in full crisis-management mode.
“Neither council or the corporation of the City of Mississauga condone the alleged actions by one of our city councillors or any harassment or bullying at city facilities,” said Crombie via a news release issued after 5 p.m. on Feb. 2.
“We take seriously the safety of all our employees, members of council and everyone who visits the City Hall precinct. Through this investigation, we will get the answers council and the public demand and deserve.”
If that were true, Crombie would’ve immediately addressed this matter, long before it was exposed by the press. Where was the investigation when Ras needed it most?
Then, Crombie had the audacity to tweet about the latest developments after the news release went out, making sure to add Ras’s name: “In light of the serious allegations involving Councillor Ron Starr, @citymississauga Council voted unanimously today for our IC to open an investigation into the matter. Through this, we will get the answers that Karen Ras, the public and Council demand and deserve.”
So now integrity commissioner Robert Swayze can open an investigation, only after a flurry of explosive press coverage? Why wasn’t this brought before council months ago? And when will Swayze investigate Crombie’s inaction regarding this very serious matter?
Council’s code of conduct has to be amended — as soon as possible — to address harassment among colleagues.
In addition, councillors cannot be allowed to “police themselves,” as Ras succinctly put it.
Ras deserved answers and recourse months ago, and Crombie doesn’t get to spin this and act like she’s suddenly all for transparency.
This fiasco could signal the end of Crombie’s mayoral reign. Crombie cruised to victory in 2014 after being endorsed by former mayor Hazel McCallion, and has had an easy run — until now.
Ward 2 voters — home to the city’s wealthiest and most demanding taxpayers — and residents across Mississauga, including Starr’s Ward 6, are fuming and voicing their concerns on social media.
But tweeting and posting in local Facebook groups isn’t nearly enough action. They need to take their grievances — about Starr, Crombie and the council code of conduct — to the Office of the Ombudsman of Ontario.
“Anyone who has an unresolved administrative issue with a municipality is welcome to make a complaint to our office at www.ombudsman.on.ca ,” said spokesperson Linda Williamson in an email.
Finally, Crombie needs to stop hiding, and publicly apologize to Ras and the furious taxpayers who dutifully elected her — and watched Ras get kicked to the curb.
Kelly Roche is the former reporter, editor and publisher of hyperlocal news site QEWSouthPost.com . She teaches journalism in Toronto.

____________________________________________________________

The inside story of the plot to topple Erin O'Toole: 'It's about character'

Publication info: Feb 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/inside-story-plot-topple-erin-otoole-about/docview/2625376174/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=The+inside+story+of+the+plot+to+topple+Erin+O%27Toole%3A+%27It%27s+about+character%27&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA — For some Conservatives, it became clear more than a year ago that Erin O’Toole wasn’t going to survive as leader of their party.
O’Toole himself didn’t realize it until hours before he was ousted.
In that chasm between O’Toole and many members of his party — and the breakdown of good will and communication that created it — lie the reasons that 73 of 119 Conservative MPs voted on Wednesday to kick him out.
Some say it was O’Toole’s flip-flops that did him in, others his attempt to move the party to the centre. Some say it was his stance on conversion therapy, others his failure to consult and communicate. Some say his leadership was a casualty of the pandemic.
One common thread that emerged from interviews with Conservative MPs, party staffers, organizers and others with long-standing ties to the party was perhaps best encapsulated by rookie MP Stephen Ellis:
“Democracy is a messy, messy way to do work.”
O’Toole won leadership in August 2020, beating out the presumed front-runner Peter MacKay by appealing to the right wing of the party as a “true blue” Conservative and hoovering up support from social conservatives who felt alienated by MacKay’s progressive approach.
In his victory speech, he pledged a renewed conservative movement, one that welcomed more Canadians, and many party members nodded in agreement.
In the months following that speech, however, O’Toole sidelined supporters of his rivals in the leadership contest, going so far as to kick one rival — Derek Sloan — out of the Conservative caucus altogether.
Then in March 2021, he gave a speech to the party’s policy convention — and while some of its themes echoed his victory speech in August, his “true blue” credentials had already begun to fade in the eyes of the party’s membership.
In the August speech, the grassroots heard words of optimism and renewal; in March, they heard insults as O’Toole emphasized the need for the party to have courage, and to prove to voters that it had grown and learned.
“We could get onside with moving the party, but not with being told there was something wrong with us,” said one longtime MP.
“We’re a big tent party, we always have been. But he started creating camps in that tent with that speech.”
Next came carbon pricing. A month after the convention, without warning or briefing any of his MPs, O’Toole dropped a bombshell : the Tories were going to embrace the idea of putting a consumer price on carbon.
“Look, I hate carbon taxes,” one MP told the Star this week. “Maybe he never could have convinced me it was the right approach, but he didn’t even give us the dignity of being part of the conversation.”
At that moment, the bonds of trust between the leader and his party’s MPs began to break.
The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic was also throwing up its own challenges.
The Conservative MPs elected in 2019 included many rookies who’d barely taken their seats in the House of Commons before the country closed its doors; another group followed in 2021, when pandemic restrictions remained.
Conservative MP Alex Ruff, a longtime O’Toole supporter, said the team-building necessary for new MPs under a new leader was impossible in the Zoom era.
In his view, what happened in the last week of O’Toole’s leadership was a reflection of the pandemic.
“This was about two years of being locked up, frustrated and without being able to come together in person as a team,” he said.
People close to O’Toole now acknowledge that he never had a good enough read on his MPs, often minimizing issues and problems or catching up with them too late.
At the point in last summer’s election campaign when the Conservatives were on track to potentially form a minority government, many figured that a victory would help soothe some of the ongoing tensions.
Except O’Toole didn’t win.
And even as he struck an optimistic tone in the days that followed, his supporters sensed that the beginning of the end could be upon them.
“It was one and done,” said a long-time Conservative organizer. “That was the precedent set for Andrew Scheer, and that’s what was going to happen to us.”
Nonetheless, his team thought they could make it to 2023, when O’Toole would face the leadership review required by the party’s constitution. With enough time, some felt they could still turn the ship around.
Deputizing defeated MP James Cumming to conduct a review of the campaign’s failings would give them time to present a plan and a path forward, O’Toole’s team believed. Maybe they could convince the caucus — and the party’s members — to give him another chance.
It seemed to help that many Conservatives believe in the right of the party’s grassroots to handle all matters of leadership.
That’s why, in their first meeting of the post-election era, the Conservative MPs were not unanimously in favour of adopting a provision of the Reform Act which gives a party’s MPs the power to call for a leadership review if 20 per cent of caucus wants one.
But the provision was adopted nonetheless. At the time, O’Toole said it was a not a “sword of Damocles” hanging over his head — but that was exactly what it became.
Getting 20 per cent of caucus to sign up took time but, in the end, not as much as even the organizers anticipated.
The irritants had piled up: A snap motion to push a bill banning conversion therapy all the way to the Senate; an apparent flip-flop over mandatory COVID-19 vaccinations on Parliament Hill; a leak of a damaging story about Alberta MP Shannon Stubbs, in what was perceived as retribution for her call for an earlier leadership review.
What his MPs saw as signs of disrespect were considered by O’Toole’s team to be the necessary work of bringing a restive group to heel.
Closing out 2021 was the “bloodbath” in a December caucus meeting over Quebec’s Bill 21, which prohibits those in positions of public authority from wearing religious symbols at work.
That meeting would set the course for the final days of O’Toole’s leadership.
A motion was put up for debate at the next meeting that would see the party condemn Bill 21 in no uncertain terms — even though the party’s official policy was that Quebec lawmakers had the right to do as they liked. O’Toole’s inner circle saw it as a trap. Adopting the motion would create a new fissure in caucus between its Quebec MPs and those opposed to Bill 21.
It seemed that the leaders detractors were not going to stop until they triggered a leadership review.
Internal pressure was brought to bear on O’Toole to consider what grassroots Tories had been asking for via several competing petitions, including one from Conservative Sen. Denise Batters: move up the leadership review.
Then, a week ago Monday, O’Toole gave what many considered a disjointed news conference about the imminent arrival of a trucker convoy in Ottawa. Few knew at the time that his wife Rebecca had just come through surgery, multiple sources told the Star, while O’Toole was juggling the return of Parliament, his restive caucus and the need for a thoughtful response to the demands of the protesters.
His response didn’t land well, and his team knew it. For the next four days, they would fight over how to deal with the convoy.
Videos were shot and shelved, lines argued over. In the meantime, some of his MPs were loudly and proudly backing the truckers.
A caucus retreat that same week turned into a shambles.
One MP took the microphone and gave O’Toole an intense and emotional dressing drown over his handling of COVID-19 vaccination requirements for MPs; when O’Toole suggested they continue the conversation elsewhere, the MP flat-out refused.
The second day of the meeting featured Cummings’s post mortem of the 2021 election campaign — but details from it were being leaked to the media even as O’Toole’s MPs were hearing them for the first time.
The renewed sense of being disrespected, and the fact there was no obvious plan for change in the campaign report, spurred meetings that night on how to gather enough signatures to force a vote on O’Toole’s leadership.
“A letter like this doesn’t come because of a single policy or an ideological divide,” said one MP.
“It’s about character.”
Both sides started making calls over the weekend.
By Monday, it was clear that enough signatures had been gathered to trigger the vote.
O’Toole’s team lashed out, portraying the organizers as acolytes of former leader Andrew Scheer, or members of “the conversion crew” who were still angry about the handling of the conversion therapy bill.
Later that night, O’Toole would issue a statement suggesting there were forces at work trying to drag the party down.
One long-time MP, who said they are in none of those camps, said it was O’Toole’s response that cemented his decision to vote him out.
“I had such high hopes for him as a leader,” the MP said, “but I’ve been left totally disappointed and disillusioned.”
Two MPs told the Star their colleagues lied to O’Toole when he called canvassing for their support, a move many framed as payback for the times they felt O’Toole had deceived them.
“Our support was soft,” said one O’Toole loyalist, “and we couldn’t harden it up.”
In his last-ditch pitch to caucus to keep him on, O’Toole pointed to the party’s gains and growth on his watch.
He promised to move up the leadership review and let the members have their say.
They will now, MPs say, whenever the next leadership race is called.
As for O’Toole, he insists there’s no bad seat in the House of Commons, and says he wants to stay as the MP for Durham.
“I pledge my support and unwavering loyalty to our next leader,” he said following his ouster, “and I urge everyone in our party to come together and do the same.”
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

The experiment has failed. Unifying the right under one national Conservative party isn't working

Publication info: Feb 3, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/experiment-has-failed-unifying-right-under-one/docview/2625376328/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=The+experiment+has+failed.+Unifying+the+right+under+one+national+Conservative+party+isn%27t+working&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-03&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ultimately, the experiment has failed. The saga of Erin O’Toole has demonstrated the near impossibility of uniting the right behind one party. Conservatives who want to challenge Liberal hegemony will have to find another vehicle.
In theory, O’Toole did all the right things. He won the leadership of his party by presenting himself as a true-blue conservative.
Once that was in the bag, he moved quickly to the left in order to appeal to the electorate at large. He endorsed a carbon tax, and had his caucus withdraw its support for conversion therapy. He made a direct pitch to unionized workers. He stopped playing footsie with the Christian right.
In short, he followed the classic formula for Conservative success: Go right to get your party on side; veer left to appeal to the country as a whole.
His problem was that this time, the classic formula didn’t work.
It didn’t work because his caucus eventually refused to play along. Conservatives — and presumably the voters they represent — were sick of hiding their true beliefs just to score easy political points in official Ottawa.
The result was total confusion. O’Toole would articulate one position, while one or more of his caucus mates articulated another.
The contradictions grew particularly intense during last weekend’s trucker protest in Ottawa. Some Conservative MPs supported the protesters. Others, echoing the feelings of many non-Conservative Canadians, were less enthusiastic.
O’Toole himself appeared confused as to what he thought about the protest.
Indeed, O’Toole seemed confused about almost everything. He continued his efforts to appeal to a broad spectrum of Canadians. Yet he might reverse himself if those efforts appeared, in Conservative terms, to be too controversial.
None of this was supposed to work this way. When Stephen Harper’s Canadian Alliance joined forces with Peter MacKay’s Progressive Conservatives, the resultant Conservative Party of Canada was supposed to act as a single, unified party.
The new party, it was thought, would eliminate feuds within the right and eventually bring the Conservatives to power.
Under Harper, this is exactly what happened. The Conservatives won three straight victories. In 2015, they appeared to be settling in for more.
But the feuds didn’t end. They grew. Social conservatives were increasingly at odds with their secular counterparts. Riding associations fractured along ideological lines.
The reasons for this were unclear. In part, they had to do with Harper’s exit from the political scene. With him gone, there was no one to enforce discipline on the party.
But in part, the splits reflected the party’s failure to forge a single coherent vision. There are still two parties warring within the bosom of the unified Conservative movement.
As O’Toole put it this week, one of those parties is modern and moderate. The other is reactionary and extreme.
The moderate party had a chance at winning power, because on most issues it was in sync with the majority of Canadians. The extreme party had no chance because it was not.
This fatal contradiction cannot be wished away. Except for a brief period under Harper, attempts to unite the right have failed.
A new leader will not solve this problem. O’Toole was a perfectly normal leader; he couldn’t make it work. There is no reason to think anyone else could do better.
Perhaps it is time to admit that uniting the right has failed. Perhaps it is time to divide the Conservative party back into its constituent parts. Social conservatives can vote for one party, and fiscal conservatives can vote for another. Those who win seats can form coalitions with like-minded MPs.
It would take a while for conservatives elected under this system to win power. It takes a while already. Recognition that the right is not united would at least be more honest.
Thomas Walkom is a Toronto-based freelance contributing columnist for the Star. Reach him via email: walkomtom@gmail.com

With Erin O'Toole out of the way, will Doug Ford make a bid to become prime minister?

Publication info: Feb 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/with-erin-otoole-out-way-will-doug-ford-make-bid/docview/2625073897/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=With+Erin+O%27Toole+out+of+the+way%2C+will+Doug+Ford+make+a+bid+to+become+prime+minister%3F&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Yes Doug Ford is premier, but a province is not a nation.
Why not Ford Nation — prime minister of all Canada?
Ford has never given up his dream of winning the bigger “brass ring” on Parliament Hill. Those are the words he has used in private moments to describe the one big achievement that still eludes him today.
Now, with Wednesday’s defenestration of Erin O’Toole as federal Conservative leader, a window of opportunity has opened wider for that still-tempting brass ring. With the leadership up for grabs again, is Ford ready to act on his lingering political fantasy?
Surely there are many good reasons to discount this bad idea. But don’t count him out just yet, not until you’ve answered today’s question and tomorrow’s thought experiment:
Who is the most powerful of all Tories in Canada today?
When Ford repurposed himself as the populist premier of the most populous province in Canada, he was quickly regarded as a rock star among his fellow travellers. When he popped up at a federal Conservative convention in 2018, delegates relegated the party’s new national leader at the time, Andrew Scheer, to taking pictures of them with Ford.
Many other Ontario contenders and pretenders will be fielding phone calls today (more on that later). But all eyes are on the premier who will have his ear to the ground — and his cellphone — until the snows melt.
Would Ford be foolish enough to trade the seat of power at Queen’s Park for the slippery slopes of Parliament Hill? History tells us that flirting with federal politics is something of an occupational habit for ambitious provincial leaders and an occupational hazard for a breathless media.
Then-premier Bill Davis kept reporters on the ropes for months over a rumoured federal run in the early 1980s with his mischievous flirtation, equivocation and incantation: “I have no plans to have any plans.”
Even Dalton McGuinty sent up a federal Liberal leadership trial balloon when he announced his resignation as premier in late 2012. The distraction quickly fizzled, as did McGuinty.
But the current premier is a wild card, utterly unpredictable. When he lost Toronto’s 2014 mayoral race, who imagined him leapfrogging to Queen’s Park a few years later?
Unilingual, you say? Unimportant for many of today’s Tories — let’s see what they say of former Saskatchewan premier Brad Wall’s lack of French.
Asked about his prospects Tuesday — back when the question of O’Toole’s fate was more hypothetical than spectacle — Ford offered this homespun homily about staying close to home:
“No, I have my hands full — I love being premier of this province,” he began. “That’s my job. I’m just, you know, 24/7 working on getting us out of this pandemic.”
And then, this little tease, intended or not: “When I see this divide in this country and in this province, I want people united and we’re going to get there.”
Note the notion of uniting “this country.” This nation. His Ford Nation?
Spoiler alert: June 2 looms — voting day is a mere four months away, and the unofficial Ontario election campaign is already underway.
Never say never, but timing is always everything in politics. A major inhibition for his federal ambition is that Ford can’t be eyeing Ottawa while neglecting Ontario.
If Ford bides his time and doesn’t bite, some of his predecessors, and cabinet ministers, well might.
In which case, don’t rule out the possibility of two former Ontario Progressive Conservative leaders taking a run at it: Patrick Brown and John Tory are both big city mayors who speak French — Brown with a Brampton power base, Tory straddling Fortress Toronto.
And then there’s Stephen Lecce, who learned everything he knows about politics working for ex-PM Stephen Harper. Ottawa beckons him after being bashed for years by teachers in the education portfolio.
Consider Caroline Mulroney, who has nothing if not name recognition and language cognition. She will be exhorted to follow in the footsteps of her famous father, former PM Brian Mulroney, notwithstanding her humiliating third-place defeat by Ford in 2018, and the minor matter of her media phobia.
Regardless of whether Ford or any other Ontario Tories run for the leadership — or renounce it once and for all — they will be braced for the inevitable fallout from the federal contest. The rival Conservative candidates are likely to lapse into the same old hard-right ideas that don’t play well with the Ontario voters Ford needs to win re-election as premier — anti-abortion with hints of the homophobia, Islamophobia and hatred of gun control that seem to resurface in every race.
With a provincial election underway, Ontario’s PCs will frequently be put on the spot and have to distance themselves with damage control. The spillover will blur and blend the federal and provincial Tory brands.
For Ford, the baggage will get heavier. And the brass ring will remain a distant dream.
Martin Regg Cohn is a Toronto-based columnist focusing on Ontario politics and international affairs for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @reggcohn

What Erin O'Toole's ousting means for BIPOC Canadians

Publication info: Feb 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/what-erin-otooles-ousting-means-bipoc-canadians/docview/2625074114/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=What+Erin+O%27Toole%27s+ousting+means+for+BIPOC+Canadians&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Erin O’Toole is no longer the leader of the Conservative party. Seventy-three MPs voted to launch a leadership race, 13 more than needed to officially oust the one election leader.
How did this happen? Well, that would require a post-mortem longer than this article could allow, but simply put? O’Toole took the party on a fast-moving train to the political centre, something some MP’s and party members decried.
As one focused on fiscal responsibility, I personally had some reservations about the $100 billion dollars in new spending O’Toole’s platform called for, but as a Black gay man, I fully supported his endorsement of a conversion therapy ban and his unending support for communities of colour.
Just one day into Black History Month and I’m already asking myself, “how will my community fare under a new Tory leader?” Last year at this time (in this very same column) I asked, “ If Black loyalty to Liberals equates to our advancement, why do we still face so many challenges?”
Challenges for Canadians who are Black, Indigenous or people of colour (BIPOC) are even more pronounced this year due to an ongoing pandemic, inflation that has driven up the cost of living, and a housing crisis that all but promises to get worst. All of this on top of systemic inequities, discrimination that still exists in 2022, and barriers to resources and opportunities.
All that to say, a new CPC leader will need to understand the unique needs of BIPOC communities, should they wish to earn their support in vote-rich places like Ontario. After all, winning Ontario is an important part of the journey to the prime minister’s office.
Say what you will about Erin O’Toole, but he understood this. It’s exactly why he felt more progressive policies would help conservatives in places like the GTA. His detractors immediately denounced this strategy when conservatives failed to gain momentum in the GTA during the last election. Here’s the thing: they were wrong.
The reality is that perception takes time to change in the eyes of voters and it cannot be done in one cycle. Conservatives tried to capture more of the progressive vote by pulling to the centre, but fruits from those labours wouldn’t appear in just one cycle. For progressive voters, especially those part of BIPOC communities, they need to see a steady commitment to those policies and values over time before placing all their eggs in a big blue basket.
If conservatives win government in the next election, there will be many BIPOC Canadians counting on them to help heal long-existing fractures within their communities. The reality is that all Canadians will need this going forward. In order to successfully meet that need the conservatives must unite within their party; whether a social conservative, fiscal conservative, or progressive conservative. Division will all but certainly promise a continual descent to oblivion for the party, making way for liberals to govern for another 100 years.
A recently founded organization, the “ Majority Committee ,” is a group of Conservative supporters who were backing O’Toole.
“We represent the silent majority of Conservatives who are common-sense, solutions-focused and pragmatic,” founder Fraser Macondald said . “I worry quite a bit about the future of the party if we reverse course and the people who want to replace Mr. O’Toole make us an unviable and irrelevant option for mainstream voters.” The group will now likely seek to get involved in the next looming leadership.
As of publication, names floating around include MP Leslyn Lewis, Pierre Poilievre, Patrick Brown, and Peter MacKay, to name a few. But if any one of them is going to unite this country, they are going to have to unite their party first. Do it conservatives. BIPOC Canadians are depending on you.
Vonny Sweetland is a political organizer and journalist based in Toronto. Follow him on Twitter @vonnysweetland.

____________________________________________________________

'One and done': Inside the plot to oust O'Toole

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Feb 2022: A.1.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/one-done-inside-plot-oust-otoole/docview/2625202641/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=%27One+and+done%27%3A+Inside+the+plot+to+oust+O%27Toole&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-02-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: For some Conservatives, it became clear more than a year ago that Erin O'Toole wasn't going to survive as leader of their party.
O'Toole himself didn't realize it until hours before he was ousted.
In that chasm between O'Toole and many members of his party - and the breakdown of good will and communication that created it - lie the reasons that 73 of 119 Conservative MPs voted on Wednesday to kick him out.
Some say it was O'Toole's flip-flops that did him in, others his attempt to move the party to the centre. Some say it was his stance on conversion therapy, others his failure to consult and communicate. Some say his leadership was a casualty of the pandemic.
One common thread that emerged from interviews with Conservative MPs, party staffers, organizers and others with long-standing ties to the party was perhaps best encapsulated by rookie MP Stephen Ellis:
"Democracy is a messy, messy way to do work."
O'Toole won leadership in August 2020, beating out the presumed front-runner Peter MacKay by appealing to the right wing of the party as a "true blue" Conservative and hoovering up support from social conservatives who felt alienated by MacKay's progressive approach.
In his victory speech, he pledged a renewed conservative movement, one that welcomed more Canadians, and many party members nodded in agreement.
In the months following that speech, however, O'Toole sidelined supporters of his rivals in the leadership contest, going so far as to kick one rival - Derek Sloan - out of the Conservative caucus altogether.
Then in March 2021, he gave a speech to the party's policy convention - and while some of its themes echoed his victory speech in August, his "true blue" credentials had already begun to fade in the eyes of the party's membership.
In the August speech, the grassroots heard words of optimism and renewal; in March, they heard insults as O'Toole emphasized the need for the party to have courage, and to prove to voters that it had grown and learned.
"We could get onside with moving the party, but not with being told there was something wrong with us," said one longtime MP.
"We're a big tent party, we always have been. But he started creating camps in that tent with that speech."
Next came carbon pricing. A month after the convention, without warning or briefing any of his MPs, O'Toole dropped a bombshell: the Tories were going to embrace the idea of putting a consumer price on carbon.
"Look, I hate carbon taxes," one MP told the Star this week. "Maybe he never could have convinced me it was the right approach, but he didn't even give us the dignity of being part of the conversation."
At that moment, the bonds of trust between the leader and his party's MPs began to break.
The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic was also throwing up its own challenges.
The Conservative MPs elected in 2019 included many rookies who'd barely taken their seats in the House of Commons before the country closed its doors; another group followed in 2021, when pandemic restrictions remained.
Conservative MP Alex Ruff, a longtime O'Toole supporter, said the team-building necessary for new MPs under a new leader was impossible in the Zoom era.
In his view, what happened in the last week of O'Toole's leadership was a reflection of the pandemic.
"This was about two years of being locked up, frustrated and without being able to come together in person as a team," he said.
People close to O'Toole now acknowledge that he never had a good enough read on his MPs, often minimizing issues and problems or catching up with them too late.
At the point in last summer's election campaign when the Conservatives were on track to potentially form a minority government, many figured that a victory would help soothe some of the ongoing tensions.
Except O'Toole didn't win.
And even as he struck an optimistic tone in the days that followed, his supporters sensed that the beginning of the end could be upon them.
"It was one and done," said a long-time Conservative organizer. "That was the precedent set for Andrew Scheer, and that's what was going to happen to us."
Nonetheless, his team thought they could make it to 2023, when O'Toole would face the leadership review required by the party's constitution. With enough time, some felt they could still turn the ship around.
Deputizing defeated MP James Cumming to conduct a review of the campaign's failings would give them time to present a plan and a path forward, O'Toole's team believed. Maybe they could persuade the caucus - and the party's members - to give him another chance.
It seemed to help that many Conservatives believe in the right of the party's grassroots to handle all matters of leadership.
That's why, in their first meeting of the post-election era, the Conservative MPs were not unanimously in favour of adopting a provision of the Reform Act, which gives a party's MPs the power to call for a leadership review if 20 per cent of caucus wants one.
But the provision was adopted nonetheless. At the time, O'Toole said it was a not a "sword of Damocles" hanging over his head - but that was exactly what it became.
Getting 20 per cent of caucus to sign up took time but, in the end, not as much as even the organizers anticipated.
The irritants had piled up: A snap motion to push a bill banning conversion therapy all the way to the Senate; an apparent flip-flop over mandatory COVID-19 vaccinations on Parliament Hill; a leak of a damaging story about Alberta MP Shannon Stubbs, in what was perceived as retribution for her call for an earlier leadership review.
What his MPs saw as signs of disrespect were considered by O'Toole's team to be the necessary work of bringing a restive group to heel.
Closing out 2021 was the "bloodbath" in a December caucus meeting over Quebec's Bill 21, which prohibits those in positions of public authority from wearing religious symbols at work.
That meeting would set the course for the final days of O'Toole's leadership.
A motion was put up for debate at the next meeting that would see the party condemn Bill 21 in no uncertain terms - even though the party's official policy was that Quebec lawmakers had the right to do as they liked. O'Toole's inner circle saw it as a trap. Adopting the motion would create a new fissure in caucus between its Quebec MPs and those opposed to Bill 21.
It seemed that the leaders detractors were not going to stop until they triggered a leadership review.
Internal pressure was brought to bear on O'Toole to consider what grassroots Tories had been asking for via several competing petitions, including one from Conservative Sen. Denise Batters: Move up the leadership review.
Then, a week ago Monday, O'Toole gave what many considered a disjointed news conference about the imminent arrival of a trucker convoy in Ottawa. Few knew at the time that his wife Rebecca had just come through surgery, multiple sources told the Star, while O'Toole was juggling the return of Parliament, his restive caucus and the need for a thoughtful response to the demands of the protesters.
His response didn't land well, and his team knew it. For the next four days, they would fight over how to deal with the convoy.
Videos were shot and shelved, lines argued over. In the meantime, some of his MPs were loudly and proudly backing the truckers.
A caucus retreat that same week turned into a shambles.
One MP took the microphone and gave O'Toole an intense and emotional dressing drown over his handling of COVID-19 vaccination requirements for MPs; when O'Toole suggested they continue the conversation elsewhere, the MP flat-out refused.
The second day of the meeting featured Cummings's post mortem of the 2021 election campaign - but details from it were being leaked to the media even as O'Toole's MPs were hearing them for the first time.
The renewed sense of being disrespected, and the fact there was no obvious plan for change in the campaign report, spurred meetings that night on how to gather enough signatures to force a vote on O'Toole's leadership.
"A letter like this doesn't come because of a single policy or an ideological divide," said one MP.
"It's about character."
Both sides started making calls over the weekend.
By Monday, it was clear that enough signatures had been gathered to trigger the vote.
O'Toole's team lashed out, portraying the organizers as acolytes of former leader Andrew Scheer, or members of "the conversion crew" who were still angry about the handling of the conversion therapy bill.
Later that night, O'Toole would issue a statement suggesting there were forces at work trying to drag the party down.
One longtime MP, who said they are in none of those camps, said it was O'Toole's response that cemented his decision to vote him out.
"I had such high hopes for him as a leader," the MP said, "but I've been left totally disappointed and disillusioned."
Two MPs told the Star their colleagues lied to O'Toole when he called canvassing for their support, a move many framed as payback for the times they felt O'Toole had deceived them.
"Our support was soft," said one O'Toole loyalist, "and we couldn't harden it up."
In his last-ditch pitch to caucus to keep him on, O'Toole pointed to the party's gains and growth on his watch.
He promised to move up the leadership review and let the members have their say.
They will now, MPs say, whenever the next leadership race is called.
As for O'Toole, he insists there's no bad seat in the House of Commons, and says he wants to stay as the MP for Durham.
"I pledge my support and unwavering loyalty to our next leader," he said following his ouster, "and I urge everyone in our party to come together and do the same."

____________________________________________________________

Firing O'Toole an opportunity, not a crisis

Publication info: Toronto Star ; Toronto, Ont. [Toronto, Ont]. 04 Feb 2022: A.8.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/firing-otoole-opportunity-not-crisis/docview/2625203249/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Firing+O%27Toole+an+opportunity%2C+not+a+crisis&amp;title=Toronto+Star&amp;issn=03190781&amp;date=2022-02-04&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Toronto+Star&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Since the Conservative caucus dumped Erin O'Toole as leader on Wednesday, some have suggested the party is now doomed - that its best chance for mainstream electability was thrown out the window, and that by courting its populist and social conservative flanks, the party relegates itself to a longer stint on the opposition benches. I believe this is too simplistic a read on what happened and ignores the opportunity ahead.
The move to show O'Toole the door was an overwhelming condemnation of O'Toole himself. As one caucus member put it to me Thursday, "He's a hypocrite." The vote was not a condemnation of the more centrist approach O'Toole espoused, it was a denunciation of his performance. Yes, social conservatives are upset with O'Toole. But he betrayed them by courting their support during the leadership race by pretending to be a candidate he had no plans to be.
Discussions about the Conservative party often focus on the challenge of having a large base of social conservatives. They are very influential, and they are organized. Activists dominate many riding associations. They stack delegate nomination meetings to ensure their own supporters vote at party conventions. They're important volunteers who can either help elect candidates or mount challenges against sitting MPs during nomination battles. They are also an important donor base.
But they have not - yet -been the majority of the party.
If O'Toole ran his leadership campaign in 2020 on the platform he presented to Canadians during the 2021 election campaign - pro-choice, in favour of carbon pricing and a temporary ban on assault-style weapons -he would have run to the left of Peter MacKay, a pro-choice candidate, and lost.
O'Toole only became leader by being the second choice of supporters of Derek Sloan and Leslyn Lewis. With two pro-choice candidates, it's safe to assume social conservatives would have left the rest of their preferential ballots blank.
The last time abortion was debated at a Conservative convention was in 2018. The motion, to delete a line in the policy book stating a Conservative government will not support any legislation to regulate abortion, was defeated by a vote of 53 per cent against. Tight, uncomfortably so, but still a defeat. In 2016, 70 per cent of Conservative delegates voted to strike the definition of marriage as a union between one man and one woman from the Tories' policy book.
The message here is clear: the party belongs to those who show up. The fight for what becomes of the Conservative party will happen over the next several months. The next leader will set the tone, the policy priorities, and the parameters of the party's coalition.
If those who are socially progressive and fiscally conservative sit out the fight, that coalition may be dominated by the social conservatives and far-right populists who some in the party now seem preoccupied in courting. So, find desirable candidates. Sell memberships. The formula is not complicated.
It took the Liberals two tries and a near-death experience after Paul Martin to land on Justin Trudeau. The Conservatives are not doomed. They just need to find someone willing to step up and do the work that's required to build a party that reflects the country.
There should be a Conservative leader unafraid to denounce the truck convoy occupying Ottawa. Someone willing to say people have the right to peaceful assembly, but it doesn't look like this. A leader who expresses alarm at the presence of Nazi and Confederate flags, and doesn't just refer to the people waving them as "bad apples."
It should also be possible to have a leader capable of empathy - one who says people who lose their jobs because they refuse to be vaccinated, for whatever reason, should have access to a job bank where employers don't require vaccinations. That the country's safety net includes all Canadians, not just those whose views we agree with.
(To be clear, I remain convinced that not getting vaccinated is a selfish position. The "freedom" signs lining the fence of the parliamentary precinct might as well say "Let more people die" or "Undermine health care." But I also think many who refuse to get vaccinated are scared and misinformed, and I don't think they should lose their houses or have their children go hungry.)
Some of the names currently being tossed around as potential Conservative leaders concern me. I hope the Tories don't settle on a divisive leader who spreads misinformation convincingly.
Canada needs a broad-based party that can challenge the Liberals for power. Not only do the voters deserve choice, but this will help prevent the Grits from being lazy and ensure more accountable government.
It is in all our interests that the Tories pick well.
Twitter: @althiaraj
CAPTION: There should be a Conservative leader unafraid to say that people have the right to peaceful assembly, but it doesn't look like the current protests in Ottawa, writes Althia Raj.PATRICK DOYLE THE CANADIAN PRESS

____________________________________________________________

Who will be the next Conservative leader? Here are some potential contenders

Publication info: Feb 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/who-will-be-next-conservative-leader-here-are/docview/2624993469/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Who+will+be+the+next+Conservative+leader%3F+Here+are+some+potential+contenders&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA — Another race to pick a new Conservative party leader is on.
And in the colourful words of one Conservative MP after Wednesday’s coup that toppled Erin O’Toole, “It’s gonna be a bloody tough job.”
A short race favours the already known and the already well-organized. A longer contest will give others a shot at it.
This will be the fourth leadership contest since the party was born of the 2003 merger between the Reform/Canadian Alliance and the Progressive Conservatives.
Here’s your cheat sheet on those around whom speculation is swirling:

- Pierre Poilievre : The early front-runner. Finance critic, 42. Career politician, former cabinet minister and political aide. Upstaged both O’Toole and Andrew Scheer with savage attacks on Liberal spending policies. Fiscal hawk. Social media savvy. Strong organizer. Poilievre embraced the so-called “Freedom Convoy” plaguing downtown Ottawa now, calling its participants “Bright, joyful & peaceful Canadians championing freedom over fear on Parliament Hill.” If he doesn’t drop out of the race like he did last time, the job could be his to lose.



- Peter MacKay : The longtime aspirant. Lawyer, 56. Former leader of the Progressive Conservative party, who merged it with the Canadian Alliance and stepped aside as Harper ran to take over. Cabinet minister under Harper. Left politics in 2015 ahead of that year’s election. Tried to make a comeback in 2020. Ran to replace Scheer. Despite more caucus support including among many socially conservative MPs, he lost to O’Toole and is still paying off that debt. Now living in Nova Scotia, MacKay works with Deloitte and law firm McInnes Cooper. He is undoubtedly interested again, but much depends on what rules the party sets out.



- Rona Ambrose : Gone but not forgotten. Former interim leader, 52, A Harper cabinet minister, she stepped up when he stepped down after losing in 2015. Socially progressive. Fiscally conservative. Ambrose unified a bruised caucus and was an effective critic of the rookie Trudeau government. Her bio touts that she was the “first leader of the Conservative party to back equal marriage and march in a gay pride parade.” Ambrose now sits on several corporate boards and think tanks, and opted out of the last leadership race. She would start as the strongest female candidate and could rally a lot of support, but may not take the leap.



- Leslyn Lewis : Social conservative standard bearer. Rookie MP, 51. A Jamaican-born lawyer, Lewis blew onto the political scene when she ran against O’Toole for the leadership in 2020 and rallied the social conservative wing of the party. An opponent of abortion and COVID-19 vaccination mandates, she bitterly clashed with O’Toole’s team in the Conservative caucus. Tweeted, “The media and the power structure expect me to sit in the back of the bus. I won’t!” Her fans may want her to run again, but sources say Lewis has privately told others that she will not.



- Michelle Rempel Garner : Western warrior. Prominent Calgary MP, 41. Feminist with an economics degree, sommelier skills and a pro-business, pro-gun bent. Socially progressive, fiscally conservative. Strong advocate for LGBTQ rights. Takes no guff on social media. As an opposition critic, she is a cabinet minister’s worst nightmare. Married to a retired U.S. army veteran, she will be urged to run in the race and has flirted with the possibility in the past. One to watch.



- Brad Wall : Former premier and Saskatchewan Party leader. Bright, quotable, 56. A consultant and political pundit, he left provincial politics in 2017 after a decade in power. His name is often floated for the national job but Wall doesn’t speak French and has not thrown his hat into the ring the last two times the leadership came open, perhaps mindful you need to parlez vous in Parliament.



- Patrick Brown : Political animal. Brampton mayor, 43. A former Conservative MP who became leader of the Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario, then got bounced by his PC caucus amid allegations of misconduct. Definitely kicking the tires at a federal run, sources said Wednesday.



- Caroline Mulroney : Ontario cabinet minister. Lawyer, bilingual, 47. Politically ambitious. The eldest child of former prime minister Brian Mulroney, and the only one to make the leap into elected politics, she ran for the Ontario PC leadership before she’d even run as an MPP. After a rocky start, is finding her feet as a provincial cabinet minister. May be too soon for a successful detour into federal politics.



- Doug Ford: Ontario premier. Chief Etobicoke cheerleader, 57. Timing is everything, and it’s not on Ford’s side, this time. Several close to the premier believe he harbours a desire to be prime minister but faces a looming provincial election. Told reporters this week he has “my hands full. I love being premier of this province, we’re going to build this province, and I’m going to continue leading this province.” So that’s a hard maybe.



- Andrew Scheer : Saskatchewan MP. Former Conservative leader and former Commons speaker, 42. Some of his caucus colleagues rue the day he was forced to step down after losing the 2019 election and would love to see him back. But Scheer has ruled out a comeback and wants to remain, as one supporter said, as a team player and one day serve as a cabinet minister in a Conservative government.


Tonda MacCharles is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @tondamacc

Ontario's integrity commissioner finds no wrongdoing in proposed rerouting of Bradford Bypass

Publication info: Feb 2, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/ontarios-integrity-commissioner-finds-no/docview/2624994767/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ontario%27s+integrity+commissioner+finds+no+wrongdoing+in+proposed+rerouting+of+Bradford+Bypass&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-02&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ontario’s integrity commissioner has found no evidence of wrongdoing by Transportation Minister Caroline Mulroney or Associate Minister Stan Cho in the government’s proposed rerouting of the planned Bradford Bypass.
The proposed route change of the controversial highway would send it around Cho’s father’s property in East Gwillimbury instead of cutting through it.
Integrity commissioner J. David Wake’s report was in response to a complaint filed by NDP MPP Taras Natyshak, who called for an investigation into Premier Doug Ford, Mulroney and Cho, alleging there was conflict of interest and undue influence over the Bradford Bypass.
The MPP’s complaint followed a joint investigation by Torstar and Canada’s National Observer last October , which found Associate Minister Cho’s father co-owns Silver Lakes Golf and Country Club in East Gwillimbury — a property that would be spared under the recently proposed route change.
“On the information available to me I was satisfied that neither Minister Mulroney, Mr. Cho nor their staff had any involvement in directing the process which led to a proposed highway realignment avoiding the golf course,” the commissioner said in his 12-page report.
Wake had previously cleared Ford of any conflict of interest in the planning of the 16.2-km Bradford Bypass, which would connect Highways 404 and 400.
A senior ministry of transportation official told the commissioner that the route change was made by staff and consultants working in the ministry with no involvement from Mulroney and her staff.
Mulroney told the commissioner that she did not know of the change to the proposed route that would circumvent Cho’s father’s business and was never briefed on it until she informed herself for the purposes of responding to Natyshak’s complaint, according to the report.
“I find that there is not only insufficient evidence to support Mr. Natyshak’s allegations, but what evidence there is points very much in the opposite direction,” the commissioner said in his report.
Cho’s office had told Torstar/Observer that the MPP declared a conflict of interest upon his appointment, with a protocol in place blocking his access to information related to the bypass.
In a submission to the commissioner, Mulroney rejected Natyshak’s allegation that she may have allowed information relayed to her by Cho concerning the route of the bypass to influence the ministry of transportation’s decision to propose the route.
“I had no information from Associate Minister Cho, and I have done nothing to influence the route of the bypass, let alone to further my private interest or to improperly further another person’s private interest,” Mulroney is quoted as saying in the report.
Mulroney said she was aware that Cho’s father had an ownership interest in Silver Lakes but never discussed the matter with him because “she felt it would be inappropriate.”
Mulroney confirmed Cho invited her to his father’s golf course in East Gwillimbury in March, weeks before the proposed route change was announced. She said she attended in her capacity as MPP for York-Simcoe, and did not discuss anything related to her role as Minister of Transportation or to the Bradford Bypass.
Cho, an MPP for Willowdale, joined her at Silver Lakes because he knew she would meet his parents and he wanted to be present “because I am so proud of them,” the report said.
“I am happy he has made clear what I have maintained now for months — I was not involved in any decisions regarding the routing of the Bradford Bypass,” Cho tweeted in response to the commissioner’s report.
In his statement, he said his parents who built their lives in Canada from scratch have been subjected to racist attacks following the Star article about the rerouting of the bypass. He said he expects an apology from the NDP for jumping to conclusions.
In her tweet, Mulroney said, “We are moving full steam ahead with the Bradford Bypass and other critically needed transportation projects across the province.”
The Bradford Bypass, a key pledge in the Tories’ June 2 re-election campaign, would cross 27 waterways and cut through environmentally sensitive Holland Marsh lands, impacting about 39 hectares of wildlife habitat and 11 hectares of wetlands.
Sheila Wang is a municipal politics and general assignment reporter for YorkRegion.com and its sister papers. Reach her via email: swang@metroland.com

Mulroney told the integrity commissioner that she attended in her capacity as MPP for York-Simcoe, and did not discuss anything related to the Bradford Bypass.

Erin O'Toole is in the fight of his political life as leadership challenge looms

Publication info: Feb 1, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/erin-otoole-is-fight-his-political-life-as/docview/2624766496/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Erin+O%27Toole+is+in+the+fight+of+his+political+life+as+leadership+challenge+looms&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: OTTAWA — Conservative Leader Erin O’Toole and his team worked furiously to salvage his leadership Tuesday, on the eve of a crucial caucus vote that some party insiders predicted he has little chance of surviving.
Conservative MPs are set to vote Wednesday on whether O’Toole ought to stay on as leader. If a majority of them don’t agree that he should, he’ll be shown the door.
O’Toole and some of his closest allies were working the phones Tuesday, trying to gauge whether that majority exists. But sources told the Star that his team was reaching out in some cases to MPs who have already signed on to the effort to dump him.
“He doesn’t have the support he thinks he does,” said one MP, speaking on the condition they not be named to freely discuss internal party matters.
Thirty-five MPs are squarely in favour of ousting O’Toole, having signed a letter calling for a vote on whether he should remain on as leader.
That effort began immediately after the Conservatives failed to beat the Liberals in the 2021 election, and has gained momentum in fits and starts as the party has struggled to make gains in popular support.
Things came to a head last week, when Conservative MPs heard the results of the party’s election review. During a heated meeting, some caucus members openly challenged O’Toole in a way that left many with the impression his days were numbered.
When news of the effort to remove him broke Monday, O’Toole’s response painted his critics as wanting to take the party down an angry and negative path, one that he characterized as a political dead end.
He returned to that theme Tuesday during calls with his MPs, several told the Star, and promised new approaches on policy.
But trying to characterize his opponents as belonging to specific wings of the party — he cited those opposed to vaccination among them — just made him new enemies, several Conservative MPs said.
“He’s doing exactly what he criticizes Justin Trudeau for doing — dividing people, and pitting them against each other,” one MP said.
That in turn is uniting O’Toole’s critics against him, another MP said, because there is a common thread that links his detractors: broken trust.
“There is no policy idea he could put forward that would fix any of this,” the MP said.
The process for a leadership review is enshrined in the Reform Act, legislation designed to give MPs more power over how their caucus runs.
To trigger a leadership review, a written notice signed by at least 20 per cent of the party’s caucus is sent to the chair. With 35 of the caucus’s 119 members having signed the letter, that threshold has been met.
A vote by secret ballot will be held electronically during a caucus meeting Wednesday on Zoom.
O’Toole only needs a simple majority of votes in his favour to claim the support of his caucus. However, as one MP put it to the Star on Tuesday, “even if he gets it, he doesn’t really have it,” given that 35 MPs have already moved against him.
If the MPs vote to replace O’Toole, a vote to choose an interim leader will be held later Wednesday evening. Names already in the mix Tuesday were deputy leader Candice Bergen, Quebec MP Gerard Deltell and former Tory cabinet minister Ed Fast.
Bergen was among the handful of Conservative MPs who voiced support for O’Toole on Tuesday.
“I want Erin O’Toole to remain as leader,” she told reporters.
While grassroots efforts to turf O’Toole have sprung up since the election, one in support of his continued leadership was relaunched on Tuesday.
Fraser Macdonald, a former Conservative campaign manager in Pickering-Uxbridge, is one of the organizers of the Majority Committee, which he said is meant to encourage a silent majority of Tories who support O’Toole’s approach to come forward.
He said their perspectives are never voiced as loudly as those who feel the party needs to tack farther right, and it’s time for a change.
“It’s hard to get people to march in the streets about moderate policy,” Macdonald said.
Macdonald launched a petition after the 2021 election to encourage O’Toole to stay on, an effort that O’Toole seized upon as proof that he still had the support of party members.
Macdonald told the Star Tuesday afternoon that he hadn’t been in contact with O’Toole’s team.
Several former Tory candidates, including some in the Greater Toronto Area, voiced support for O’Toole on Tuesday, as did Alberta MP Tim Uppal and Nova Scotia MP Chris D’Entremont.
Finance critic Pierre Poilievre, who had contemplated a run for leadership in the 2020 race that O’Toole ultimately won, did not return a request for comment Tuesday.
Poilievre’s name tops the lists of many party insiders as the person who make a bid if a leadership contest is called.
Another potential contender has already turned down the job. Premier Doug Ford said Tuesday he has no interest in pursuing the federal leadership.
“I have my hands full. I love being premier of this province. We’re going to build this province, and I’m going to continue leading this province,” said Ford, whose Progressive Conservative government is up for re-election on June 2.
“That’s my job, 24-7. I want to unite this province. I can’t stand this divide,” he said.
With files from Robert Benzie
Stephanie Levitz is an Ottawa-based reporter covering federal politics for the Star. Follow her on Twitter: @StephanieLevitz

Ontario confirms 290 medical exemptions from COVID-19 vaccinations

Publication info: Feb 1, 2022.

https://libproxy.wlu.ca/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/blogs-podcasts-websites/ontario-confirms-290-medical-exemptions-covid-19/docview/2624766590/se-2?accountid=15090

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://ocul-wlu.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/openurl?institution=01OCUL_WLU&amp;vid=01OCUL_WLU:WLU_DEF&amp;?url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=unknown&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Acanadiannews&amp;atitle=Ontario+confirms+290+medical+exemptions+from+COVID-19+vaccinations&amp;title=&amp;issn=&amp;date=2022-02-01&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=&amp;au=&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Ontario has granted fewer than 300 medical exemptions from COVID-19 vaccinations a month into a new system that requires them to be verified by local health units — a measure intended to cut down on fraud .
Now integrated into QR codes used under the proof-of-vaccination system to get into gyms, cinemas, sporting events, restaurants, bars, concert halls and other venues, the exemptions replace the previous regime in which patrons could show an exemption letter from a doctor to gain entry.
There were 290 medical exemptions registered in the provincial COVax computer system as of Monday’s reopening , according to government figures provided to the Star. Ontario’s population is approximately 14.7 million.
The relatively low number suggests the new system is working in the wake of concerns from chief medical officer Dr. Kieran Moore that no more than five in 100,000 Ontarians have specific and rare medical conditions that medically qualify them for vaccination exemptions, officials said.
“We’re very pleased that given the limited number of valid medical exemptions issued to date, the process is working and individuals with legitimate medical exemptions are able to be accommodated,” said Alexandra Hilkene, a spokesperson for Health Minister Christine Elliott.
Critics complained the old system of presenting doctor’s letters was ripe for abuse and forgeries. The College of Physicians and Surgeons of Ontario is investigating more than 40 doctors for COVID-19-related issues, which include potentially bogus exemptions.
One government source told the Star last fall that “we’ve seen the same doctors giving out exemptions to everyone who asks.” It’s not known how many potentially invalid exemption letters were circulating.
Health units in Ontario have granted another 234 exemptions to citizens participating in vaccine trials.
Concerns about exemptions were amplified in the fall when two of Premier Doug Ford’s then-70 MPPs claimed them — a statistical anomaly.
Lindsey Park (Durham) and Christina Mitas of (Scarborough Centre) have announced they will not run in the June 2 election. Park quit the Progressive Conservative caucus last fall, leaving Mitas as the lone unvaccinated Tory MPP after the premier required all his members to be vaccinated unless they had a valid exemption.
Toronto Public Health said it has received 79 exemption requests from qualified medical practitioners and confirmed 58 of them. Eight were denied, and doctors or nurse practitioners who submitted another 13 have been asked for more detail “ due to incomplete information in the initial submission.”
“Designated Toronto Public Health staff reviews each request to ensure the practitioner is qualified to make a submission according to the province’s criteria and that the information provided on the submission template complies with those criteria,” the health unit added in a statement.
In neighbouring Peel, medical professionals can submit exemption applications to a secure online portal launched last week. To date, two exemptions have been requested and both were granted, Peel Public Health told the Star on Tuesday.
York Region Public Health reported 22 exemption requests with 20 approved, a rate of 1.8 per 100,000 residents — well below the statistical threshold set by Moore.
“Individuals without a clinic assessment from an Ontario health care professional will not be considered medical exempt from receiving the COVID-19 vaccine,” said York Region spokesperson Melissa Pinto.
The Durham Region public health unit has received 11 exemption requests. Nine were granted and two remain under review.
Rob Ferguson is a Toronto-based reporter covering Ontario politics for the Star. Follow him on Twitter: @robferguson1
